Pleasure is a key aspect of life, and human beings seek out what gives them pleasure. We are naturally attracted to what makes us feel good. \n\n\nTake my favorite food, cheese, for instance. Scientific studies have revealed that cheese contains a chemical called casein, known for its ability to induce feelings of pleasure. This chemical is so powerful that it triggers the same brain regions as opioids, potentially leading to addictive behaviors. Yet, my intention is not addiction, but rather, to experience the joy that comes from feeling good. Hence, my love for cheese. \n\nBut it&#x27;s not just about the cheese. I often find myself pondering\u2014what truly brings us that feeling of goodness?  What are the essential elements that guarantee a delightful human experience? Is it all about chemical receptors in the brain? Is happiness just a pill or does it encompass something deeper? Is the true science of feeling good science or just a philosophy or attitude that keeps the human mood in optimal condition? Let\u2019s explore what we know about the science of feeling good and its intersections with behavioral philosophy and psychology to get the bottom of the mystery humans have pondered and sought for millennia: How to feel good all the time and lead a happy and meaningful life. \n______\n\n\nFinish writing the blog post/article above supplementing it with scientific, psychology, and philosophic ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Effect of feeling good on helping: cookies and kindness.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Two experiments with adult subjects investigated the effects of a person&#x27;s positive affective state on his or her subsequent helpfulness to others. \\&quot;Feeling good\\&quot; was induced by having received cookies while studying in a library (Study I) and by having found a dime in the coin return of a public telephone while making a call (Study II). In Study I, where the dependent measure involved volunteering in reply to a student&#x27;s request, a distinction was made between specific willingness to help and general willingness to engage in any subsequent activity. In Study II, the dependent measure was whether subjects spontaneously helped to pick up papers that were dropped in front of them. On the basis of previous research, it was predicted that subjects who were thus made to \\&quot;feel good\\&quot; would be more helpful than control subjects. Results support the predictions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Alice M. Isen&quot;,&quot;Paula F. Levin&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1972,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of personality and social psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/feeling-helping-cookies-kindness-isen/918add22d7765176be5e98c096c4966e/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/H0032317&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;21 3&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          384-8\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:1},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Subjective well-being. The science of happiness and a proposal for a national index.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;One area of positive psychology analyzes subjective well-being (SWB), people&#x27;s cognitive and affective evaluations of their lives. Progress has been made in understanding the components of SWB, the importance of adaptation and goals to feelings of well-being, the temperament underpinnings of SWB, and the cultural influences on well-being. Representative selection of respondents, naturalistic experience sampling measures, and other methodological refinements are now used to study SWB and could be used to produce national indicators of happiness.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;E. Diener&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2000,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;The American psychologist&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/wellbeing-science-happiness-proposal-index-diener/93acebd3c0125f5aa30a28fc32ca0b70/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0003-066X.55.1.34&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;55 1&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          34-43\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:2},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Positive psychology. An introduction.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;A science of positive subjective experience, positive individual traits, and positive institutions promises to improve quality of life and prevent the pathologies that arise when life is barren and meaningless. The exclusive focus on pathology that has dominated so much of our discipline results in a model of the human being lacking the positive features that make life worth living. Hope, wisdom, creativity, future mindedness, courage, spirituality, responsibility, and perseverance are ignored or explained as transformations of more authentic negative impulses. The 15 articles in this millennial issue of the American Psychologist discuss such issues as what enables happiness, the effects of autonomy and self-regulation, how optimism and hope affect health, what constitutes wisdom, and how talent and creativity come to fruition. The authors outline a framework for a science of positive psychology, point to gaps in our knowledge, and predict that the next century will see a science and profession that will come to understand and build the factors that allow individuals, communities, and societies to flourish.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. A field concerned with well-being and optimal functioning, positive psychology aims to broaden the focus of clinical psychology beyond suffering and its direct alleviation. Our proposed conceptual framework parses happiness into three domains: pleasure, engagement, and meaning. For each of these constructs, there are now valid and practical assessment tools appropriate for the clinical setting. Additionally, mounting evidence demonstrates the efficacy and effectiveness of positive interventions aimed at cultivating pleasure, engagement, and meaning. We contend that positive interventions are justifiable in their own right. Japanese and American college students (total N = 913) reported how frequently they experienced various emotional states in daily life. In support of the hypothesis, the reported frequency of general positive emotions (e.g. calm, elated) was most closely associated with the reported frequency of interpersonally engaged positive emotions (e.g. friendly feelings) in Japan, but with the reported frequency of interpersonally disengaged positive emotions (e.g. pride) in the United States. Further, for Americans the reported frequency of experience was considerably higher for positive emotions than for negative emotions, but for Japanese it was higher for engaged emotions than for disengaged emotions. The terms thoughts, feelings, and behaviors include all psychological variables that are measurable in a human being. The statement that others&#x27; presence may be imagined or implied suggests that we are prone to social influence even when no other people are present, such as when watching television, or following internalized cultural norms. Social psychologists typically explain human behavior as a result of the interaction of mental states and immediate social situations. In general, social psychologists have a preference for laboratory-based, empirical findings. Social psychology theories tend to be specific and focused, rather than global and general. Social psychology is an interdisciplinary domain that bridges the gap between psychology and sociology. During the years immediately following World War II, there was frequent collaboration between psychologists and sociologists.[2] However, the two disciplines have become increasingly specialized and isolated from each other in recent years, with sociologists focusing on \\&quot;macro variables\\&quot; (e.g., social structure) to a much greater extent. Nevertheless, sociological approaches to social psychology remain an important counterpart to psychological research in this area. In addition to the split between psychology and sociology, there has been a somewhat less pronounced difference in emphasis between American social psychologists and European social psychologists. I argue that the motivational theory is wrong, and not only wrong, but backwards. The heterogeneity problem is the principal source of motivation for this, otherwise, highly counterintuitive theory. Pieters&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2008,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Judgment and Decision Making&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/emotion-specificity-decision-making-feeling-zeelenberg/c9bcad6805d2562bace3553518d85f22/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1017/s1930297500000139&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:16},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Handbook of motivation and cognition : foundations of social behavior&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The apparent success of cognitive principles in accounting for several behaviors has led social psychologists to question the need for motivations and other \\&quot;hot\\&quot; dispositional constructs. In their place, they postulate nonmotivational \\&quot;cold\\&quot; cognitions. Behavioral variations between individuals are thus reduced to differences in information processing abilities, while biases and other apparently motivated behaviors are explained on the \\&quot;faulty computer\\&quot; model. However, as many cognitive psychologists now acknowledge this mechanistic theory fails to tie the processing of information to the performance of actions. In a creative attempt to bridge this gap, the editors and investigators have begun to challenge the prevailing hot/cold, either/or dichotomy. Instead, they propose the \\&quot;warm look\\&quot; - a synergistic approach to the roles of \\&quot;hot\\&quot; motivations and \\&quot;cold\\&quot; cognitions in the production of behavior. In their view, neither one alone is sufficient to explain social phenomena. In fact, outside of theory, the two are inseparable. This comprehensive handbook attempts an integration of contrasting approaches to behavior discusses the dual contributions of cognition and motivation to affective states, the development and evaluation of the self, and the setting and attainment of goals. Central themes include the notion of different public and private selves forming distinct influences on motivational behavior; the key role of affect in mediating social information processing; and the differences between informational and affective value, or between behavior geared to finding out versus behavior prompted by a desire to feel good. While much remains to be learned about the complex interplay of motivation and cognition, these studies demonstrate that the two can no longer be treated as separate, unrelated factors. Subjective states and goals clearly influence information processing, while the acquisition of information alters affect and behavior. An ambitious and original attempt to bridge the gap between thought and action, the Handbook is an indispensable reference for all social cognitive and developmental psychologists, investigators of personality and motivation, and advanced students in these areas.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;R. In contrast, behavioral ecologists assume them to indicate behavioral intentions or action requests. To test these contrasting positions, over 2,000 online participants were presented with facial expressions and asked what they revealed-feeling states, behavioral intentions, or action requests. The majority of the observers chose feeling states as the message of facial expressions of disgust, fear, sadness, happiness, and surprise, supporting the emotions view. Only the anger display tended to elicit more choices of behavioral intention or action request, partially supporting the behavioral ecology view. The results support the view that facial expressions communicate emotions, with emotions being multicomponential phenomena that comprise feelings, intentions, and wishes.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;G. This point of view, however, has come under increasing criticism among positive psychologists, and in this chapter we complement these recent perspectives. By applying principles of motivation science, we construct an alternative theory of the good life that emphasizes the importance of people having an effective organization of their value, truth, and control motives (Higgins, 2012). This working together among value, truth, and control motives creates the sense of an overall \u201cfit\u201d with one&#x27;s world that creates an experience of \u201cfeeling right\u201d about one&#x27;s life. Here&#x27;s how these studies contribute to our understanding:\n\n1. **Positive affective state enhances helpfulness**: Individuals in a positive mood, such as those experiencing the joy of consuming a favorite food like cheese, are more likely to be helpful and kind to others. This suggests that feeling good not only benefits the individual but also impacts their social behavior positively [(Isen &amp; Levin, 1972)](https://consensus.app/papers/feeling-helping-cookies-kindness-isen/918add22d7765176be5e98c096c4966e/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n2. **Subjective well-being and happiness**: Subjective well-being, or people&#x27;s cognitive and affective evaluations of their lives, plays a crucial role in what makes us feel good. Nevertheless, I can provide a general overview based on established psychological theories and research findings.\n\n### Positive States vs. Immediate Stimuli\n\n**Positive States**:\nPositive states such as happiness, contentment, or joy are generally more enduring emotional conditions. They can be influenced by a variety of factors, including one&#x27;s general outlook on life, long-term relationships, career satisfaction, and a sense of purpose or achievement. These states are typically not the direct result of a single stimulus but are built over time through experiences, thoughts, and behaviors that align with one&#x27;s values and goals.\n\n**Immediate Stimuli**:\nImmediate stimuli that produce &#x27;feel good&#x27; feelings are typically specific, short-term triggers that lead to a quick, often visceral reaction. Examples include tasting your favorite food, receiving a compliment, listening to a favorite piece of music, or experiencing a warm, sunny day. These stimuli can directly impact the brain&#x27;s reward system, releasing neurotransmitters such as dopamine and serotonin, which contribute to feelings of pleasure and satisfaction.\n\n### Mechanism by Which Stimuli Produce Positive Feelings\n\n1. **Sensory Pleasure**: This is the simplest form of pleasure, which comes directly from the senses (e.g., taste, touch, sound, sight, and smell). For example, eating a piece of chocolate can immediately stimulate the brain&#x27;s reward centers, releasing dopamine.\n\n2. **Social Interaction**: Positive social interactions can stimulate the release of oxytocin, often referred to as the &#x27;cuddle hormone&#x27;, which increases feelings of trust, bonding, and social connection.\n\n3. **Novelty**: New experiences or unexpected surprises can trigger the release of dopamine, leading to feelings of pleasure and curiosity.\n\n4. **Accomplishment**: Completing a task or achieving a goal can lead to a sense of satisfaction and elation. This is often associated with the release of endorphins and dopamine, contributing to what is sometimes called the &#x27;achievement high&#x27;.\n\n5. **Aesthetic Appreciation**: Encountering beauty, whether in nature, art, or music, can evoke a profound sense of awe and pleasure, often associated with increased activity in the brain&#x27;s frontal lobes, which are involved in emotional regulation and meaning-making.\n\n6. **Altruism**: Engaging in acts of kindness or helping others can produce a &#x27;helper&#x27;s high&#x27;, associated with endorphin release, which leads to feelings of happiness and well-being.\n\nEach of these mechanisms involves complex interactions within the brain and body, influenced by individual perceptions, past experiences, and personal values. While the immediate pleasure from stimuli is often short-lived, it can contribute to longer-term happiness when integrated into a balanced and fulfilling life. If you have specific aspects you want to delve into or need more detailed explanations, please let me know!"]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

"update_time": 1710529393.1107135, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Emotional states and physical health.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive emotional states may promote healthy perceptions, beliefs, and physical well-being itself. To explore potential mechanisms linking pleasant feelings and good health, the authors consider several lines of research, including (a) direct effects of positive affect on physiology, especially the immune system, (b) the information value of emotional experiences, (c) the psychological resources engendered by positive feeling states, (d) the ways in which mood can motivate health-relevant behaviors, and (e) the elicitation of social support. Positive emotions are conscious processes that involve a variety of components, such as a pleasant experience, facial/body expressions, evaluations, and especially behavioural plans and activation states. People&#x27;s cognitive process is often accompanied by emotions, and the influence of positive emotions on cognitive activities has gradually become the focus of research in recent years. This study constructs a regulation model and an assessment model of positive emotions, and analyses the neural mechanisms of the effects of dopamine substances on human positive emotions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Jie Yin&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2019,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Translational Neuroscience&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/study-progress-neural-mechanism-positive-emotions-yin/81d62d707adc575a836980f192b06f33/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1515/tnsci-2019-0016&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;10&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;93 - 98&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:2},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The neurobiology of positive emotions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Compared to the study of negative emotions such as fear, the neurobiology of positive emotional processes and the associated positive affect (PA) states has only recently received scientific attention. Biological theories conceptualize PA as being related to (i) signals indicating that bodies are returning to equilibrium among those studying homeostasis, (ii) utility estimation among those favoring neuroeconomic views, and (iii) approach and other instinctual behaviors among those cultivating neuroethological perspectives. Indeed, there are probably several distinct forms of positive affect, but all are closely related to ancient sub-neocortical limbic brain regions we share with other mammals. There is now a convergence of evidence to suggest that various regions of the limbic system, including especially ventral striatal dopamine systems are implemented in an anticipatory (appetitive) positive affective state. Dopamine independent mechanisms utilizing opiate and GABA receptors in the ventral striatum, amygdala and orbital frontal cortex are important in elaborating consummatory PA (i.e. sensory pleasure) states, and various neuropeptides mediate homeostatic satisfactions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. Burgdorf&quot;,&quot;J. Panksepp&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2006,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Neuroscience &amp; Biobehavioral Reviews&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/neurobiology-emotions-burgdorf/eec9b7bfa4855b878ed63d3b78f87a91/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.neubiorev.2005.06.001&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;30&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;173-187&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:3},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Pleasure as a sign you can attend to something else: Placing positive feelings within a general model of affect&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive feelings are considered within the framework of a general model of origins and functions of affect. This model treats affect as reflecting the error signal of a feedback loop managing rate of incentive-seeking (and threat-avoidant) behaviour. In this view, positive feelings represent a sign that things are going better than necessary and are presumed to induce coasting. A tendency to coast is seen as facilitating the shift of attention and effort to other behavioural domains, where they may be needed more or where unforeseen opportunities have arisen. Such a function for positive feelings would permit the person both to maintain satisfactory standing with regard to multiple goals and to take advantage of unforeseen opportunities, thus providing adaptive value. Comparisons are made to other recently developed ideas concerning the functions of positive feelings.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;C. Carver&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2003,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Cognition and Emotion&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/pleasure-sign-attend-something-else-placing-feelings-carver/f1387f6706c8518e95e5c2cf4e2415e9/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/02699930302294&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;17&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;241 - 261&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:4},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;What Good Are Positive Emotions?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This article opens by noting that positive emotions do not fit existing models of emotions. Consequently, a new model is advanced to describe the form and function of a subset of positive emotions, including joy, interest, contentment, and love. This new model posits that these positive emotions serve to broaden an individual&#x27;s momentary thought\u2013action repertoire, which in turn has the effect of building that individual&#x27;s physical, intellectual, and social resources. Empirical evidence to support this broaden-and-build model of positive emotions is reviewed, and implications for emotion regulation and health promotion are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1998,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Review of General Psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/what-good-positive-emotions-fredrickson/a535b0f0d83d5d868fe18409e2ee804d/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/1089-2680.2.3.300&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;2&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;300 - 319&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:5},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Emotional states and physical health.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive emotional states may promote healthy perceptions, beliefs, and physical well-being itself. We review and integrate the different perspectives on positive emotions (i.e., positive valence, positive emotion regulation strategies, and positive adaptive function) and the four main mechanisms (i.e., cognition, affect, behavior, and physiology) that lead to positive organizational outcomes. There is growing evidence that positive emotions influence variables vital for workplace success such as positive beliefs, creativity, work engagement, positive coping, health, teamwork and collaboration, customer satisfaction, leadership, and performance. We additionally review dynamic features of positive emotions (i.e., intraindividual variability, reactivity, inertia, cycles, feedback loops) and their relation to psychological and work outcomes. Finally, we discuss additional questions and future directions for consideration.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;E. Diener&quot;,&quot;Stuti Thapa&quot;,&quot;L. Tay&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2020,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Annual Review of Organizational Psychology and Organizational Behavior&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/emotions-work-diener/8819cf4f1b0d5c10a78020bcbcf1daea/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1146/annurev-orgpsych-012119-044908&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:7},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Upward spirals of positive emotions counter downward spirals of negativity: insights from the broaden-and-build theory and affective neuroscience on the treatment of emotion dysfunctions and deficits in psychopathology.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This review integrates Fredrickson&#x27;s broaden-and-build theory of positive emotions with advances in affective neuroscience regarding plasticity in the neural circuitry of emotions to inform the treatment of emotion deficits within psychopathology. We first present a body of research showing that positive emotions broaden cognition and behavioral repertoires, and in so doing, build durable biopsychosocial resources that support coping and flourishing mental health. Next, by explicating the processes through which momentary experiences of emotions may accrue into self-perpetuating emotional systems, the current review proposes an underlying architecture of state-trait interactions that engenders lasting affective dispositions. This theoretical framework is then used to elucidate the cognitive-emotional mechanisms underpinning three disorders of affect regulation: depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia. In turn, two mind training interventions, mindfulness and loving-kindness meditation, are highlighted as means of generating positive emotions that may counter the negative affective processes implicated in these disorders. We conclude with the proposition that positive emotions may exert a countervailing force on the dysphoric, fearful, or anhedonic states characteristic of psychopathologies typified by emotional dysfunctions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Eric L. Garland&quot;,&quot;Barbara Fredrickson&quot;,&quot;A. Kring&quot;,&quot;David P Johnson&quot;,&quot;Piper S. Its psychological mechanism may be:when pursuing positive emotion comes to be a major goal, people tend to(1) set a too high standard for happy emotion;(2) obtain happiness through ineffective ways;(3) monitor the process of getting happy instead of immersing in it. There are many questions should be further explored:(1) Revealing the consequences of pursuing positive emotion comprehensively;(2) The neural mechanisms of pursuing positive emotion&#x27;s negative effects;(3) The cross-culture differences of pursuing positive emotion;(4) To explore the way to gain positive results in pursuing positive emotion.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Li Aimei&quot;,&quot;Lin Xiaoping&quot;,&quot;Gao Jieyi&quot;,&quot;Peng Yuan&quot;,&quot;Xia Ying&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2015,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/effect-pursuing-positive-emotion-psychological-aimei/5e14d1e63f6e574ab711db6bdc135e51/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.3724/SP.J.1042.2015.00979&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;23&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;979-989&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:9},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;How Positive Emotions Build Physical Health&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The mechanisms underlying the association between positive emotions and physical health remain a mystery. We hypothesize that an upward-spiral dynamic continually reinforces the tie between positive emotions and physical health and that this spiral is mediated by people\u2019s perceptions of their positive social connections. We tested this overarching hypothesis in a longitudinal field experiment in which participants were randomly assigned to an intervention group that self-generated positive emotions via loving-kindness meditation or to a waiting-list control group. Participants in the intervention group increased in positive emotions relative to those in the control group, an effect moderated by baseline vagal tone, a proxy index of physical health. Increased positive emotions, in turn, produced increases in vagal tone, an effect mediated by increased perceptions of social connections. This experimental evidence identifies one mechanism\u2014perceptions of social connections\u2014through which positive emotions build physical health, indexed as vagal tone. Results suggest that positive emotions, positive social connections, and physical health influence one another in a self-sustaining upward-spiral dynamic.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Bethany E. Kok&quot;,&quot;Kimberly A. Coffey&quot;,&quot;M. Cohn&quot;,&quot;Lahnna I Catalino&quot;,&quot;Tanya Vacharkulksemsuk&quot;,&quot;S. Algoe&quot;,&quot;Mary M. Brantley&quot;,&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2013,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Psychological Science&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/emotions-build-physical-health-kok/6b3f8ad54875573a8a46f3c8d77aa8cd/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/0956797612470827&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;24&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1123 - 1132&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:10},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;BRAIN MECHANISMS OF HAPPINESS&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Happiness is a kind of subjective feeling of positive emotions. Since the psychological process of reward is closely linked to pleasure, studies to elucidate the brain mechanisms of happiness have focused on the neural circuitry that processes reward information. Brain imaging studies have revealed that the orbitofrontal cortex, cingulate cortex, medial prefrontal cortex, insula, nucleus accumbens, ventral pallidum, substantia nigra, and ventral tegmental area are the key areas related to happiness. When we consider the brain mechanisms of happiness, we need to distinguish between the neural mechanisms for liking and wanting, and between those that encode and cause pleasant feelings. Among these brain areas, subcortical structures participate in \u201cwanting\u201d, while cortical areas participate in \u201cliking\u201d. Orbitofrontal activity has been shown to encode the subjective experience of pleasure. However, it is not clear whether orbitofrontal activity actually causes pleasant feelings. Since the neuroscience of happiness is still in the primitive stage, further experiments are needed to elucidate the brain mechanisms of happiness.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. Funahashi&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2011,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Psychologia&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/brain-mechanisms-happiness-funahashi/0ebc7f68c26e58c4a6189a5f3891f3e2/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.2117/PSYSOC.2011.222&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;54&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;222-233&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:11},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Working mechanisms in positive interventions: A study using daily assessment of positive emotions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;ABSTRACT One commonly suggested mechanism in positive psychology interventions (PPIs) involves the elicitation of positive emotions. We examined (1) whether PPIs increase the intensity and variety of positive emotions; (2) which positive emotions are elicited by two different PPIs; and (3) the impact of positive emotions on well-being. In a randomized, controlled one-week intervention study, we compared the \u2018three good things\u2019 and the \u2018three funny things\u2019 intervention with a placebo control. We assessed the positive and negative emotions reported daily during the intervention, and the well-being and depressive symptoms directly before, after, and one week after the intervention. Results showed higher intensity and variety of positive emotions elicited by the PPIs, and increases in well-being could be explained by the intensity and variety of positive emotions. The study provides a model for how the mechanisms underlying PPIs can be studied and underlines the relevance of positive emotions in PPIs.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;F. Gander&quot;,&quot;R. Proyer&quot;,&quot;Eva Hentz&quot;,&quot;W. Ruch&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2020,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;The Journal of Positive Psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/working-mechanisms-interventions-study-using-assessment-gander/37ccb5970ef554d0b9f791441d8bb5b6/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/17439760.2020.1789698&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;15&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;633 - 638&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:12},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Undoing Effect of Positive Emotions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive emotions are hypothesized to undo the cardiovascular aftereffects of negative emotions. Study 1 tests this undoing effect. Participants (n = 170) experiencing anxiety-induced cardiovascular reactivity viewed a film that elicited (a) contentment, (b) amusement, (c) neutrality, or (d) sadness. Contentment-eliciting and amusing films produced faster cardiovascular recovery than neutral or sad films did. Participants in Study 2 (n = 185) viewed these same films following a neutral state. Results disconfirm the alternative explanation that the undoing effect reflects a simple replacement process. Findings are contextualized by Fredrickson&#x27;s broaden-and-build theory of positive emotions (B. L. Fredrickson, 1998).&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;,&quot;R. Mancuso&quot;,&quot;C. Branigan&quot;,&quot;M. We propose that feeling and expressing positive emotions on the job have favorable consequences on: 1 employees independent of their relationships with others e.g., greater persistence, 2 reactions of others to employees e.g., \\&quot;halo,\\&quot; or overgeneralization to other desirable traits, and 3 reactions of employees to others e.g., helping others. These three sets of intervening processes are proposed, in turn, to lead to work achievement, job enrichment and a higher quality social context. A partial test of this framework is made in an 18-month study of 272 employees. Results indicate that positive emotion on the job at time 1 is associated with evidence of work achievement more favorable supervisor evaluations and higher pay and a supportive social context more support from supervisors and coworkers at time 2. But positive emotion at time 1 is not significantly associated with job enrichment at time 2.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Barry M. Staw&quot;,&quot;R. I. Sutton&quot;,&quot;L. H. The broaden-and-build theory of positive emotions.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;In this article, the author describes a new theoretical perspective on positive emotions and situates this new perspective within the emerging field of positive psychology. The broaden-and-build theory posits that experiences of positive emotions broaden people&#x27;s momentary thought-action repertoires, which in turn serves to build their enduring personal resources, ranging from physical and intellectual resources to social and psychological resources. Preliminary empirical evidence supporting the broaden-and-build theory is reviewed, and open empirical questions that remain to be tested are identified. The theory and findings suggest that the capacity to experience positive emotions may be a fundamental human strength central to the study of human flourishing.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2001,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;The American psychologist&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/role-emotions-psychology-broadenandbuild-theory-fredrickson/f7343b806c1759bbb584074d5e4d45ac/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0003-066X.56.3.218&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;56 3&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          218-26\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:15},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Culture, Emotion, and Well-being: Good Feelings in Japan and the United States&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;We tested the hypothesis that \u201cgood feelings\u201d\u2014the central element of subjective well-being\u2014are associated with interdependence and interpersonal engagement of the self in Japan, but with independence and interpersonal disengagement of the self in the United States. Japanese and American college students (total N = 913) reported how frequently they experienced various emotional states in daily life. In support of the hypothesis, the reported frequency of general positive emotions (e.g. calm, elated) was most closely associated with the reported frequency of interpersonally engaged positive emotions (e.g. friendly feelings) in Japan, but with the reported frequency of interpersonally disengaged positive emotions (e.g. pride) in the United States. Further, for Americans the reported frequency of experience was considerably higher for positive emotions than for negative emotions, but for Japanese it was higher for engaged emotions than for disengaged emotions. Implications for cultural constructions of emotion in general and subjective well-being in particular are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. Kitayama&quot;,&quot;H. Markus&quot;,&quot;Masaru Kurokawa&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2000,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Cognition and Emotion&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/culture-emotion-wellbeing-good-feelings-japan-united-kitayama/ac4ee7b7b0d3523ea7feb32c1ec8967a/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/026999300379003&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;14&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;124 - 93&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:16},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Happiness unpacked: positive emotions increase life satisfaction by building resilience.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Happiness-a composite of life satisfaction, coping resources, and positive emotions-predicts desirable life outcomes in many domains. The broaden-and-build theory suggests that this is because positive emotions help people build lasting resources. To test this hypothesis, the authors measured emotions daily for 1 month in a sample of students (N = 86) and assessed life satisfaction and trait resilience at the beginning and end of the month. Positive emotions predicted increases in both resilience and life satisfaction. Negative emotions had weak or null effects and did not interfere with the benefits of positive emotions. Positive emotions also mediated the relation between baseline and final resilience, but life satisfaction did not. This suggests that it is in-the-moment positive emotions, and not more general positive evaluations of one&#x27;s life, that form the link between happiness and desirable life outcomes. Change in resilience mediated the relation between positive emotions and increased life satisfaction, suggesting that happy people become more satisfied not simply because they feel better but because they develop resources for living well.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Based on a review of East-West cultural differences in dialectical emotions, or co-occurring positive and negative feelings, we predicted culture to influence the association between positive emotions and depression, but not the association between negative emotions and depression. As predicted, in a survey of over 600 European-, immigrant Asian-, and Asian American college students, positive emotions were associated with depression symptoms among European Americans and Asian Americans, but not immigrant Asians. Negative emotions were associated with depression symptoms among all three groups. We also found initial evidence that acculturation (i.e., nativity) may influence the role of positive emotions in depression: Asian Americans fell \\&quot;in between\\&quot; the two other groups. These findings suggest the importance of studying the role of culture in positive emotions and in positive psychology. J. A. Russell and J. M. Carroll&#x27;s (1999) circumplex model holds that happiness and sadness are polar opposites and, thus, mutually exclusive. In contrast, the evaluative space model (J. T. Cacioppo &amp; G. G. Berntson, 1994) proposes that positive and negative affect are separable and that mixed feelings of happiness and sadness can co-occur. The authors both replicated and extended past research by showing that whereas most participants surveyed in typical situations felt either happy or sad, many participants surveyed immediately after watching the film Life Is Beautiful, moving out of their dormitories, or graduating from college felt both happy and sad. Results suggest that although affective experience may typically be bipolar, the underlying processes, and occasionally the resulting experience of emotion, are better characterized as bivariate.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Jeff T. Based on the research available, here\u2019s how we can separate positive states and immediate stimuli, and discuss their mechanisms:\n\n### Positive States:\n\nPositive states like happiness, contentment, and joy are generally broader and more enduring than responses to specific stimuli. They can be influenced by:\n\n1. **Psychological Resources**: Positive emotional states enhance psychological resources like resilience, optimism, and self-efficacy. They may improve physical well-being and promote healthier behaviors [(Salovey et al., 2000)](https://consensus.app/papers/states-health-salovey/c9eb87b520b859cbb5f6e88c49c30ec1/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n2. **Social Connections**: Positive emotions strengthen social connections, which are crucial for emotional and physical well-being. They foster trust, compassion, and broader social networks, enhancing an individual&#x27;s support system [(Fredrickson, 1998)](https://consensus.app/papers/what-good-positive-emotions-fredrickson/a535b0f0d83d5d868fe18409e2ee804d/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n3. **Coping Mechanisms**: Happiness and other positive emotions can lead to better coping mechanisms for stress and adversity, promoting resilience and a more balanced life satisfaction [(Cohn et al., 2009)](https://consensus.app/papers/happiness-unpacked-emotions-increase-life-satisfaction-cohn/fb4111b0a50257cf8f565ea47813882e/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n### Immediate Stimuli:\n\nImmediate stimuli that produce &#x27;feel-good&#x27; feelings can range from sensory experiences to specific events. These reactions can be more fleeting than broad emotional states but are powerful:\n\n1. **Neurobiological Responses**: Immediate pleasant stimuli often trigger direct neurobiological responses. For example, eating delicious food or listening to music can activate the brain&#x27;s reward pathways, releasing dopamine and other feel-good neurotransmitters, which induce pleasure and satisfaction [(Burgdorf &amp; Panksepp, 2006)](https://consensus.app/papers/neurobiology-emotions-burgdorf/eec9b7bfa4855b878ed63d3b78f87a91/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n2. **Sensory Pleasure**: The direct sensory pleasure from stimuli such as tastes, sounds, or visual art is processed in the brain&#x27;s sensory areas and limbic system, leading to immediate positive feelings [(Carver, 2003)](https://consensus.app/papers/pleasure-sign-attend-something-else-placing-feelings-carver/f1387f6706c8518e95e5c2cf4e2415e9/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n3. **Evaluative Responses**: Our cognitive appraisal of a situation or stimulus can quickly lead to positive feelings. This evaluation depends on personal values, current mood, and contextual factors. For example, receiving a compliment or achieving a goal can immediately generate feelings of pride and joy [(Yin, 2019)](https://consensus.app/papers/study-progress-neural-mechanism-positive-emotions-yin/81d62d707adc575a836980f192b06f33/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n### Mechanisms:\n\n1. **Neurological Pathways**: Both long-term positive states and immediate positive reactions involve complex neurological pathways. The limbic system, particularly the ventral striatum and prefrontal cortex, plays a crucial role in processing positive emotions and stimuli [(Jie Yin, 2019)](https://consensus.app/papers/study-progress-neural-mechanism-positive-emotions-yin/81d62d707adc575a836980f192b06f33/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n2. **Broaden-and-Build Theory**: This theory suggests that positive emotions broaden an individual&#x27;s thought-action repertoire, leading to the building of enduring personal resources, which in turn contribute to improved well-being and further positive emotions [(Fredrickson, 2001)](https://consensus.app/papers/role-emotions-psychology-broadenandbuild-theory-fredrickson/f7343b806c1759bbb584074d5e4d45ac/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nIn summary, while positive states are typically broader and more enduring, influenced by psychological resources and social connections, immediate stimuli induce &#x27;feel-good&#x27; feelings through direct neurobiological reactions and sensory pleasures. Both are integral to the human experience of positivity and well-being."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

Pleasure is a key aspect of life, and human beings seek out what gives them pleasure. We are naturally attracted to what makes us feel good. \n\n\nTake my favorite food, cheese, for instance. Scientific studies have revealed that cheese contains a chemical called casein, known for its ability to induce feelings of pleasure. This chemical is so powerful that it triggers the same brain regions as opioids, potentially leading to addictive behaviors. Yet, my intention is not addiction, but rather, to experience the joy that comes from feeling good. Hence, my love for cheese. \n\nBut it&#x27;s not just about the cheese. I often find myself pondering\u2014what truly brings us that feeling of goodness?  What are the essential elements that guarantee a delightful human experience? Is it all about chemical receptors in the brain? Is happiness just a pill or does it encompass something deeper? Is the true science of feeling good science or just a philosophy or attitude that keeps the human mood in optimal condition? Let\u2019s explore what we know about the science of feeling good and its intersections with behavioral philosophy and psychology to get the bottom of the mystery humans have pondered and sought for millennia: How to feel good all the time and lead a happy and meaningful life. \n\nSee, happiness isn\u2019t only the joy of chewing on a cube of sharp creamy cheesy cheddar. It is also the enduring feeling of goodness that comes from the sense that you\u2019re in a good place in your life right now. ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;What Good Are Positive Emotions?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This article opens by noting that positive emotions do not fit existing models of emotions. Consequently, a new model is advanced to describe the form and function of a subset of positive emotions, including joy, interest, contentment, and love. This new model posits that these positive emotions serve to broaden an individual&#x27;s momentary thought\u2013action repertoire, which in turn has the effect of building that individual&#x27;s physical, intellectual, and social resources. Empirical evidence to support this broaden-and-build model of positive emotions is reviewed, and implications for emotion regulation and health promotion are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Core relational themes and expressive displays of eight positive emotions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Understanding positive emotions&#x27; shared and differentiating features can yield valuable insight into the structure of positive emotion space and identify emotion states, or aspects of emotion states, that are most relevant for particular psychological processes and outcomes. We report two studies that examined core relational themes (Study 1) and expressive displays (Study 2) for eight positive emotion constructs\u2014amusement, awe, contentment, gratitude, interest, joy, love, and pride. Across studies, all eight emotions shared one quality: high positive valence. Distinctive core relational theme and expressive display patterns were found for four emotions\u2014amusement, awe, interest, and pride. Gratitude was associated with a distinct core relational theme but not an expressive display. Joy and love were each associated with a distinct expressive display but their core relational themes also characterised pride and gratitude, respectively. Contentment was associated with a distinct expressive display but not a core relational theme. The implications of this work for the study of positive emotion are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Belinda Campos&quot;,&quot;M. Shiota&quot;,&quot;D. Keltner&quot;,&quot;Gian C. Gonzaga&quot;,&quot;Jennifer L Goetz&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2013,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Cognition and Emotion&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/what-shared-core-relational-themes-expressive-displays-campos/2db7ff48187b51b8a72a127f6bb55dd7/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/02699931.2012.683852&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;27&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;37 - 52&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:3},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The broaden-and-build theory of positive emotions.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The broaden-and-build theory describes the form and function of a subset of positive emotions, including joy, interest, contentment and love. A key proposition is that these positive emotions broaden an individual&#x27;s momentary thought-action repertoire: joy sparks the urge to play, interest sparks the urge to explore, contentment sparks the urge to savour and integrate, and love sparks a recurring cycle of each of these urges within safe, close relationships. The broadened mindsets arising from these positive emotions are contrasted to the narrowed mindsets sparked by many negative emotions (i.e. specific action tendencies, such as attack or flee). A second key proposition concerns the consequences of these broadened mindsets: by broadening an individual&#x27;s momentary thought-action repertoire--whether through play, exploration or similar activities--positive emotions promote discovery of novel and creative actions, ideas and social bonds, which in turn build that individual&#x27;s personal resources; ranging from physical and intellectual resources, to social and psychological resources. Importantly, these resources function as reserves that can be drawn on later to improve the odds of successful coping and survival. This chapter reviews the latest empirical evidence supporting the broaden-and-build theory and draws out implications the theory holds for optimizing health and well-being.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2004,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Philosophical transactions of the Royal Society of London. A Case for a Sociology of the Good Life&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Despite the enormous growth in happiness research in recent decades, there remains a lack of consistency in the use of the terms happiness, satisfaction, contentment and well-being. In this article I argue for a sociologically grounded distinction between happiness and contentment that defines the former as positive affect and the latter as positive reflection. Contentment is therefore understood as a fulfilling relationship with the self and society (to borrow from G.H. Mead&#x27;s terminology) and happiness involves pleasurable experiences. There is a history of similar distinctions in philosophy and psychoanalysis, but much of the contemporary discourse fails to distinguish between individual and collective definitions of happiness. This article will argue that happiness and contentment ought not to be treated as competing approaches to the good life, but as complimentary forms of emotional experience. Further, I argue that the current interest in happiness can be linked to larger culture shifts involving neoliberalism and individualism.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. McKenzie&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2016,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal for The Theory of Social Behaviour&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/happiness-contentment-case-sociology-good-life-mckenzie/cf70b1b6acca51ba847d175af34fb615/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1111/JTSB.12098&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;46&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;252-267&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:5},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Happiness unpacked: positive emotions increase life satisfaction by building resilience.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Happiness-a composite of life satisfaction, coping resources, and positive emotions-predicts desirable life outcomes in many domains. The broaden-and-build theory suggests that this is because positive emotions help people build lasting resources. To test this hypothesis, the authors measured emotions daily for 1 month in a sample of students (N = 86) and assessed life satisfaction and trait resilience at the beginning and end of the month. Positive emotions predicted increases in both resilience and life satisfaction. Negative emotions had weak or null effects and did not interfere with the benefits of positive emotions. Positive emotions also mediated the relation between baseline and final resilience, but life satisfaction did not. This suggests that it is in-the-moment positive emotions, and not more general positive evaluations of one&#x27;s life, that form the link between happiness and desirable life outcomes. Change in resilience mediated the relation between positive emotions and increased life satisfaction, suggesting that happy people become more satisfied not simply because they feel better but because they develop resources for living well.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. We report an investigation into the hypothesis that positive basic emotions have distinct vocal expressions (Ekman, 1992b, Cognition and Emotion, 6, 169\u2013200). Non-verbal vocalisations are used that map onto five putative positive emotions: Achievement/Triumph, Amusement, Contentment, Sensual Pleasure, and Relief. Data from categorisation and rating tasks indicate that each vocal expression is accurately categorised and consistently rated as expressing the intended emotion. Keltner&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2003,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/faces-positive-emotion-shiota/5a1a0a4a694b528cbb4d44b03da94e7f/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1196/annals.1280.029&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;1000&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:9},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Are The Very Happy Too Happy?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Although positive emotions undoubtedly confer benefits, one can have too much of it. There is probably a point beyond which enjoyment interferes with realism, yet it is unclear where that point is. The original \u201cStates of Mind\u201d (SOM) model (Schwartz and Garamoni, 1986; 1989) proposed that a ratio of [positive] to [positive plus negative] affective/cognitive states [P/(P+N)] of about 0.62 is optimal, but previous research indicated that higher ratios may go with good mental health. The revised \u201cbalanced states of mind\u201d (BSOM) model (Schwartz, 1997) suggests a higher cutoff, with ratios above 0.90 being dysfunctional. This paper reports a study of 72 very positive subjects (mean ratio = 0.85) and assessed possible dysfunction by means of questionnaires, role-plays, and physiological responses to induced stress. Signs of dysfunction were no more frequent among the most positive subjects (ratios of 0.90 and above) than among moderately positive subjects. This suggests that there is nothing wrong with the high levels of happiness in present day society. As yet, it is still not established how much more happiness will be too much. One possibility is that standard cognition/emotion measures need to be revised in order to detect truly excessive positivity in a sensitive manner.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Elisha Tarlow Friedman&quot;,&quot;R. Haaga&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2002,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Happiness Studies&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/very-friedman/16a59b20cca85a31ab152a20a692d3ba/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1023/A:1021828127970&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;3&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;355-372&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:10},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Benefits of Frequent Positive Affect: Does Happiness Lead to Success?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Numerous studies show that happy individuals are successful across multiple life domains, including marriage, friendship, income, work performance, and health. The authors suggest a conceptual model to account for these findings, arguing that the happiness-success link exists not only because success makes people happy, but also because positive affect engenders success. Three classes of evidence--crosssectional, longitudinal, and experimental--are documented to test their model. Relevant studies are described and their effect sizes combined meta-analytically. The results reveal that happiness is associated with and precedes numerous successful outcomes, as well as behaviors paralleling success. Furthermore, the evidence suggests that positive affect--the hallmark of well-being--may be the cause of many of the desirable characteristics, resources, and successes correlated with happiness. Diener&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2005,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/benefits-frequent-positive-affect-does-happiness-lead-lyubomirsky/f7a25f49b01f5633a4499b4a3700c47a/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0033-2909.131.6.803&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:11},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Sources of Happiness: A Comparison of Male and Female Scholars&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Happiness is a concept which mean many things to many people. Part of the challenge of a science of happiness is to identify different concepts of happiness, and where applicable, split them into their components. Happiness can be defined in terms of a mental state of satisfaction and contentment; positive feelings/emotions; a harmonious homeostasis; achievement and hope; and freedom from ill-being (Lu, Gilmour, &amp; Kao, 2001). However, happiness is not a static state. Even the happiest of people the cheeriest 10%feel blue at times. And even the bluest has their moments of joy. That has presented a challenge to social scientists trying to measure happiness. Happiness is a mental state of well-being characterized by positive or pleasant emotions ranging from contentment to intense joy.Happiness is defined (a) as a predominance of positive over negative affect and (b) as satisfaction with life as a whole (Argyle, Martin, &amp; Crossland, 1989). Philosophers have commonly distinguished two accounts of happiness: hedonism, and the life satisfaction theory. Hedonists identify happiness with the individual&#x27;s balance of pleasant over unpleasant experience whereas Life satisfaction theories identify happiness with having a favourable attitude toward one&#x27;s life as a whole. A third theory, the emotional state view identifies happiness with an agent&#x27;s emotional condition as a whole (Eid &amp; Larson, 2008). In addition, happiness is conceptualized better as a trait than as a transient emotional state (Veenhoven, 1994). Thus, to understand why some people are happier than others, one must understand the cognitive and motivational processes that serve to maintain, and even enhance, enduring happiness and transient mood (Lyubomirsky, 2001). Subjective Wellbeing researchers have progressed from early survey searches for \\&quot;objective\\&quot; external indicators (Andrews &amp; Withey, 1976) and scale development (Diener, Emmons, Larsen, &amp; Griffin, 1985) to explanations of psychological mechanisms of happiness (Lu &amp; Lin, 1998) and even to large-scale cross-cultural comparisons (Diener, Diener, &amp; Diener, 1995).Factors that affect happiness of a person range from internal sources to external sources, right from genetic influences to social situation, personality, momentary events and so on. Chance events like personal tragedies or illness might affect ones happiness but the effect does not remain long (Diener, 2000). Proximal environment like the social class, community, family and economic situation has their effect on well being of a person. At the same time, factors like hope and optimism can be learned to moderate one&#x27;s level of happiness (Seligman, 2002). There are three components of happiness: pleasure (\\&quot;the smiley-face piece\\&quot;), engagement (the depth of involvement with one&#x27;s family, work, romance and hobbies) and meaning (using personal strengths to serve some larger end). Of those three roads to a happy, satisfied life, pleasure is the least consequential and engagement and meaning are much more important\\&quot; (Davis, 2014).People vary in their perception of happiness at different stages of their life and education also plays a role in it. So in order to understand the phenomena from the perspective of research scholars and to compare their level of happiness across gender, the present study was carried out.MethodParticipantsA sample of 60 research scholars equally divided into male (n=30) and female (n=30) groups, were taken from Jamia Millia Islamia. They were enrolled in Ph.D programme in different departments of both science and social science streams. The age of the scholars ranged from 24 to 28 years.InstrumentsThe Subjective Happiness Scale: The scale was developed by Lyubomirsky and Lepper in 1999 and measures the extent to which an individual sees himself or herself as a happy or unhappy person. No wonder then that in this chaotic reality and despite various joyful and satisfying moments, the majority of grown-ups claim that they are unhappy. Amazingly, however, there are always those who believe and declare that they are happy, which raises the question what is happiness and what is it constituted from. Google suggests that \u201cHappiness is that feeling that comes over you when you know life is good and you can\u2019t help but smile. It\u2019s the opposite of sadness. Happiness is a sense of well-being, joy, or contentment. When people are successful, or safe, or lucky, they feel happy\u201d. This description combines a number of positive experiences and feelings, that most likely affect our brain to release chemicals recognized as the \u2018good guys\u2019, in contrast to the \u2018bad guys\u2019, chemicals secreted in situations of sadness, agony, pain, failures, disappointments and frustrations that affect brain circuits associated with unpleasant emotions and thoughts. Although moments of satisfaction, joy and pleasure raise good feelings, these are usually temporary, whereas happiness in its broader essence reflects a positive state of mind based on numerous parameters that collectively raise a long-lasting contentment. It has been suggested that positive affective states are protective, but the pathways through which such effects might be mediated are poorly understood. Here we show that positive affect in middle-aged men and women is associated with reduced neuroendocrine, inflammatory, and cardiovascular activity. Positive affect was assessed by aggregating momentary experience samples of happiness over a working day and was inversely related to cortisol output over the day, independently of age, gender, socioeconomic position, body mass, and smoking. Similar patterns were observed on a leisure day. Happiness was also inversely related to heart rate assessed by using ambulatory monitoring methods over the day. Participants underwent mental stress testing in the laboratory, where plasma fibrinogen stress responses were smaller in happier individuals. Participants experienced happy, neutral, or sad moods and \\&quot;remembered\\&quot; whether names connoting race (African American, European American) belonged to social categories (criminal, politician, basketball player). Positive mood increased reliance on heuristics, indexed by higher false identification of members of stereotyped groups. Positive mood lowered sensitivity (d&#x27;), even among relative experts, and shifted bias (beta) or criterion to be more lenient for stereotypical names. In contrast, sad mood did not disrupt sensitivity and, in fact, revealed the use of a stricter criterion compared with baseline mood. Banaji&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2000,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of personality and social psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/mood-heuristics-influence-states-sensitivity-bias-park/246a98ae1e2d584fa7dae7efc5f25c76/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0022-3514.78.6.1005&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;78 6&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          1005-23\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:15},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The neurobiology of positive emotions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Compared to the study of negative emotions such as fear, the neurobiology of positive emotional processes and the associated positive affect (PA) states has only recently received scientific attention. Biological theories conceptualize PA as being related to (i) signals indicating that bodies are returning to equilibrium among those studying homeostasis, (ii) utility estimation among those favoring neuroeconomic views, and (iii) approach and other instinctual behaviors among those cultivating neuroethological perspectives. Indeed, there are probably several distinct forms of positive affect, but all are closely related to ancient sub-neocortical limbic brain regions we share with other mammals. There is now a convergence of evidence to suggest that various regions of the limbic system, including especially ventral striatal dopamine systems are implemented in an anticipatory (appetitive) positive affective state. Dopamine independent mechanisms utilizing opiate and GABA receptors in the ventral striatum, amygdala and orbital frontal cortex are important in elaborating consummatory PA (i.e. sensory pleasure) states, and various neuropeptides mediate homeostatic satisfactions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. Burgdorf&quot;,&quot;J. Panksepp&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2006,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Neuroscience &amp; Biobehavioral Reviews&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/neurobiology-emotions-burgdorf/eec9b7bfa4855b878ed63d3b78f87a91/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.neubiorev.2005.06.001&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;30&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;173-187&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:16},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Undoing Effect of Positive Emotions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive emotions are hypothesized to undo the cardiovascular aftereffects of negative emotions. Study 1 tests this undoing effect. Participants (n = 170) experiencing anxiety-induced cardiovascular reactivity viewed a film that elicited (a) contentment, (b) amusement, (c) neutrality, or (d) sadness. Contentment-eliciting and amusing films produced faster cardiovascular recovery than neutral or sad films did. Participants in Study 2 (n = 185) viewed these same films following a neutral state. Results disconfirm the alternative explanation that the undoing effect reflects a simple replacement process. Findings are contextualized by Fredrickson&#x27;s broaden-and-build theory of positive emotions (B. L. Fredrickson, 1998).&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;,&quot;R. Mancuso&quot;,&quot;C. Branigan&quot;,&quot;M. Tugade&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2000,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Motivation and Emotion&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/undoing-effect-positive-emotions-fredrickson/08ce9254e79359b2a532072598063b33/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1023/A:1010796329158&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;24&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;237-258&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:17},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Is valuing positive emotion associated with life satisfaction?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The experience of positive emotion is closely linked to subjective well-being. For this reason, campaigns aimed at promoting the value of positive emotion have become widespread. What is rarely considered are the cultural implications of this focus on happiness. Promoting positive emotions as important for \\&quot;the good life\\&quot; not only has implications for how individuals value these emotional states, but for how they believe others around them value these emotions also. Drawing on data from over 9,000 college students across 47 countries we examined whether individuals&#x27; life satisfaction is associated with living in contexts in which positive emotions are socially valued. The findings show that people report more life satisfaction in countries where positive emotions are highly valued and this is linked to an increased frequency of positive emotional experiences in these contexts. They also reveal, however, that increased life satisfaction in countries that place a premium on positive emotion is less evident for people who tend to experience less valued emotional states: people who experience many negative emotions, do not flourish to the same extent in these contexts. The findings demonstrate how the cultural value placed on certain emotion states may shape the relationship between emotional experiences and subjective well-being.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Bastian&quot;,&quot;Peter Kuppens&quot;,&quot;Kim De Roover&quot;,&quot;E. Diener&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2014,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Emotion&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/valuing-emotion-associated-life-satisfaction-bastian/9d0d05c55acd5c39a42fcb4385157006/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/a0036466&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;14 4&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          639-45\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:18},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Assessment of Intraindividual Variability in Positive and Negative Affect Using Latent State-Trait Model Analyses&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Intraindividual variability in positive and negative affect was assessed by the positive affect (Contentment, Joy, Vigor, Love, and Excitement) and negative affect (Depression, Hostility, Anxiety, Agitation, and Social Anxiety) subscales of the state version of the Comprehensive Personality and Affect Scales (COPAS) during a 3-week period. Using the latent state-trait model analysis, which takes both intraindividual variability and interindividual difference into account by controlling measurement error, it was shown that the variability could be measured reliably by the scores of theCOPAS. In particular, a total of 56.9% to 63.5% and 48.2% to 60.6% of the reliable interindividual difference in positive and negative affect, respectively,was attributed to the intraindividual variability.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Tomoyuki Yasuda&quot;,&quot;C. Lawrenz&quot;,&quot;R. V. Whitlock&quot;,&quot;B. Lubin&quot;,&quot;Pui\u2010wa Lei&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2004,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Educational and Psychological Measurement&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/assessment-intraindividual-variability-positive-yasuda/57fe86668be850f1aa5e99d6a1ae66cb/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/0013164403258445&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;64&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;514 - 530&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:19},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;States-of-Mind in Psychopathology and Psychological Well-Being&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This study investigated the states-of-mind model of depression, anxiety, anger, life satisfaction and happiness in four ways. Three hundred and ninety-eight undergraduate students from Singapore participated in this study. First, states-of-mind ratio and positive automatic thoughts were positively correlated with life satisfaction and happiness, and negatively correlated with anxiety, depression, and anger. In contrast, negative automatic thoughts were positively correlated with anxiety, depression, and anger, and negatively correlated with life satisfaction and happiness. Second, the BSOM categories based depression-related automatic thoughts was able to significantly differentiate among levels of depression, happiness, life satisfaction, anxiety, and anger in ANOVA and in terms of variance accounted for as indicated by partial Eta squared. Third, the BSOM ratio was the best predictor for happiness and life satisfaction and second best predictor for depression, anxiety, and anger in terms of variance accounted for as indicated by adjusted R2, in comparison to the negative cognition model and positive cognition model. Fourth, both ANOVA results and multiple regression results showed that there is cognitive content-specificity for the BSOM based on depression-related automatic thoughts. Implications and limitations of these findings were discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. These emotions also build lasting personal resources, contributing to emotional well-being and resilience.\n\n2. **Salovey et al. (2000)**: The research highlights the connection between positive emotional states and physical health. Positive emotions can improve health through various pathways, including direct physiological effects on the immune system, fostering healthier behaviors, and improving social support.\n\n3. **Campos et al. (2013)**: This study explores the distinct core relational themes and expressive displays associated with different positive emotions. It suggests that while all positive emotions share high positive valence, they differ significantly in their core relational themes and facial/body expressions.\n\n4. **Fredrickson (2004)**: The paper expands on the broaden-and-build theory, explaining how positive emotions broaden an individual\u2019s thought-action repertoire and build enduring resources, which in turn enhance coping mechanisms and overall well-being.\n\n5. **McKenzie (2016)**: The article argues for a distinction between happiness (positive affect) and contentment (positive reflection), proposing that happiness is associated with pleasurable experiences, while contentment stems from a fulfilling relationship with oneself and society.\n\n6. **Cohn et al. (2009)**: The authors demonstrate that daily positive emotions increase life satisfaction and resilience, underscoring the idea that in-the-moment positive emotions, rather than general positive evaluations of one\u2019s life, are crucial for happiness and well-being.\n\n7. **Sauter &amp; Scott (2007)**: This research suggests that different positive emotions have distinct vocal expressions and that these unique emotional sounds can be accurately recognized and differentiated by others, highlighting the complexity of positive emotional expression.\n\n8. **Salovey et al. (2000)** (second entry): This is a duplicate of item 2, reinforcing the relationship between positive emotional states and better physical health through multiple mechanisms.\n\n9. **Shiota, Campos, &amp; Keltner (2003)**: The study investigates the specific facial and upper-body displays associated with different positive emotions and finds distinct expressions for emotions such as awe, amusement, and pride, challenging the idea that there is only one facial expression for positive affect (the Duchenne smile).\n\n10. **Friedman, Schwartz, &amp; Haaga (2002)**: This study challenges the notion that there can be too much happiness. It found no evidence of dysfunction among individuals with very high positive emotion ratios, suggesting that high levels of happiness are not necessarily detrimental.\n\nEach of these studies contributes to a broader understanding of positive emotions, their distinctions, and their impacts on physical health, psychological well-being, and social interactions. They collectively underscore the importance of fostering positive emotions for enhancing life satisfaction, resilience, and overall well-being."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true
