Pleasure is a key aspect of life, and human beings seek out what gives them pleasure. We are naturally attracted to what makes us feel good. \n\n\nTake my favorite food, cheese, for instance. Scientific studies have revealed that cheese contains a chemical called casein, known for its ability to induce feelings of pleasure. This chemical is so powerful that it triggers the same brain regions as opioids, potentially leading to addictive behaviors. Yet, my intention is not addiction, but rather, to experience the joy that comes from feeling good. Hence, my love for cheese. \n\nBut it&#x27;s not just about the cheese. I often find myself pondering\u2014what truly brings us that feeling of goodness? What are the essential elements that guarantee a delightful human experience? Is it all about chemical receptors in the brain? Is happiness just a pill or does it encompass something deeper? Is the true science of feeling good science or just a philosophy or attitude that keeps the human mood in optimal condition? Let\u2019s explore what we know about the science of feeling good and its intersections with behavioral philosophy and psychology to get the bottom of the mystery humans have pondered and sought for millennia: How to feel good all the time and lead a happy and meaningful life. \n\nSee, happiness isn\u2019t only the joy of chewing on a cube of sharp creamy cheesy cheddar. It is also the enduring feeling of goodness that comes from the sense that you\u2019re in a good place in your life right now. It\u2019s the feeling of goodness that comes from dwelling in a positive state. \n\nWhat We Know So Far:\nPositive states such as contentment, general happiness, and joy\n--------\n\nCan you use these studies to finish up this blog post above and end with a list of 5 science-supported methods of using immediate happiness-inducing stimuli to build long-lasting positive states such  as contentment, good physical and mental health, purposefulness, direction, etc., and spend particular time discussing the distinctions sited in McKenzie (2016)"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "864ed90e18a0a25c-FCO", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "4ec0b408-acec-4ed6-9ffd-29b7d2d0c71f", "children": ["60efbf63-309a-4c43-972d-469c6d107220"]}, "60efbf63-309a-4c43-972d-469c6d107220": {"id": "60efbf63-309a-4c43-972d-469c6d107220", "message": {"id": "60efbf63-309a-4c43-972d-469c6d107220", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1710530331.67054, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Building on our understanding of the science of feeling good, we know that while the immediate pleasure from experiences like enjoying cheese taps into our brain&#x27;s reward system, true happiness extends far beyond these transient moments of joy. It encompasses enduring states of contentment, health, purposefulness, and direction in life.\n\nFrom the research findings summarized earlier:\n\n1. **Broaden-and-Build Theory (Fredrickson, 1998 &amp; 2004)**: This theory suggests that experiencing positive emotions broadens one&#x27;s awareness and encourages novel, varied, and exploratory thoughts and actions. Over time, this leads to building enduring personal resources, ranging from physical and social resources to intellectual and psychological capacities.\n\n2. **Positive Emotions and Health (Salovey et al., 2000)**: Positive emotional states not only enhance mental health but are also linked to physical well-being. They can lead to healthier lifestyles and may even have direct physiological benefits, such as on the immune system.\n\n3. **Distinctions of Positive Emotions (Campos et al., 2013)**: Different positive emotions serve different functions and lead to distinct types of satisfaction and well-being. For example, joy might lead to playing and creativity, while contentment might encourage reflection and appreciation.\n\n4. **Sociology of Happiness (McKenzie, 2016)**: Happiness (positive affect) and contentment (positive reflection) are distinguished. While happiness can be fleeting and dependent on external factors, contentment is more about a fulfilling relationship with oneself and society. This distinction is crucial as it underscores the different pathways through which we can cultivate a good life: one through seeking pleasurable experiences and the other through fostering a deep sense of satisfaction with life.\n\n5. **Expression and Recognition of Emotions (Sauter &amp; Scott, 2007; Shiota et al., 2003)**: The way we express and recognize different positive emotions can affect our relationships and social interactions, further influencing our overall well-being.\n\nBuilding on these insights, here are five science-supported methods to use immediate happiness-inducing stimuli to build long-lasting positive states:\n\n1. **Cultivate a Variety of Positive Emotions**: Engage in activities that foster a range of positive emotions. For example, engage in playful activities to experience joy, immerse yourself in nature to feel awe, and practice gratitude to feel more content. Diversifying your emotional experiences can broaden your thought-action repertoires and build lasting resources.\n\n2. **Practice Mindfulness and Reflection**: Spend time in self-reflection to understand what brings you genuine contentment, beyond mere fleeting pleasure. Mindfulness practices can help you become more aware of your internal states, leading to a deeper sense of contentment.\n\n3. **Build and Maintain Social Connections**: Foster relationships that provide support, validation, and love. Strong social ties can lead to enduring feelings of love and belonging, key components of long-term well-being.\n\n4. **Set and Pursue Purposeful Goals**: Having clear goals and a sense of direction can lead to feelings of success and accomplishment. Choose goals that are aligned with your values and interests to ensure they contribute to your overall sense of purpose and contentment.\n\n5. **Adopt Healthy Lifestyle Habits**: Regular physical activity, a balanced diet, and adequate sleep can improve your mood and energy levels, leading to more frequent and intense experiences of positive emotions, which over time contribute to lasting well-being.\n\nBy understanding the distinctions between fleeting happiness and deeper contentment, as highlighted by McKenzie (2016), we can strive not just for momentary pleasures but for a fulfilling and meaningful life. It&#x27;s about balancing the joy of immediate pleasures with activities and relationships that provide a profound sense of satisfaction and belonging. This comprehensive approach can guide us towards a life that is not only happy but also rich, purposeful, and rewarding."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true
, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [], "gizmo_id": "g-bo0FiWLY7", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4-gizmo", "pad": "AAAAA", "parent_id": "aaa2acbb-c6c1-44c6-844b-8e4a67349850", "request_id": "864ed90e18a0a25c-FCO", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa2acbb-c6c1-44c6-844b-8e4a67349850", "children": ["aaa2deb4-8e7a-44d3-bbfc-3f801d618a89"]}, "aaa2deb4-8e7a-44d3-bbfc-3f801d618a89": {"id": "aaa2deb4-8e7a-44d3-bbfc-3f801d618a89", "message": {"id": "aaa2deb4-8e7a-44d3-bbfc-3f801d618a89", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1710530455.254617, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["write 3 paragraphs that summarize the current knowledge and trends in the science of feeling good"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "864edd0f79030d80-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "60efbf63-309a-4c43-972d-469c6d107220", "children": ["f3b02f87-d77f-4fcc-bad0-bf48f6ca1c17"]}, "f3b02f87-d77f-4fcc-bad0-bf48f6ca1c17": {"id": "f3b02f87-d77f-4fcc-bad0-bf48f6ca1c17", "message": {"id": "f3b02f87-d77f-4fcc-bad0-bf48f6ca1c17", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1710530483.248044, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["The science of feeling good, an area deeply explored within positive psychology, illuminates the multifaceted nature of happiness and well-being. Central to this field is the distinction between transient pleasures and enduring states of contentment, which has been crucially outlined in recent studies and theories. The broaden-and-build theory by Fredrickson emphasizes that positive emotions extend beyond fleeting moments, serving to expand our cognitive, social, and emotional resources, which in turn foster resilience and long-term well-being. Moreover, findings by Salovey et al. demonstrate the significant impact of positive emotional states on physical health, suggesting a bi-directional relationship between psychological well-being and physiological health. This body of work suggests that while immediate joy from stimuli like food or entertainment is valid, true, lasting happiness encompasses deeper, more sustained states such as contentment, purposefulness, and social connection.\n\nResearch has also delved into the nuances of positive emotions, highlighting the diversity and specificity of feelings such as joy, pride, gratitude, and love. Studies by Campos et al. and others underline that each positive emotion carries unique expressions and functions, contributing differently to our overall well-being. This specificity underscores the importance of cultivating a broad range of positive emotions to enhance various aspects of personal and social life. Furthermore, the work of McKenzie brings a sociological perspective, distinguishing between happiness as an immediate, affective experience and contentment as a reflective, evaluative state. This distinction is critical as it suggests different paths to achieving a fulfilling life: one through the pursuit of enjoyable experiences and the other through the development of a satisfying life narrative and social integration.\n\nIn light of these insights, current trends in the science of feeling good are moving towards a more holistic understanding of well-being, integrating emotional, cognitive, social, and physiological components. This comprehensive approach advocates for a balanced life that values both the pursuit of pleasure and the cultivation of meaningful relationships, purposeful goals, and a healthy lifestyle. As research continues to unfold, it is increasingly clear that long-term happiness and well-being are complex, multi-dimensional constructs that require intentional effort and a broad strategy encompassing various aspects of human experience. The ongoing exploration in this field continues to offer valuable insights into how individuals can navigate the pursuit of happiness in an increasingly complex and changing world."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

These heat pump systems are different from the traditional vented drying systems commonly used in the US. The European style machines are typically more compact and energy-efficient due to this technology.\n\nHeat pump dryers in these combo units work by using a closed-loop heat exchange system to recirculate hot air within the drum, removing moisture from the clothes without venting hot air outside. This makes them more energy-efficient but also results in longer drying times compared to standard, vented dryers. This is a key feature of many European-style washer/dryer combos and a reason for their growing popularity in environments where space is limited and energy efficiency is valued, such as apartments or homes without easy external venting options."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

This is due to several factors:\n\n1. **Combined functionality**: Combos are both washing and drying in the same drum, which can lead to less effective drying compared to dedicated dryers.\n\n2. **Condenser drying**: Earlier models often used condenser drying rather than heat pump technology. In condenser dryers, the moisture is condensed into water and drained away, but this process is less energy-efficient and can be less effective in very humid conditions.\n\n3. **Load size and overloading**: Combos typically have smaller capacities than standalone machines. Overloading the machine can significantly reduce drying effectiveness, leaving clothes feeling damp.\n\n4. **Environmental factors**: The ambient air in colder, more humid climates like Minnesota can affect the drying efficiency of condenser and heat pump dryers alike.\n\nSince 2007, however, there have been significant improvements in washer/dryer combo technologies, including more efficient and effective heat pump (pompa di calore) systems. Nonetheless, for those with space constraints or energy efficiency in mind, modern European-style combos are a much-improved option. "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "code", "language": "unknown", "response_format_name": null, "text": "# Cost calculation for the dryer running at full capacity\n# Dryer wattage: 850 watts\n# Average drying time for a compact dryer can vary, let&#x27;s assume 1.5 hours (90 minutes) for a full load for calculation\n# Average price per kWh in euros: \u20ac0.517\n\ndryer_wattage = 850  # in watts\naverage_drying_time = 1.5  # in hours\naverage_price_per_kWh = 0.517  # in euros\n\n# Convert dryer wattage to kilowatts\ndryer_kw = dryer_wattage / 1000  # in kilowatts\n\n# Calculate energy consumed per drying cycle\nenergy_consumed_per_cycle = dryer_kw * average_drying_time  # in kilowatt-hours (kWh)\n\n# Calculate cost per drying cycle\ncost_per_cycle = energy_consumed_per_cycle * average_price_per_kWh  # in euros\n\ncost_per_cycle"}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": false, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", Guidelines for finding valid Wolfram Language interpretations of Entities, etc. \nL2: \nL3: If you need to write Wolfram Language code involving Entity or EntityClass expressions, NEVER assume that you can retrieve or deduce correct identifiers for entities, properties, etc. from your existing training. \nL4: \nL5: When writing code that requires retrieval of entity-property data from the Wolfram Knowledgebase, ALWAYS use chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.getSemanticInterpretationAPI first, with a simplified natural language input. This function can find Wolfram Language interpretations of\nL6: - Entities (examples: Empire State Building, caffeine, Taylor Swift)\nL7: - Well-defined, named EntityClasses (examples: UN countries, lanthanide elements, skyscrapers)\nL8: - Entity + EntityProperty expressions (examples: population of France, mass of Pluto, Asian population of San Francisco)\nL9: - Entity lookups (examples: 5 tallest buildings in Beijing, cities larger than 10M people, books written by Stephen King)\nL10: - Note that getSemanticInterpretation may be able to interpret quite complex entity-related inputs, involving both filters and requests for properties for example &quot;release dates of highest grossing movies in the 1970s directed by Steven Spielberg&quot;.\nL11: \nL12: To find the correct name of a specific entity, entity class, or property in a specific Wolfram Entity type, you may use the following, providing the type and a natural-language, non-camelcase name or phrase:\nL13:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityAPI\nL14:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityClassAPI\nL15:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findPropertyAPI\nL16: \nL17: \nL18: ## Guidelines for using Entity data with chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.getWolframCloudResults\nL19: - A list of all EntityTypes may be retrieved with &quot;EntityValue[]&quot;.\nL20: - You may also retrieve all properties for a given type with:\nL21: EntityProperties[&quot;{{entity type}}&quot;].\nL22: - Prefer direct use of entities of a given type to their corresponding typeData function (e.g., prefer `Entity[\\&quot;Element\\&quot;,\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;][\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]` to `ElementData[\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;,\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]`).\nL23: - Prefer using &quot;Association&quot; in the third argument of any EntityValue calls. This will return a key-value association with Entities as keys. You generally should not request the &quot;Name&quot; property in such an Association, since it is present in the Keys.\nL24: - Wolfram Language visualization and other functions are designed to understand this data structure and automatically retrieve name, date, geographic, etc. information as needed from the associated entities. \nL25: - The Wolfram Cloud will automatically and efficiently batch requests for data; when possible, use lists of entities and/or properties in EntityValue calls instead of mapping over lists. For example, this:\nL26:    EntityValue[{Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;France&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Germany&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Spain&quot;]}, &quot;Population&quot;, &quot;Association&quot;]\nL27: is better than this:\nL28:    EntityValue[#, &quot;Population&quot;] &amp; /@ {Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;France&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Germany&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Spain&quot;]}\nL29: # \u30101\u2020getWolframAlphaResults query guidelines.txt\u2020file-Bvv5cOuKLkrkrKmc7BMrtF9X\u3011\nL30: getWolframAlphaResults guidelines:\nL31: - Translate non-English queries before sending, then respond in the language the user&#x27;s query was written in.\nL32: - Convert inputs to simplified keyword queries whenever possible (e.g. convert &quot;how many people live in France&quot; to &quot;France population&quot;).\nL33: - ALWAYS use this exponent notation: `6*10^14`, NEVER `6e14`.\nL34: - Use ONLY single-letter variable names, with or without integer subscript (e.g., n, n1, n_1).\nL35: - Use named physical constants (e.g., &#x27;speed of light&#x27;) without numerical substitution.\nL36: - Include a space between compound units (e.g., &quot;\\[CapitalOmega] m&quot; for &quot;ohm*meter&quot;).\nL37: - To solve for a variable in an equation with units, consider solving a corresponding equation without units; exclude counting units (e.g., books), include genuine units (e.g., kg).\nL38: - If data for multiple properties is needed, make separate calls for each property.\nL39: - If Wolfram provides multiple &#x27;Assumptions&#x27; for a query, choose the more relevant one(s) without explaining the initial result. If you are unsure, ask the user to choose. Then Re-send the exact same &#x27;input&#x27; with NO modifications, and add the &#x27;assumption&#x27; parameter, formatted as a list, with the relevant values.\nL40: - If you receive a 501 error and Wolfram Alpha provides &quot;Things to try instead&quot;, review those suggestions and try one or more of them, *exactly* as provided by the API, if they might provide a good answer.\nL41: - ONLY simplify or rephrase the initial query if a more relevant &#x27;Assumption&#x27; or other input suggestions are not provided.\nL42: # \u30102\u2020getWolframCloudResults query guidelines.txt\u2020file-jAt577A8QpOTIErsx25lbYTr\u3011\nL43: getWolframCloudResults guidelines:\nL44: - Always explain your chain of thought before writing any code. When composing your explanation, follow all the guidelines here regarding variable names, etc. even in your written response.\nL45: - Always think about what Wolfram Language functions may be most relevant and efficient for solving a given problem.\nL46: - The Import[] function is supported by this function, allowing you to import data from the web.\nL47: - Before writing any code requiring access to Entity, EntityProperty, EntityClass, etc. data, read the file &quot;Wolfram Entity Data&quot;\nL48: - Before writing any code involving Food and nutrition data, read the file &quot;Wolfram Food Data&quot;\nL49: - getWolframCloudResults will render and return URLs you can use to display in your responses; you do not need to Export visualizations as images or do any other kind of processing.\nL50: - If getWolframCloudResults return data-related fields in addition to the default &quot;output&quot; such as outputLength, firstOutputValue, etc., your response should focus on those additional fields and encourage the user to define further steps for analysis. In these cases, if &quot;output&quot; is an image URL it is likely to be an image of a truncated list or dataset, and not helpful to the user.\nL51: - Do not specify ColorFunction[], PlotTheme[] or related options in visualization code unless requested by the user. The Wolfram Language has sensible default values.\nL52: - Variable names must ONLY be lowercase letters or camelCase names. NEVER use uppercase single letters, snake_case names, or names containing any non-alphanumeric character, especially underscores. Examples: {{invalid name -&gt; valid name}, {C -&gt; c}, {county_population -&gt; countyPopulation}, {LCM_T1 -&gt; lcmT1}}.\nL53: - Use ONLY double quotes around all strings, including plot labels, etc. (e.g., `PlotLegends -&gt; {\\&quot;sin(x)\\&quot;, \\&quot;cos(x)\\&quot;, \\&quot;tan(x)\\&quot;}`).\nL54: - Avoid use of QuantityMagnitude.\nL55: - Apply Evaluate to complex expressions like integrals before plotting (e.g., `Plot[Evaluate[Integrate[...]]]`).\nL56: - Remove all comments and formatting from code passed to the \\&quot;input\\&quot; parameter; for example: instead of `square[x_] := Module[{result},\\\\n  result = x^2 (* Calculate the square *)\\\\n]`, send `square[x_]:=Module[{result},result=x^2]`.\nL57: # \u30103\u2020Wolfram Food Data.txt\u2020file-kI98s2K5Nx9fhlHbuT7gYZEn\u3011\nL58: - In general, to find nutrition for a food or a list of foods, use the Wolfram Resource Function &quot;NutritionReport&quot; with the output format &quot;ASCIITable&quot;. Always try this Wolfram Language approach before attempting a comparable query using Wolfram Alpha. Example:\nL59:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;100g rice\\n8oz chicken\\n1 glass wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;]\nL60: \nL61: - If specific properties are asked for, find the EntityProperty associated with the requested data using Interpreter and include it using the &quot;NutritionProperties&quot; option. Examples:\nL62:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;100g rice\\n8oz chicken\\n1 glass wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;,&quot;NutritionProperties&quot;-&gt;{EntityProperty[&quot;Food&quot;, &quot;AbsoluteTotalCaloriesContent&quot;], EntityProperty[&quot;Food&quot;, &quot;AbsoluteTotalProteinContent&quot;]}]\nL63:      -- For user queries about nutrition in a &#x27;piece&#x27;, &#x27;slice&#x27;, &#x27;scoop&#x27;, &#x27;stick&#x27;, &#x27;clove&#x27;, &#x27;plate&#x27;, &#x27;can&#x27; of a food or &#x27;bottle&#x27;, &#x27;glass&#x27; of a drink, FIRST go get the typical weight in grams for EACH of the foods or typical weight in mL for EACH of the drinks from your general knowledge. Do the same for sizes &#x27;small&#x27;,&#x27;medium&#x27;,&#x27;large&#x27;. Use them in your NutritionReport resource function input. Example:\nL64:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;2*26g bread\\n1*68g ice cream\\n3*28g ham\\n1*14g bacon\\n2*148g pizza\\n1*750mL wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;]\nL65:      -- If the information for a drink is not available in mL, convert it to grams. Example: convert 50mL champagne to 50g champagne.\nL66:      -- Disregard the preparation adjectives in ingredient names, such as &#x27;chopped&#x27;, &#x27;diced&#x27;, &#x27;sliced&#x27;, &#x27;scrambled&#x27;.\nL67:      -- When performing these actions, you do not need to explain every step of the process before sending calculations to Wolfram.\nVisible: 0% - 100%", "summary": null, "assets": [], "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og", "regex": "\u3010(\\d+)(?::(\\d+))?\u2020([^\u2020\u3010\u3011]*)[^\u3010\u3011]*?\u3011"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "file", "name": "Wolfram Entity Data.txt", "id": "file-JSCY7TYYTEkJTsQOcqvvKiVC", "source": "my_files", "text": "\nL1: ## Guidelines for finding valid Wolfram Language interpretations of Entities, etc. \nL2: \nL3: If you need to write Wolfram Language code involving Entity or EntityClass expressions, NEVER assume that you can retrieve or deduce correct identifiers for entities, properties, etc. from your existing training. \nL4: \nL5: When writing code that requires retrieval of entity-property data from the Wolfram Knowledgebase, ALWAYS use chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.getSemanticInterpretationAPI first, with a simplified natural language input. This function can find Wolfram Language interpretations of\nL6: - Entities (examples: Empire State Building, caffeine, Taylor Swift)\nL7: - Well-defined, named EntityClasses (examples: UN countries, lanthanide elements, skyscrapers)\nL8: - Entity + EntityProperty expressions (examples: population of France, mass of Pluto, Asian population of San Francisco)\nL9: - Entity lookups (examples: 5 tallest buildings in Beijing, cities larger than 10M people, books written by Stephen King)\nL10: - Note that getSemanticInterpretation may be able to interpret quite complex entity-related inputs, involving both filters and requests for properties for example &quot;release dates of highest grossing movies in the 1970s directed by Steven Spielberg&quot;.\nL11: \nL12: To find the correct name of a specific entity, entity class, or property in a specific Wolfram Entity type, you may use the following, providing the type and a natural-language, non-camelcase name or phrase:\nL13:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityAPI\nL14:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityClassAPI\nL15:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findPropertyAPI\nL16: \nL17: \nL18: ## Guidelines for using Entity data with chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.getWolframCloudResults\nL19: - A list of all EntityTypes may be retrieved with &quot;EntityValue[]&quot;.\nL20: - You may also retrieve all properties for a given type with:\nL21: EntityProperties[&quot;{{entity type}}&quot;].\nL22: - Prefer direct use of entities of a given type to their corresponding typeData function (e.g., prefer `Entity[\\&quot;Element\\&quot;,\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;][\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]` to `ElementData[\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;,\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]`).\nL23: - Prefer using &quot;Association&quot; in the third argument of any EntityValue calls. Examples:\nL62:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;100g rice\\n8oz chicken\\n1 glass wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;,&quot;NutritionProperties&quot;-&gt;{EntityProperty[&quot;Food&quot;, &quot;AbsoluteTotalCaloriesContent&quot;], EntityProperty[&quot;Food&quot;, &quot;AbsoluteTotalProteinContent&quot;]}]\nL63:      -- For user queries about nutrition in a &#x27;piece&#x27;, &#x27;slice&#x27;, &#x27;scoop&#x27;, &#x27;stick&#x27;, &#x27;clove&#x27;, &#x27;plate&#x27;, &#x27;can&#x27; of a food or &#x27;bottle&#x27;, &#x27;glass&#x27; of a drink, FIRST go get the typical weight in grams for EACH of the foods or typical weight in mL for EACH of the drinks from your general knowledge. Do the same for sizes &#x27;small&#x27;,&#x27;medium&#x27;,&#x27;large&#x27;. Use them in your NutritionReport resource function input. Example:\nL64:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;2*26g bread\\n1*68g ice cream\\n3*28g ham\\n1*14g bacon\\n2*148g pizza\\n1*750mL wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;]\nL65:      -- If the information for a drink is not available in mL, convert it to grams. Example: convert 50mL champagne to 50g champagne.\nL66:      -- Disregard the preparation adjectives in ingredient names, such as &#x27;chopped&#x27;, &#x27;diced&#x27;, &#x27;sliced&#x27;, &#x27;scrambled&#x27;.\nL67:      -- When performing these actions, you do not need to explain every step of the process before sending calculations to Wolfram.\nVisible: 0% - 100%", "extra": null}], Data.txt\u2020file-JSCY7TYYTEkJTsQOcqvvKiVC\u3011\nL1: ## Guidelines for finding valid Wolfram Language interpretations of Entities, etc. \nL2: \nL3: If you need to write Wolfram Language code involving Entity or EntityClass expressions, NEVER assume that you can retrieve or deduce correct identifiers for entities, properties, etc. from your existing training. \nL4: \nL5: When writing code that requires retrieval of entity-property data from the Wolfram Knowledgebase, ALWAYS use chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.getSemanticInterpretationAPI first, with a simplified natural language input. This function can find Wolfram Language interpretations of\nL6: - Entities (examples: Empire State Building, caffeine, Taylor Swift)\nL7: - Well-defined, named EntityClasses (examples: UN countries, lanthanide elements, skyscrapers)\nL8: - Entity + EntityProperty expressions (examples: population of France, mass of Pluto, Asian population of San Francisco)\nL9: - Entity lookups (examples: 5 tallest buildings in Beijing, cities larger than 10M people, books written by Stephen King)\nL10: - Note that getSemanticInterpretation may be able to interpret quite complex entity-related inputs, involving both filters and requests for properties for example &quot;release dates of highest grossing movies in the 1970s directed by Steven Spielberg&quot;.\nL11: \nL12: To find the correct name of a specific entity, entity class, or property in a specific Wolfram Entity type, you may use the following, providing the type and a natural-language, non-camelcase name or phrase:\nL13:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityAPI\nL14:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityClassAPI\nL15:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findPropertyAPI\nL16: \nL17: \nL18: ## Guidelines for using Entity data with chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.getWolframCloudResults\nL19: - A list of all EntityTypes may be retrieved with &quot;EntityValue[]&quot;.\nL20: - You may also retrieve all properties for a given type with:\nL21: EntityProperties[&quot;{{entity type}}&quot;].\nL22: - Prefer direct use of entities of a given type to their corresponding typeData function (e.g., prefer `Entity[\\&quot;Element\\&quot;,\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;][\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]` to `ElementData[\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;,\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]`).\nL23: - Prefer using &quot;Association&quot; in the third argument of any EntityValue calls. This will return a key-value association with Entities as keys. You generally should not request the &quot;Name&quot; property in such an Association, since it is present in the Keys.\nL24: - Wolfram Language visualization and other functions are designed to understand this data structure and automatically retrieve name, date, geographic, etc. information as needed from the associated entities. \nL25: - The Wolfram Cloud will automatically and efficiently batch requests for data; when possible, use lists of entities and/or properties in EntityValue calls instead of mapping over lists. For example, this:\nL26:    EntityValue[{Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;France&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Germany&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Spain&quot;]}, &quot;Population&quot;, &quot;Association&quot;]\nL27: is better than this:\nL28:    EntityValue[#, &quot;Population&quot;] &amp; /@ {Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;France&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Germany&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Spain&quot;]}\nL29: # \u30101\u2020getWolframCloudResults query guidelines.txt\u2020file-jAt577A8QpOTIErsx25lbYTr\u3011\nL30: getWolframCloudResults guidelines:\nL31: - Always explain your chain of thought before writing any code. When composing your explanation, follow all the guidelines here regarding variable names, etc. even in your written response.\nL32: - Always think about what Wolfram Language functions may be most relevant and efficient for solving a given problem.\nL33: - The Import[] function is supported by this function, allowing you to import data from the web.\nL34: - Before writing any code requiring access to Entity, EntityProperty, EntityClass, etc. data, read the file &quot;Wolfram Entity Data&quot;\nL35: - Before writing any code involving Food and nutrition data, read the file &quot;Wolfram Food Data&quot;\nL36: - getWolframCloudResults will render and return URLs you can use to display in your responses; you do not need to Export visualizations as images or do any other kind of processing.\nL37: - If getWolframCloudResults return data-related fields in addition to the default &quot;output&quot; such as outputLength, firstOutputValue, etc., your response should focus on those additional fields and encourage the user to define further steps for analysis. In these cases, if &quot;output&quot; is an image URL it is likely to be an image of a truncated list or dataset, and not helpful to the user.\nL38: - Do not specify ColorFunction[], PlotTheme[] or related options in visualization code unless requested by the user. The Wolfram Language has sensible default values.\nL39: - Variable names must ONLY be lowercase letters or camelCase names. NEVER use uppercase single letters, snake_case names, or names containing any non-alphanumeric character, especially underscores. Examples: {{invalid name -&gt; valid name}, {C -&gt; c}, {county_population -&gt; countyPopulation}, {LCM_T1 -&gt; lcmT1}}.\nL40: - Use ONLY double quotes around all strings, including plot labels, etc. (e.g., `PlotLegends -&gt; {\\&quot;sin(x)\\&quot;, \\&quot;cos(x)\\&quot;, \\&quot;tan(x)\\&quot;}`).\nL41: - Avoid use of QuantityMagnitude.\nL42: - Apply Evaluate to complex expressions like integrals before plotting (e.g., `Plot[Evaluate[Integrate[...]]]`).\nL43: - Remove all comments and formatting from code passed to the \\&quot;input\\&quot; parameter; for example: instead of `square[x_] := Module[{result},\\\\n  result = x^2 (* Calculate the square *)\\\\n]`, send `square[x_]:=Module[{result},result=x^2]`.\nL44: # \u30102\u2020getWolframAlphaResults query guidelines.txt\u2020file-Bvv5cOuKLkrkrKmc7BMrtF9X\u3011\nL45: getWolframAlphaResults guidelines:\nL46: - Translate non-English queries before sending, then respond in the language the user&#x27;s query was written in.\nL47: - Convert inputs to simplified keyword queries whenever possible (e.g. convert &quot;how many people live in France&quot; to &quot;France population&quot;).\nL48: - ALWAYS use this exponent notation: `6*10^14`, NEVER `6e14`.\nL49: - Use ONLY single-letter variable names, with or without integer subscript (e.g., n, n1, n_1).\nL50: - Use named physical constants (e.g., &#x27;speed of light&#x27;) without numerical substitution.\nL51: - Include a space between compound units (e.g., &quot;\\[CapitalOmega] m&quot; for &quot;ohm*meter&quot;).\nL52: - To solve for a variable in an equation with units, consider solving a corresponding equation without units; exclude counting units (e.g., books), include genuine units (e.g., kg).\nL53: - If data for multiple properties is needed, make separate calls for each property.\nL54: - If Wolfram provides multiple &#x27;Assumptions&#x27; for a query, choose the more relevant one(s) without explaining the initial result. If you are unsure, ask the user to choose. Then Re-send the exact same &#x27;input&#x27; with NO modifications, and add the &#x27;assumption&#x27; parameter, formatted as a list, with the relevant values.\nL55: - If you receive a 501 error and Wolfram Alpha provides &quot;Things to try instead&quot;, review those suggestions and try one or more of them, *exactly* as provided by the API, if they might provide a good answer.\nL56: - ONLY simplify or rephrase the initial query if a more relevant &#x27;Assumption&#x27; or other input suggestions are not provided.\nL57: # \u30103\u2020Wolfram Food Data.txt\u2020file-kI98s2K5Nx9fhlHbuT7gYZEn\u3011\nL58: - In general, to find nutrition for a food or a list of foods, use the Wolfram Resource Function &quot;NutritionReport&quot; with the output format &quot;ASCIITable&quot;. Always try this Wolfram Language approach before attempting a comparable query using Wolfram Alpha. Example:\nL59:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;100g rice\\n8oz chicken\\n1 glass wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;]\nL60: \nL61: - If specific properties are asked for, find the EntityProperty associated with the requested data using Interpreter and include it using the &quot;NutritionProperties&quot; option. Examples:\nL62:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;100g rice\\n8oz chicken\\n1 glass wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;,&quot;NutritionProperties&quot;-&gt;{EntityProperty[&quot;Food&quot;, &quot;AbsoluteTotalCaloriesContent&quot;], EntityProperty[&quot;Food&quot;, &quot;AbsoluteTotalProteinContent&quot;]}]\nL63:      -- For user queries about nutrition in a &#x27;piece&#x27;, &#x27;slice&#x27;, &#x27;scoop&#x27;, &#x27;stick&#x27;, &#x27;clove&#x27;, &#x27;plate&#x27;, &#x27;can&#x27; of a food or &#x27;bottle&#x27;, &#x27;glass&#x27; of a drink, FIRST go get the typical weight in grams for EACH of the foods or typical weight in mL for EACH of the drinks from your general knowledge. Do the same for sizes &#x27;small&#x27;,&#x27;medium&#x27;,&#x27;large&#x27;. Use them in your NutritionReport resource function input. This function can find Wolfram Language interpretations of\nL6: - Entities (examples: Empire State Building, caffeine, Taylor Swift)\nL7: - Well-defined, named EntityClasses (examples: UN countries, lanthanide elements, skyscrapers)\nL8: - Entity + EntityProperty expressions (examples: population of France, mass of Pluto, Asian population of San Francisco)\nL9: - Entity lookups (examples: 5 tallest buildings in Beijing, cities larger than 10M people, books written by Stephen King)\nL10: - Note that getSemanticInterpretation may be able to interpret quite complex entity-related inputs, involving both filters and requests for properties for example &quot;release dates of highest grossing movies in the 1970s directed by Steven Spielberg&quot;.\nL11: \nL12: To find the correct name of a specific entity, entity class, or property in a specific Wolfram Entity type, you may use the following, providing the type and a natural-language, non-camelcase name or phrase:\nL13:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityAPI\nL14:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityClassAPI\nL15:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findPropertyAPI\nL16: \nL17: \nL18: ## Guidelines for using Entity data with chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.getWolframCloudResults\nL19: - A list of all EntityTypes may be retrieved with &quot;EntityValue[]&quot;.\nL20: - You may also retrieve all properties for a given type with:\nL21: EntityProperties[&quot;{{entity type}}&quot;].\nL22: - Prefer direct use of entities of a given type to their corresponding typeData function (e.g., prefer `Entity[\\&quot;Element\\&quot;,\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;][\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]` to `ElementData[\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;,\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]`).\nL23: - Prefer using &quot;Association&quot; in the third argument of any EntityValue calls. This will return a key-value association with Entities as keys. You generally should not request the &quot;Name&quot; property in such an Association, since it is present in the Keys.\nL24: - Wolfram Language visualization and other functions are designed to understand this data structure and automatically retrieve name, date, geographic, etc. information as needed from the associated entities. \nL25: - The Wolfram Cloud will automatically and efficiently batch requests for data; when possible, use lists of entities and/or properties in EntityValue calls instead of mapping over lists. For example, this:\nL26:    EntityValue[{Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;France&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Germany&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Spain&quot;]}, &quot;Population&quot;, &quot;Association&quot;]\nL27: is better than this:\nL28:    EntityValue[#, &quot;Population&quot;] &amp; /@ {Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;France&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Germany&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Spain&quot;]}\nL29: # \u30101\u2020getWolframCloudResults query guidelines.txt\u2020file-jAt577A8QpOTIErsx25lbYTr\u3011\nL30: getWolframCloudResults guidelines:\nL31: - Always explain your chain of thought before writing any code. When composing your explanation, follow all the guidelines here regarding variable names, etc. even in your written response.\nL32: - Always think about what Wolfram Language functions may be most relevant and efficient for solving a given problem.\nL33: - The Import[] function is supported by this function, allowing you to import data from the web.\nL34: - Before writing any code requiring access to Entity, EntityProperty, EntityClass, etc. data, read the file &quot;Wolfram Entity Data&quot;\nL35: - Before writing any code involving Food and nutrition data, read the file &quot;Wolfram Food Data&quot;\nL36: - getWolframCloudResults will render and return URLs you can use to display in your responses; you do not need to Export visualizations as images or do any other kind of processing.\nL37: - If getWolframCloudResults return data-related fields in addition to the default &quot;output&quot; such as outputLength, firstOutputValue, etc., your response should focus on those additional fields and encourage the user to define further steps for analysis. In these cases, if &quot;output&quot; is an image URL it is likely to be an image of a truncated list or dataset, and not helpful to the user.\nL38: - Do not specify ColorFunction[], PlotTheme[] or related options in visualization code unless requested by the user. The Wolfram Language has sensible default values.\nL39: - Variable names must ONLY be lowercase letters or camelCase names. NEVER use uppercase single letters, snake_case names, or names containing any non-alphanumeric character, especially underscores. Examples: {{invalid name -&gt; valid name}, {C -&gt; c}, {county_population -&gt; countyPopulation}, {LCM_T1 -&gt; lcmT1}}.\nL40: - Use ONLY double quotes around all strings, including plot labels, etc. (e.g., `PlotLegends -&gt; {\\&quot;sin(x)\\&quot;, \\&quot;cos(x)\\&quot;, \\&quot;tan(x)\\&quot;}`).\nL41: - Avoid use of QuantityMagnitude.\nL42: - Apply Evaluate to complex expressions like integrals before plotting (e.g., `Plot[Evaluate[Integrate[...]]]`).\nL43: - Remove all comments and formatting from code passed to the \\&quot;input\\&quot; parameter; for example: instead of `square[x_] := Module[{result},\\\\n  result = x^2 (* Calculate the square *)\\\\n]`, send `square[x_]:=Module[{result},result=x^2]`.\nL44: # \u30102\u2020getWolframAlphaResults query guidelines.txt\u2020file-Bvv5cOuKLkrkrKmc7BMrtF9X\u3011\nL45: getWolframAlphaResults guidelines:\nL46: - Translate non-English queries before sending, then respond in the language the user&#x27;s query was written in.\nL47: - Convert inputs to simplified keyword queries whenever possible (e.g. convert &quot;how many people live in France&quot; to &quot;France population&quot;).\nL48: - ALWAYS use this exponent notation: `6*10^14`, NEVER `6e14`.\nL49: - Use ONLY single-letter variable names, with or without integer subscript (e.g., n, n1, n_1).\nL50: - Use named physical constants (e.g., &#x27;speed of light&#x27;) without numerical substitution.\nL51: - Include a space between compound units (e.g., &quot;\\[CapitalOmega] m&quot; for &quot;ohm*meter&quot;).\nL52: - To solve for a variable in an equation with units, consider solving a corresponding equation without units; exclude counting units (e.g., books), include genuine units (e.g., kg).\nL53: - If data for multiple properties is needed, make separate calls for each property.\nL54: - If Wolfram provides multiple &#x27;Assumptions&#x27; for a query, choose the more relevant one(s) without explaining the initial result. If you are unsure, ask the user to choose. Then Re-send the exact same &#x27;input&#x27; with NO modifications, and add the &#x27;assumption&#x27; parameter, formatted as a list, with the relevant values.\nL55: - If you receive a 501 error and Wolfram Alpha provides &quot;Things to try instead&quot;, review those suggestions and try one or more of them, *exactly* as provided by the API, if they might provide a good answer.\nL56: - ONLY simplify or rephrase the initial query if a more relevant &#x27;Assumption&#x27; or other input suggestions are not provided.\nL57: # \u30103\u2020Wolfram Food Data.txt\u2020file-kI98s2K5Nx9fhlHbuT7gYZEn\u3011\nL58: - In general, to find nutrition for a food or a list of foods, use the Wolfram Resource Function &quot;NutritionReport&quot; with the output format &quot;ASCIITable&quot;. Always try this Wolfram Language approach before attempting a comparable query using Wolfram Alpha. Example:\nL59:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;100g rice\\n8oz chicken\\n1 glass wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;]\nL60: \nL61: - If specific properties are asked for, find the EntityProperty associated with the requested data using Interpreter and include it using the &quot;NutritionProperties&quot; option. Do the same for sizes &#x27;small&#x27;,&#x27;medium&#x27;,&#x27;large&#x27;. Use them in your NutritionReport resource function input. There are several software options available for transcribing audio files from interviews or oral histories:\n\n1. **Otter.ai**: This is a user-friendly tool that offers automatic transcription services. It&#x27;s highly regarded for its accuracy and ease of use. Otter.ai provides a certain amount of free transcription time each month, with the option to subscribe for more features and longer transcription time.\n\n2. **Descript**: Descript offers transcription services along with advanced audio editing capabilities. It&#x27;s particularly useful if you want to edit the audio by editing the text transcript. They offer a free trial, and then you can choose a subscription plan if you like the service.\n\n3. **Sonix**: This is another automatic transcription service known for its accuracy and ease of use. Sonix offers a pay-per-use model, which might be beneficial if you only need transcription services occasionally.\n\n4. **Rev**: Rev offers both automated and human transcription services. The automated service is cheaper and faster, while the human transcription service provides higher accuracy. You can choose based on your needs and budget.\n\n5. **Temi**: Like Rev, Temi offers automated transcription services at competitive rates. It\u2019s fast and fairly accurate for clear, well-recorded audio.\n\n6. **Trint**: Trint is another automatic transcription service that provides quick and easy transcriptions. "e048b550-cede-4ef8-9320-2e211f772b52"}}, "gizmo_id": "g-bo0FiWLY7", "request_id": "86078d1e8f26a265-FCO", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "6665c74a-e3b0-4b17-9235-1662d91ab12c", "children": ["60662c1e-3a9c-48ca-88ee-da3de2b14f80"]}, "60662c1e-3a9c-48ca-88ee-da3de2b14f80": {"id": "60662c1e-3a9c-48ca-88ee-da3de2b14f80", "message": {"id": "60662c1e-3a9c-48ca-88ee-da3de2b14f80", "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "chat_consensus_app__jit_plugin.search_papers", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1709782727.806192, "update_time": 1709782693.1934514, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Psychological impact of fear-based messages in context of COVID 19&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Dear Editor, COVID-19 has emerged as public health crises all around the globe. This unprecedented time call for optimum use of effective health messaging from various sources. Both official communication and media intended to provide information and guidance to the public but the impact of social media and print media is deeper. Messages on social media largely utilise fear-based messages (FBM) to ensure public compliance. Therefore, it is imperative to understand how FBM influences the psyche. Researchers have suggested the cautious use of FBM as it may be ineffective owing to its low efficacy and optimism bias of people around. During the outbreak of Ebola, fear-related behaviours like limited health services utilisation, migration, stigma, and discrimination, blaming and attacking health workers played an important role in the progression of the outbreak. These fear-related behaviours contributed significantly to morbidity and mortality (Shultz et al., 2016). Exposure to Ebola was potentially traumatic considering a high mortality rate, in comparison, fear-related behaviours in context of covid-19 which cannot be explained by illness. Newspapers frequently sensationalise new clusters as \u2018corona blast\u2019. Animations depicting \u2018corona virus\u2019 as a monster are frequently seen. The frequent appearance of images of dead bodies and graveyards can fuel biased interpretation. Exposure to such fear based messages in the absence of other reliable information can lead to a biased conclusion that corona kills everyone. Psychological response is significantly influenced by type and amount of media exposure. Social media messages amplify their effect through \u2018echo chamber\u2019 or \u2018illusion of truth effect\u2019 (Van den Broucke, 2020). Moreover, continuous exposure to COVID related information and denial messages can also lead to bias in estimating threat accurately. Corona Denial messages from authorities or government agencies can also contribute to mistrust and thus result into noncompliance with behavioural measures (Bavel et al., 2020). FBM can be a significant contributor towards cases of suicide reported across the world (Thakur &amp; Jain, 2020). Many individuals suspected for COVID or asymptomatic patients are expressing severe health anxiety or contemplating suicide due to fear of stigma and discrimination. People are also avoiding hospital visits for non-COVID morbidities timely. Fear has become an important governing factor even for health care. Other fear-related behaviours like panic migration, hoarding essentials due to \u2018Zero-sum thinking\u2019 are frequently observed (Bavel et al., 2020; Ventriglio et al., 2020). Fear can elicit the phenomenon of knowledge resistance and misinterpretations (Van den Broucke, 2020). It may also lead to minimising or denial that is, people don\u2019t believe in the plausibility of a message and adopt desired behaviour changes. FBM can also induce guilt and shame contributing to stigma and suicidality. Threat appeals are shown to be effective only when they are coupled with self-efficacy enhancing message. Response to fear can be understood by \u2018Extended Parallel Process Model\u2019 in which perception of threat and self-efficacy is important components. High perception of threat and low perceived self-efficacy can initiate maladaptive behaviours (Carey &amp; Sarma, 2016). Precautionary information with reassurance has a greater impact on behaviour change by enhancing the selfefficacy (Ruiter et al., 2001). Enabling people to make an informed decision can enhance the feelings of social responsibility towards a collective behavioural change (Stolow et al., 2020). Guideline for media reporting should be formulated in conjunction with recommendations for health promotion during a pandemic (Van den Broucke, 2020; Ventriglio et al., 2020). The negative impact of a disproportionate threat should be highlighted by media. Researchers should examine impact of such FBM and corona denial messages during pandemic and post pandemic.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Swami&quot;,&quot;Tanu Gupta&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2020,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;International Journal of Social Psychiatry&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/impact-fearbased-messages-context-covid-swami/9f125d8f625158d4a3a6378a1f5a12fd/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/0020764020980773&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;67&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1081 - 1082&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:1},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Crime, News and Fear of Crime: Toward an Identification of Audience Effects&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Communication studies increasingly recognize the audience&#x27;s critical role in receiving and interpreting media messages. Research into audience attributes that distinguish \u201cmedia effects,\u201d on the fear of crime (FEAR) has been limited\u2014particularly as it relates to the reception of news. This study is based on a survey of 2,092 adults in Tallahassee, Florida at the height of a media driven \u201cpanic\u201d about violent crime. Controlling for age, gender, race, victim experience and other perceptions of crime, the frequency of watching television news and listening to news on the radio is significantly related to FEAR. Reading newspapers and newsmagazines and recall of detail concerning specific highly publicized violent crimes are unrelated to FEAR. When audiences are disaggregated by gender, race, and a series of third attributes, television news consumption is significantly related to FEAR only for white females between the ages of thirty and fifty-four. This finding holds regardless of victim experience, income or perceived safety. Several explanations derived from previous research are applied to this finding. Both \u201cresonance\u201d and \u201csubstitution\u201d have possible explanatory relevance, but the \u201caffinity\u201d of audience members with victims most often seen on television news may best account for the concentration of \u201cmedia effects\u201d among white women.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Ted Chiricos&quot;,&quot;Sarah Eschholz&quot;,&quot;Marc G. Gertz&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1997,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Social Problems&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/crime-news-fear-crime-toward-identification-audience-chiricos/2137540bc7fd5e8a8e5603560d5b6367/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.2307/3097181&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;44&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;342-357&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:2},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Viruses Going Viral: Impact of Fear-Arousing Sensationalist Social Media Messages on User Engagement&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Social media presents a promising yet competitive communication landscape for health practitioners and organizations during the rapid spread of an emerging infectious disease. The current study examined the association between the level of fear-arousing sensationalism and user engagement in 800 Facebook posts regarding the 2016 Zika virus outbreak. Results revealed that the majority of nonnews posts completely lacked sensationalist elements, and that user engagement increased significantly as the level of fear-arousing sensationalism increased from low levels. We discuss the potential value of message design that can engender an appropriate level of public concern and increase user engagement on social media.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;K. Ali&quot;,&quot;Khawaja Zain-ul-abdin&quot;,&quot;Cong Li&quot;,&quot;Lisa Johns&quot;,&quot;A. Ali&quot;,&quot;Nick Carcioppolo&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2019,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Science Communication&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/viruses-going-viral-impact-feararousing-sensationalist-ali/4898167e114b593a985587a3cd9cffd5/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/1075547019846124&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;41&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;314 - 338&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:3},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;How Fear-Arousing News Messages Affect Risk Perceptions and Intention to Talk About Risk&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;ABSTRACT Building on the theoretical arguments of the impersonal-impact and differential-impact hypotheses, this study has a twofold purpose: first, to demonstrate how fear-arousing media messages about risk are associated with personal-level risk perception, as well as, and perhaps more so than, societal-level risk perception; and second, to examine how the resulting risk perceptions can mediate intention to talk about the risk with family and friends. A news message evaluation study was conducted among the general public in South Korea concerning two major risks, carcinogens and bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE). Two sets of structural equation models reveal three main findings: (a) Fear-arousing news messages are positively related to personal-level risk perception, as well as to societal-level risk perception; (b) fear-arousing news messages result in intention to talk about the risk directly and indirectly through risk perception; and (c) personal-level risk perception appears more strongly related to intention to talk than does societal-level risk perception, although such relationships may vary across risk topics.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;H. Paek&quot;,&quot;Sang-Hwa Oh&quot;,&quot;Thomas Hove&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2016,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Health Communication&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/feararousing-news-messages-affect-risk-perceptions-paek/200b0ee7e04155ab9800282907d9f947/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/10410236.2015.1037419&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;31&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1051 - 1062&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:4},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Fear, threat and efficacy in threat appeals: message involvement as a key mediator to message acceptance.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;In a sample of 170 youngsters, the effect of two versions of a public service announcement (PSA) threat appeal against speeding, placed in four different contexts, on evoked fear, perceived threat (severity and probability of occurrence), perceived response efficacy and self-efficacy, message involvement and anti-speeding attitude and anti-speeding intention is investigated. Evoked fear and perceived threat and efficacy independently influence message involvement. Message involvement is a full mediator between evoked fear, perceived threat and efficacy perception on the one hand, and attitudes towards the message and behavioral intention to accept the message on the other. Speeding experience has a significantly negative impact on anti-speeding attitudes. Message and medium context threat levels and context thematic congruency have a significant effect on evoked fear and to a lesser extent on perceived threat.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Verolien Cauberghe&quot;,&quot;Patrick De Pelsmacker&quot;,&quot;W. Janssens&quot;,&quot;Nathalie Dens&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2009,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Accident; analysis and prevention&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/fear-threat-efficacy-threat-appeals-message-mediator-cauberghe/fe25a7675837531cbbf1483640ed4de9/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.aap.2008.11.006&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;41 2&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          276-85\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:5},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Threat and fear: Pragmatic purposes of emotionalisation in media discourse&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The impact of mass media on individuals and society is to a great extent based on emotions. We concentrate on fear as it is one of the basic emotions triggered by risk and threat, which is claimed to play a key role in the twenty-first century consciousness (Furedi 20018). The study focuses on the emotionalisation of fear in contemporary media discourse about Russia, more specifically, on constructions of Russian threat and fear of Russia in Anglo-American media texts to highlight pragmatic effects and to speculate on possible purposes of such discourses. The study aims to explore the functioning of the lexemes threat and fear , in textual contexts with the focus on their pragma-discursive characteristics. It identifies the mechanisms as well as linguistic tools involved in media strategies of scare-mongering. The dataset was derived from quality British and American newspapers in the period 2018-2020, and was analysed drawing on an interdisciplinary approach combining critical discourse analysis, pragmatics, medialinguistics, psycholinguistics and the theory of proximisation. The paper argues that appealing to emotions as well as constructing emotions is aimed at enhancing the persuasive function of media and fulfilling their own agenda. The persistent use of the words threat and fear in relation to Russia as well as the obsessive discussion of this topic in media aim to shape a certain negative public opinion of Russia among readerships. The findings show that to achieve this goal different strategies and linguistic tools are used including: exaggeration, repetition, proximisation, interrogative headlines, presupposition, among others. The results go beyond linguistics, and may find implementation in political studies, since they provide researchers with tools for understanding contemporary social and political processes.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Vladimir I. Ozymenko&quot;,&quot;T. Larina&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2021,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Russian Journal of Linguistics&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/threat-purposes-emotionalisation-media-discourse-ozymenko/6d103211012355a0851da784b568536f/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.22363/2687-0088-2021-25-3-746-766&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:6},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Investigating mediated effects of fear of COVID-19 and COVID-19 misunderstanding in the association between problematic social media use, psychological distress, and insomnia&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;\\n Introduction\\n Due to the serious situation of the novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) worldwide, many countries have implemented policies to minimize the spread of COVID-19 infection. However, some of these policies prevent people from physical contact. Consequently, many individuals may rely on social media to obtain information concerning COVID-19. Unfortunately, social media use (especially problematic social media use) may give rise to psychological distress. Therefore, this study thus examined potential psychopathology to explain the association between problematic social media use, psychological distress, and insomnia.\\n \\n Methods\\n Utilizing an online survey, a sample of Iranian young adults (n=1078 with 628 males; mean age=26.24 years [SD\u00b17.41]) completed questions and psychometric scales concerning psychological distress, insomnia, problematic social media use, fear of COVID-19, and COVID-19 misunderstanding.\\n \\n Results\\n Problematic social media use was significantly associated with psychological distress both directly and indirectly. The indirect effects were through fear of COVID-19 (unstandardized coefficient [B]=0.177; Bootstrapping SE=0.026) and COVID-19 misunderstanding (B=0.060; Bootstrapping SE=0.014). Problematic social media use was significantly associated with insomnia both directly and indirectly. The indirect effect was through fear of COVID-19 (B=0.062; Bootstrapping SE=0.019) but not COVID-19 misunderstanding (B=0.012; Bootstrapping SE=0.014).\\n \\n Discussion/Conclusion\\n Due to the pressure of the COVID-19 outbreak, individuals are highly likely to develop psychological distress and insomnia. Apart from developing appropriate health policies to minimize the spread of COVID-19 infection, healthcare providers should design appropriate online campaigns to eliminate people\u2019s fear of COVID-19 and to diminish misunderstanding concerning COVID-19.\\n&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Chung-Ying Lin&quot;,&quot;A. Brostr\u00f6m&quot;,&quot;M. Griffiths&quot;,&quot;A. Pakpour&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2020,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Internet Interventions&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/investigating-mediated-effects-fear-covid19-covid19-lin/6c5498d604cc5c4da0301be34cd29035/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.invent.2020.100345&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;21&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:7},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Understanding Self-Effects in Social Media&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The aim of this article is to improve understanding of self-effects in social media, and to compare self-effects with reception effects. Self-effects are the effects of messages the cognitions, emotions, attitudes, and behaviors of the message creators/senders themselves. A total of 4 theories have tried to explain self-effects in offline environments: self-persuasion, self-concept change, expressive writing, and political deliberation. The article reviews research into online self-effects that evolved from each of these theories, and argues why self-effects may be stronger online than offline. Based on this review, a model is introduced that helps explain how online self- and reception effects may coalesce and amplify each other. The article ends by presenting some suggestions for future research.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;P. Valkenburg&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2017,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Human Communication Research&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/understanding-selfeffects-social-media-valkenburg/39c04e90b34a5050af0c7320b0254427/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1111/HCRE.12113&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;43&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;477-490&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:8},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The limitations of fear messages&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Hastings and MacFadyen have raised important questions about the optimal direction for future tobacco control media campaigns. There is much that we agree with. However, we disagree with their central recommendation that campaigns should reduce the use of messages that portray the serious consequences of tobacco use in an emotionally evocative way. They base this recommendation on four assumptions which we feel are questionable:\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\nWe disagree with the first three of these points and would like to quibble a bit about the fourth.\\n\\nMost of the research on the effectiveness of fear appeals does indeed rely on models of rational cognitive processing. These models yield predictions about when fear appeals will be effective and when they won&#x27;t, based on concepts such as \u201cprotection motivation\u201d1 or subjective expected utility.2 They spawn complex experiments that attempt to produce variations in perceived severity of the danger, susceptibility to the danger, and perceived ability to perform the required response. Interestingly, these experiments frequently fail to yield support for the theoretical models.3 Instead, most studies show that the more fear aroused by the communication, the greater the persuasion.4,5 Likewise, we have evidence that the most effective anti-tobacco advertisements among both adults and teenagers \u2026&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;G. Hastings&quot;,&quot;L. Macfadyen&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2002,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Tobacco Control&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/limitations-fear-messages-hastings/f462fe25714a5030aa4e41f42328d9be/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1136/tc.11.1.73&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;11&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;73 - 75&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:9},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Fear: The potential of an appeal neglected by marketing.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Considerable social psychology and communications research show that intelligent use of fear messages can have favorable effects on attitude change and action. Yet the unique persuasive possibilities offered by the fear appeal have been neglected by marketing. This is in sharp contrast to the creative pursuit of positive advertising appeals. This article presents a marketing-oriented discussion and summary of research on the fear appeal.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. L. Ray&quot;,&quot;W. L. Wilkie&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1970,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Marketing&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/fear-appeal-neglected-marketing-ray/efb5f9532ae051639c1e7e551036b29b/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.2307/1250296&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;34&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;54-62&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:10},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Mass Media and Fear of Crime&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Charges that the mass media create unwarranted levels of fear of crime are almost as old as the media themselves. Researchers entered the fray in large numbers in the 1960s, documenting the effects of television, newspapers, and movies on perceptions of crime and fear of criminal victimization. Recent developments in mass media, such as the rise in popularity of crime reenactment television programs, the access to more violence via cable, VCR, and satellite dish, and the interactive nature of electronic games, raise even greater concern about the fear-generating potential of these media. In addition, the real-world increase in the occurrence of stranger crimes and mass attacks could make the media image even more potent, because of the prevalence of random or random-appearing crimes reported by the media. This article provides an overview of the research on the mass media and its effects on perceptions of crime danger, personal fear of crime, and reactions to crime risk. In addition, we examine the modifiers of the relationships between media and fear.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;L. Heath&quot;,&quot;Kevin Gilbert&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1996,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;American Behavioral Scientist&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/mass-media-fear-crime-heath/ca54e6b2a6945c3c8136fe19eb9f36f9/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/0002764296039004003&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;39&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;379 - 386&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:11},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Creating Fear: News and the Construction of Crisis&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The creative use of fear by news media and social control organizations has produced a \\&quot;discurse of fear\\&quot; - the awareness and expection that danger and risk are lurking everywhere. Case studies illustrates how certain organizations and social institutions benefit from the explotation of such fear construction. One social impact is a manipulated public empathy: We now have more \\&quot;victims\\&quot; than at any time in our prior history. Another, more troubling resutl is the role we have ceded to law enforcement and punishment: we turn ever more readily to the state and formal control to protect us from what we fear. This book attempts through the marshalling of significant data to interrupt that vicious cycle of fear discourse. David Altheide employs a method, which he calls \\&quot;tracking discourse\\&quot;, to map how the nature and the extent of the use of the word \\&quot;fear\\&quot; has changed since the 1980s; how the topics associated with fear, the topics of media discourse, have also changed over the same period (for example, the emphasis \\&quot;moves\\&quot; over time across AIDS, crime, immigrants, race, sexuality, schools, and children); and how certain news sources prevail over others, thus protectively insulating themselves from criticism of the premises of their discourse frames.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;David L. Altheide&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2002,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/creating-fear-news-construction-crisis-altheide/16db52f63cc756ddb4cd8df4b5008ff7/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.2307/1556563&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:12},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Effects of Fear Appeal: A Moderating Role of Culture and Message Type&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This study explores the moderating role that culture plays on the effects of fear-appeal advertisements on subjects\u2019 message acceptance. Secondly, this study investigates the role of message type in two different cultures (South Korea and the United States). As predicted, culture played as a moderating variable in the process of fear-arousing, antismoking ads. The main difference, however, was found in the collectivistic culture; although no significant difference was found for the individualistic culture.
