Results shows that age and not gender or education has a greater influence on the acceptance of fake news in particular cultures.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;G. Rampersad&quot;,&quot;Turki Althiyabi&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2019,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Information Technology &amp; Politics&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/fake-news-acceptance-demographics-culture-media-rampersad/50e688ef516a51c89520eed54a205d7e/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/19331681.2019.1686676&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;17&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1 - 11&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:14},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Fear of terrorism: media exposure and subjective fear of attack&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;ABSTRACT In many Western countries, citizen knowledge of terrorist events is intrinsically shaped by the style of broadcasted messages published by the media. Media discourses regarding terrorist acts raise questions about how such rhetoric elicits fear in people who typically experience such events through news reports. However, we do not fully understand the impact of the media on perceptions of terrorism as clearly as we understand the relationship between the media and fear of crime. This study examines how media sources accessed actively (e.g. through newspapers; Internet) or passively (e.g. through television; radio) influence knowledge and fear of terrorism. We find receiving information about terrorism from multiple media sources increases fear of terrorism, but media sources accessed passively are not as influential as media sources accessed more actively. These results highlight how media consumption from various sources may affect one\u2019s fear of terrorism, and further illustrates how the role of perceived knowledge may exacerbate or mitigate fear. Implications for policy and practice are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Harley Williamson&quot;,&quot;Suzanna Fay&quot;,&quot;Toby Miles-Johnson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2019,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Global Crime&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/fear-terrorism-media-exposure-fear-attack-williamson/88ce18ba671651c6af511c32bbdb06ab/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/17440572.2019.1569519&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;20&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1 - 25&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:15},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Breaking news: How local TV news and real-world conditions affect fear of crime&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Many Americans report that they are fearful of crime. One frequently cited source of this fear is the mass media. The media, and local television news in particular, often report on incidents of crime, and do so in a selective and sometimes sensational manner. This paper examines the role of the media in shaping crime fears, in conjunction with both demographic factors and local crime conditions. Unlike most previous research in this area, which typically focuses on only one medium, the present study examines the effects of several\u2014local and national television, radio, newspapers, and the Internet. The findings address four theoretical perspectives on the relationship among the media, real-world conditions, and fear of crime.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Ronald Weitzer&quot;,&quot;C. Kubrin&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2004,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Justice Quarterly&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/breaking-news-news-realworld-conditions-affect-fear-crime-weitzer/02fae02b3cb651a394476234f3f6160f/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/07418820400095881&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;21&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;497 - 520&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:16},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Effect of fear-arousing communications.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;IT is generally recognized that when beliefs and attitudes are modified, learning processes are involved in which motivational factors play a primary role. Symbols in mass communications can be manipulated in a variety of ways so as to arouse socially acquired motives such as need for achievement, group conformity, power-seeking, and the more emotion-laden drives arising from aggression, sympathy, guilt, and anxiety. The present experiment was designed to study the effects of one particular type of motive-incentive variable in persuasive communications, namely, the arousal of fear or anxiety by depicting potential dangers to which the audience might be exposed. Fear appeals of this sort are frequently used to influence attitudes and behavior. For example, medical authorities sometimes try to persuade people to visit cancer detection clinics by pointing to the dangerous consequences of failing to detect the early symptoms of cancer; various political groups play up the threat of war or totalitarianism in an attempt to motivate adherence to their political program. Our interest in such attempts is primarily that of determining the conditions under which the arousal of fear is effective or ineffective in eliciting changes in beliefs, practices, and attitudes. Implicit in the use of fear appeals is the assumption that when emotional tension is aroused, the audience will become more highly motivated to accept the reassuring beliefs or recommendations advocated by the 1 This study was conducted at Yale University as part of a coordinated program of research on attitude and opinion change, financed by a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation. The attitude change research project is under the general direction of Professor Carl I. Hovland, to whom the authors wish to express their appreciation for many valuable suggestions concerning the design of the experiment. Janis&quot;,&quot;S. Feshbach&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1953,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of abnormal psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/feararousing-communications-janis/aa74cc610d4d5611a325937f3e1d63e6/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/H0060732&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;48 1&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          78-92\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:17},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Appealing to fear: A meta-analysis of fear appeal effectiveness and theories.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Fear appeals are a polarizing issue, with proponents confident in their efficacy and opponents confident that they backfire. We present the results of a comprehensive meta-analysis investigating fear appeals&#x27; effectiveness for influencing attitudes, intentions, and behaviors. We tested predictions from a large number of theories, the majority of which have never been tested meta-analytically until now. Studies were included if they contained a treatment group exposed to a fear appeal, a valid comparison group, a manipulation of depicted fear, a measure of attitudes, intentions, or behaviors concerning the targeted risk or recommended solution, and adequate statistics to calculate effect sizes. The meta-analysis included 127 articles (9% unpublished) yielding 248 independent samples (NTotal = 27,372) collected from diverse populations. Results showed a positive effect of fear appeals on attitudes, intentions, and behaviors, with the average effect on a composite index being random-effects d = 0.29. Moderation analyses based on prominent fear appeal theories showed that the effectiveness of fear appeals increased when the message included efficacy statements, depicted high susceptibility and severity, recommended one-time only (vs. repeated) behaviors, and targeted audiences that included a larger percentage of female message recipients. Overall, we conclude that (a) fear appeals are effective at positively influencing attitude, intentions, and behaviors; (b) there are very few circumstances under which they are not effective; and (c) there are no identified circumstances under which they backfire and lead to undesirable outcomes.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Melanie B. However, less is known how social media consumption may influence individuals&#x27; levels of fear. Research indicates that messages utilizing fear (fear-based messages or FBMs) can significantly affect the public&#x27;s psychological state. Although such messages are often intended to inform or guide public behavior, they can lead to unintended consequences, such as increased anxiety, stigmatization, and even non-compliance with beneficial measures due to mistrust or fear fatigue. Here are some key insights from relevant research:\n\n1. **Psychological Impact of Fear-Based Messaging**: Fear-based messages can induce fear-related behaviors, such as avoidance of health services, stigma, discrimination, and non-compliance with public guidelines. Continuous exposure to such messages can lead to biased interpretations and overestimations of threats, significantly influencing psychological responses [(Swami &amp; Gupta, 2020)](https://consensus.app/papers/impact-fearbased-messages-context-covid-swami/9f125d8f625158d4a3a6378a1f5a12fd/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n2. **Media and Fear of Crime**: The frequency of consuming media, especially television news, has been found to correlate significantly with fear, particularly among certain demographics. This relationship suggests that media consumption can amplify fears about crime and safety [(Chiricos, Eschholz, &amp; Gertz, 1997)](https://consensus.app/papers/crime-news-fear-crime-toward-identification-audience-chiricos/2137540bc7fd5e8a8e5603560d5b6367/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n3. **Social Media and Fear**: Platforms like Facebook have been observed to increase user engagement with posts that contain fear-arousing sensationalist content. This can indicate that social media amplifies the impact of fear-based messaging, affecting public concern and engagement with issues [(Ali et al., 2019)](https://consensus.app/papers/viruses-going-viral-impact-feararousing-sensationalist-ali/4898167e114b593a985587a3cd9cffd5/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n4. **Impact of Fear on Behavior and Perception**: Fear-arousing news messages have been shown to increase personal-level risk perception more than societal-level risk perception. This heightened perception of personal risk can lead to increased discussions about risks and potentially change behavior and attitudes [(Paek, Oh, &amp; Hove, 2016)](https://consensus.app/papers/feararousing-news-messages-affect-risk-perceptions-paek/200b0ee7e04155ab9800282907d9f947/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n5. **Fear and Media Discourse**: The emotionalization of fear in media discourse, particularly in relation to perceived threats (like from specific countries or groups), aims to enhance media&#x27;s persuasive function and may fulfill particular agendas by shaping public opinion and perceptions [(Ozymenko &amp; Larina, 2021)](https://consensus.app/papers/threat-purposes-emotionalisation-media-discourse-ozymenko/6d103211012355a0851da784b568536f/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nIn summary, fear-based messaging in the media, whether relating to public health, crime, or other perceived threats, can significantly affect the public&#x27;s attitudes, behaviors, and perceptions. While these messages might aim to inform and protect the public, they can also lead to heightened anxiety, stigma, and a skewed perception of risk.\n\nFor more AI-powered insights, go to [consensus.app](https://consensus.app/?utm_source=chatgpt)."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

"text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Safe for Democracy: The Secret Wars of the CIA&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;\\&quot;Safe for Democracy\\&quot; for the first time places the story of the CIA&#x27;s covert operations squarely in the context of America&#x27;s global quest for democratic values and institutions. It evolved rapidly into an eclectic, well-resourced organization whose activities provided a substitute for overt military action and afforded essential backup when the Cold War turned hot in Korea and Vietnam. This comprehensive examination of a still controversial subject sheds valuable new light on the undercover operations mounted by the CIA during the Cold War. Using a wide range of unpublished government records and documents, James Callanan traces the growth of the agency chronologically as it forged a covert action mission that sought to advance US foreign and defense policy in all corners of the globe. As part of these efforts, the CIA undertook support of Russian exiles, populations uprooted either during World War II or by the Russian Revolution decades before. No one seemed better prepared to fight in the American secret war against communism than the uprooted Russians, whom the CIA directed to carry out propaganda, espionage, and subversion operations from their home base in West Germany. Yet the American engagement of Russian exiles had unpredictable outcomes. Drawing on recently declassified and previously untapped sources, Cold War Exiles and the CIA examines how the CIA\u2019s Russian operations became entangled with the internal struggles of Russia abroad and also the espionage wars of the superpowers in divided Germany. This indicates that the exposure counterintelligence strategy is a potent tool for defanging covert foreign election interference/partisan electoral interventions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Dov H. Levin&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2023,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Intelligence and National Security&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/sunlight-counterintelligence-technique-effectiveness-levin/fbadfe9f9b8a56fea1b73745f9cfc94d/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/02684527.2023.2181923&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;38&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;816 - 834&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:14},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Media technology, covert action, and the politics of exposure&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;States wishing to use force in the modern era frequently face strong incentives to exploit secrecy. Successful covert operations can reduce the likelihood of unwanted escalation with powerful rivals and help leaders conceal unpopular actions from domestic and foreign audiences alike. The many benefits of secrecy, however, can only be realized if covert operations remain covert. We argue that access to information and communications technologies (ICTs) is a critical factor that increases the chances that a covert mission will be exposed. As a result, leaders are much less likely to reach for the quiet option when a potential target has dense ICT networks. We illustrate our mechanism through US national security archival vignettes. We test our argument using a dataset of declassified US military and electoral interventions intended to subvert incumbent regimes throughout the Cold War. The core finding, that leaders are less likely to pursue covert action relative to alternative options when the chances of exposure are high, holds across five distinct measures of ICT networks as well as different model specifications and placebo tests. Our findings suggest that Cold War-style covert operations may well be a thing of the past in an age where communication and media technologies have proliferated to the far corners of the globe. We advance debates on communications technologies, covert action, and political violence.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Michael F Joseph&quot;,&quot;Michael Poznansky&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2018,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Peace Research&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/media-technology-action-politics-exposure-joseph/78d50b0184cc502181e7c34d3cde5b15/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/0022343317731508&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;55&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;320 - 335&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:15},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;\u2018The Sun Never Sets on the Activities of the CIA\u2019: Project Resistance at William and Mary&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract This article examines the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) on the campus of the College of William and Mary in 1969 and 1970. Although the CIA operation at William and Mary was first revealed in 1980, it has not received any scholarly attention. The CIA compiled information on students and faculty who were perceived to be radical. The CIA utilized informants working in the Office of the Dean of Men. In gathering information about students and professors, CIA officials violated the law and undermined academic freedom. The surveillance serves as a reminder of how easily a secret agency can threaten civil liberties and demonstrates why Congress must be vigilant in its oversight of the intelligence establishment.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;D. McCarthy&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2013,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Intelligence and National Security&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/never-sets-activities-project-resistance-william-mary-mccarthy/fc885b5915685f3ca3b593713ce639f1/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/02684527.2012.699291&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;28&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;611 - 633&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:16},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;CIA (Central Intelligence Agency) Covert Action in Zaire and Angola: Patterns and Consequences&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;\\&quot;Covert action\\&quot; as practiced by the United States Central Intelligence Agency has been defined as \\&quot;clandestine activity designed to influence foreign governments, events, organizations or persons in support of U.S. foreign policy conducted in such a way that the involvement of the U.S. Government is not apparent.\\&quot;1 The CIA has pursued its most substantial African covert actions in Zaire (the former Belgian Congo) and Angola. As the paramilitary, political, and propaganda operation unfolded in Angola in 19751976, both U.S. policymakers and distressed African observers were struck by its connection to earlier American intervention in Zaire. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger suggested that Angolan independence was fraught with the same dangers for U.S. security as Zairian independence in 1960: \\&quot;We cannot ignore, for example, the substantial Soviet build-up of weapons in Angola, which has introduced great power rivalry into Africa for the first time in 15 years.\\&quot;2 Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs William Schaufele, Jr., discerned \\&quot;obvious parallels between Soviet efforts to move in on the Congo after independence in&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. Weissman&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1979,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Political Science Quarterly&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/intelligence-agency-covert-action-zaire-angola-patterns-weissman/980d2a2bd59957ff8048951b15ebd35f/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.2307/2149851&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;94&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;263-286&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:17},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The CIA &amp; the cult of secrecy&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;PAGE This dissertation re-conceptualizes the scandals that engulfed the intelligence community in the mid-1970s. The Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) confronted an unprecedented crisis during these years: the Pike hearings in the House of Representatives, the Church Committee in the Senate, and an executive branch commission led by then Vice President Nelson Rockefeller. Historians and political scientists have studied these events before, but I present a nuanced interpretation of the intelligence investigations by placing them in a broader political and cultural context. To fully understand the impact of the so-called \\&quot;Year of Intelligence,\\&quot; I argue that scholars need to focus on what was happening outside of Congress. The CIA encountered a backlash from both ends of the political spectrum. I provide the first history of Counter-Spy, a left wing magazine founded in 1973 that called for the abolition of covert action. The magazine&#x27;s editors directly challenged the \\&quot;culture of secrecy\\&quot; at the CIA by publishing the names of Agency operatives. At the same time, conservatives embarked on a very different confrontation with the Agency. Like CounterSpy, they charged that the CIA was keeping secrets from the American people, but their concern was with Agency analysis of the Soviet Union, not covert action. I also examine Hollywood portrayals of the CIA in this tumultuous era; rather than simply responding to the Congressional investigations and the Rockefeller Commission, filmmakers actually anticipated the widespread concerns about the complex relationship between espionage and democracy. The events of the mid-1970s badly tarnished the CIA&#x27;s image. In response to this rapid decline in popular support, the Agency developed an aggressive public relations campaign designed to restore confidence in government secrecy and covert operations. This dissertation contains the first systematic history of CIA public relations. The public relations staff has consistently portrayed the CIA as the most open intelligence agency in the world, heroically protecting national security while accepting the necessity of Congressional oversight. But despite these public statements, Agency officials worked to revitalize the \\&quot;culture of secrecy.\\&quot; They have dramatically restricted the ability of former employees to write critically about CIA activities; they have successfully lobbied Congress for exemptions to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA); and they have repeatedly broken promises to de-classify historical records. Agency officials have been obsessed with protecting their image, and this obsession has frequently undermined historical research. Robert M. Gates launched an openness initiative in February 1992, but the culture at the Agency was not fundamentally changed. In fact, George Tenet shut down the voluntary de-classification program at the CIA in 1998. A key conclusion of this study is that the \\&quot;culture of secrecy\\&quot; at the Agency remains firmly entrenched. Since the CIA cannot be reformed from within, I argue that outside intervention is required.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;D. In fact, the CIA\u2019s obsession with secrecy kept most of its documents classified. Nevertheless, among the declassified materials released during the 1990s was Nicholas Cullather\u2019s 1994 Operation PBSUCCESS: The United States and Guatemala, 1952-1954, a secret report on CIA involvement in the 1954 overthrow of Guatemalan President Jacobo Arbenz. Here are some notable studies and analyses that shed light on the extent and impact of these operations:\n\n1. **Covert Operations and the Cold War**: James Callanan&#x27;s comprehensive examination of covert operations during the Cold War, including their evolution and impact on US foreign and defense policy across the globe, provides insight into the scope and nature of these operations [(Callanan, 2009)](https://consensus.app/papers/action-cold-policy-intelligence-operations-callanan/1f4f784ab9dd5808a648841321f71d8c/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n2. **Secret Wars and Democratic Values**: John Prados&#x27; "text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Italian \u2018Stay-Behind\u2019 network \u2013 The origins of operation \u2018Gladio\u2019&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract This essay is based on an analysis of the official documentation made available to the Italian Parliamentary Commissions of Inquiry on the origins and development of the stay-behind network in Italy. It tries to use these materials and integrate them with those of historical research on some related subjects in order to sketch out a tentative outline of the chronology and of the reasons for the creation of \u2018Gladio\u2019, as the stay-behind network was officially denominated. The article concludes that the documents released to the Parliamentary Committees do not permit the assumption that Operation \u2018Gladio\u2019 was involved in any illegal activities connected with the terrorism of the late 1960s and of the 1970s. The documents, in other words, do not help solving any of the mysteries which beleaguered Italian post-war history for more than a decade. On the other hand, the parliamentary reports tell a story which fits very well with the results of historical research on Italy&#x27;s foreign and security policy after World War II, and confirm some of its key assumptions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;L. Cacciatore&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2021,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Intelligence and National Security&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/staybehind-networks-interim-strategy-gladio-case-cacciatore/d5b426f021d451e68705fdc3983b06f1/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/02684527.2021.1911436&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;36&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;642 - 659&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:2},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The ghost of Machiavelli: An approach to operation Gladio and terrorism in cold war Italy&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;In 1990, a document was made public in Italy that shed new light on the secret aspects of the Cold War in Western Europe. The document, dated 1 June 1959, had been compiled by the Italian military secret service SIFAR and is entitled \u201cThe special forces of SIFAR and Operation Gladio\u201d. It explained that a secret stay-behind army linked to NATO had been set up in Italy for the purpose of unconventional warfare. Ever since, there have been allegations in Italy that the Gladio stay-behind army was linked to acts of terrorism during the Cold War. Despite their importance for criminal, legal and social investigations into the secret history of the Cold War, these questions have received next to no attention among the English-speaking research community since the documents&#x27; discovery, partly due to language barriers. With no claim to deal with the stay-behind armies in an exhaustive manner, this essay attempts to analyse and contextualise the Italian data.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;D. Ganser&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2006,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Crime, Law and Social Change&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/ghost-machiavelli-approach-operation-gladio-terrorism-ganser/c1921f069901502d9eebfbe4b30d7111/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1007/S10611-006-9015-7&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;45&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;111-154&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:3},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The mobilisation of the internal cold war in Italy&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;On 18 October 1990, Premier Giulio Andreotti disclosed that a clandestine guerrilla organisation, Gladio, had existed in Italy from the early 1950s.\u2019 President Antonio Cossiga asserted that its members were \u2018patriots\u2019 recruited to prepare resistance in case of an Eastern Bloc attack on Italy. Communists claimed that the clandestine organisation had operated to prevent a legal accession to power by the Left. The Venetian police magistrate, Felice Casson, who uncovered the secret network and others have raised questions about its possible connection with some of the unsolved acts of terrorism which afflicted Italy between 1969 and 1984.2 Bettino Craxi, who did not learn of the existence of Gladio until a year after he became premier in 1983, has asked \u2018Did it turn away from its original aims of national defence? Were members of it linked to the terrorist destruction?\u2018.3 His concerns were echoed by the Republican leader Giorgio La Malfa, who asked \u2018Could there be a connection between this structure and the tension, the killings, the deaths, the wounds inflicted on Italian life in the 1960s and 1970s until the beginning of the 1980s?\u2018.4 These concerns and the information that is available to the public concerning Gladio must be evaluated in the context of post-war Italian history. The intervention of the United States in internal Italian politics has been blatant and the dominant Christian Democrats from the beginning cast their lot with the United States. In the first three months of the crucial election year of 1948, the United States provided Italy with $176 million, but warned that aid would immediately be terminated if the Left was victorious at the polls. If the Italian voters did not allow themselves to be bought, the United States was ready to support an insurrection by providing underground groups with money and military assistance. The American Mediterranean fleet was strengthened; U.S. warships were dispatched to Italy\u2019s main ports; and preparations were made for a direct occupation of Sicily and Sardinia.s The Left, however, was defeated, and the Christian Democrats, who continued to receive American financial largess, played the role of docile clients. Though the post-war Italian armed forces amounted to no more than a token entity, Italy, primarily for political and strategic considerations, was brought into NATO at its inception in 1949. With the outbreak of the Korean War, the United States hastily equipped the Italian military with American ordinance. According to one of Andreotti\u2019s renditions, Gladio was formed in 1951 amid the tense climate engendered by the Korean War.6 William Colby, who served at the Rome CIA office and who directed the CIA between 1973 and 1976, has stated that the United States played a central role in setting up this \u2018secret army\u2019.\u2019&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Cook&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1994,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;History of European Ideas&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/mobilisation-cold-italy-cook/df3556a43c965cac896e6ba81eafb3ed/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/0191-6599(94)90204-6&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;19&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;115-120&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:4},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;EL CASO GLADIO: Una red militar clandestina en la Italia de la Guerra Fr\u00eda&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;espanolDurante la Guerra Fria existio una red clandestina vinculada a la OTAN, denominada StayBehind, cuya mision habria sido actuar tras las lineas enemigas en caso de invasion sovietica. Puesto que la invasion nunca se produjo, esta red nunca actuo y su existencia habria permanecido oculta si el presidente del Gobierno italiano Giulio Andreotti, no la hubiera revelado en 1990. La rama italiana de Stay-Behind era conocida como Gladio y, aunque las investigaciones judiciales y parlamentarias no han hallado prueba alguna de su implicacion en actividades delictivas, se ha difundido una teoria de la conspiracion que la implica en el terrorismo de los \u201canos de plomo\u201d. Este articulo refuta dicha teoria sobre la base de la amplia documentacion sobre el tema hoy accesible a los investigadores, y plantea tambien cuales son los puntos todavia no esclarecidos en la historia de Gladio. EnglishDuring the Cold War, Stay-Behind was a clandestine network connected to NATO whose mission would have been to act behind enemy lines in the event of a Soviet invasion. Since the invasion never took place, this network never acted and its existence would have remained hidden if the president of the Italian government, Giulio Andreotti, had not disclosed it in 1990. The Italian branch of Stay-Behind was known as Gladio and, although judicial and parliamentary inquiries have not found any evidence of its involvement in criminal activities, a conspiracy theory that maintains its responsabilty in the terrorism of the \u201clead years\u201d has been spread. This article refutes that theory on the basis of the extensive documentation on the subject now available to researchers and addresses the points that have not yet been clarified in Gladio&#x27;s story.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. Il dibattito culturale e politico sulla riforma della legislazione ecclesiastica. \\nABSTRACT: Individuals and experiences that, in the years between 1962 and 1970, had an important influence on the civic and political growth of the author and Gladio Gemma. Lariccia&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2022,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Stato, Chiese e pluralismo confessionale&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/amicizia-gladio-gemma-negli-anni-insegnamento-modena-lariccia/c8540f20777d5ad6afe89c64a26d1182/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.54103/1971-8543/19073&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:6},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The GLAD-IN-ART Project&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The GLAD-IN-ART project deals with the development of a glove-exoskeleton interface system utilized by the human operator for the control of manipulative procedures of virtual objects. The main feature of the advanced interface is the capability of replicating both internal and external force sensations to the human operator. More than 300 people, divided into 15 research teams and two support groups, worked for one year on the project. Twenty-two journals were systematically searched for the period 1918\u20131990, 350,000 newspaper issues were screened, and 39,953 articles were collected. About 150 experts on mass movement and floods were interviewed and 1482 published and unpublished technical and scientific reports were reviewed. The results of the AVI project, in spite of the limitations, represent the most comprehensive archiving of mass movement and floods ever prepared in Italy. The type and quality of the information collected and the methodologies and techniques used to make the inventory are discussed. Some, such as the friezes from the tomb of C. Lusius Storax at Teate Marrucinorum (Chieti) or the large relief panel from near Pompeii\u2019s Porta Stabia, are well-preserved and well-known; but the majority are fragmentary, some showing no more than a pair of legs or part of a worn figure. M. Flecker\u2019s book, based on an Augsburg dissertation of 2008/9 directed by V. Kockel, sets out to collect and analyse these pieces and to set them in their historical and art-historical contexts. As with many dissertations, the core of the work is a catalogue (chapt. IX, section A), which lists and describes 79 reliefs. Almost all are illustrated, often with excellent photographs from the collection of the DAI Rome; and Flecker has examined a large number of them in person. They include the spectacular blocks from a frieze with nearly-lifesize gladiators recovered from robbers at Fiano Romano and displayed in the museum at Lucus Feroniae, north of Rome (A 34); only preliminary publications of this important discovery have been published to date,1 and it is very welcome that Flecker has been authorised to describe and to illustrate the reliefs fully, even if other elements are not yet published (notably the fragments of an accompanying inscription and a togatus statue). For each entry Flecker gives an oftenextensive bibliography and a detailed description, which concentrates on the categories of gladiator depicted, their equipment and arms, and the iconographic scheme followed. Very few of the reliefs can be dated on an epigraphic basis; these include some atypical examples dating from the 2nd c. A.D., later than the main period covered here. For the rest, Flecker proposes dates based primarily on the Realien (especially the equipment and arms of the gladiators) and on his conception of the overall development of gladiatorial combat, both being discussed in the first part of the book; he concludes that the main period of production falls in the 1st c. B.C. and A.D., with concentration especially in the Caesarian and early to mid-Augustan periods (cf. chart on 180). Dunbabin&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2018,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Roman Archaeology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/gladiator-reliefs-italy-developments-gladiator-imagery-dunbabin/d9bc241671fc5a9b932777be803c6704/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1017/S1047759418001770&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;31&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;694 - 700&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:16},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Preliminary Characterization of Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. gladioli Causing Fusarium Corm Rot of Saffron in Italy.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Fusarium corm rot of saffron (Crocus sativus L.), incited by Fusarium oxysporum Schlecht. f. sp. gladioli, causes severe stigma yield losses in L&#x27;Aquila Province in Central Italy. Primary symptoms during flowering (October through November) include basal stem rot, yellowing and wilting of shoots, and corm rot. The rapid spread of the disease is apparently caused only by movement of contaminated and/or infected corms (2,3). Ten isolates of F. oxysporum f. sp. gladioli, obtained from infected saffron crops located in the principal areas of saffron production in L&#x27;Aquila Province (2,3), were characterized by vegetative compatibility tests. The isolates were placed into vegetative compatibility groups (VCGs) using heterokaryon tests with chlorate-resistant nitrate-nonutilizing (nit) mutants. Based on complementation among these isolates and with a representative isolate of VCG 0340 (4), the tested isolates were assigned to VCG 0340. The fact that all isolates examined in this study belong to a single VCG supports the hypothesis that a clonal population of F. oxysporum f. sp. gladioli is spreading in L&#x27;Aquila Province in planting stock. In previous studies, only two Italian isolates of the pathogen obtained from Gladiolus were tested for vegetative compatibility, and both were included in VCG 0343 (1,4). Acquisition of further information on a larger number of isolates obtained from other cropping sites and associated with other hosts may result in a better understanding of the origin and spread of the pathogen in Italy, leading to improved strategies for control of Fusarium corm rot of saffron. One location where they have yielded spectacular results is Carnuntum in Austria, on the south bank of the Danube, capital of the key Roman province of Pannonia. Excavations in the late nineteenth and twentieth centuries revealed many of the major elements of this extensive complex, including the legionary fortress and the civilian town or municipium. Excavation, however, is no longer the only way of recovering and recording the details of these buried structures. In 2011, a combination of non-invasive survey methods in the area to the south of the civilian town, where little was visible on the surface, led to the dramatic discovery of remains interpreted as a gladiatorial school, complete with individual cells for the gladiators and a circular training arena. The combination of techniques has led to the recording and visualisation of the buried remains in astonishing detail, and the impact of the discovery is made all the greater by the stunning reconstruction images that the project has generated.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;W. Meirvenne&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2014,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Antiquity&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/school-gladiators-carnuntum-austria-neubauer/441b1ccff03756458e8c9e81dfed1778/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1017/S0003598X00050298&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;88&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;173 - 190&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:18},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The fluctuations of italian glaciers during the last century: a contribution to knowledge about alpine glacier changes&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract. This paper describes the recent evolution of Italian glaciers through an analysis of all available terminus fluctuation data that the authors have entered in a glaciers database (named GLAD) containing 883 records collected on glaciers from 1908 to 2002. Furthermore, a representative subset of data (249 glaciers located in Lombardy) was analysed regarding surface area changes. For the analysis of terminus fluctuations, the glaciers were sorted by size classes according to length. The data showed that during the 20th century Italian Alpine glaciers underwent a generalized retreat, with one distinct and well documented readvance episode that occurred between the 1970s and mid\u20101980s, and a poorly documented one around the early 1920s. The rates of terminus advance and retreat have changed without significant delays for the larger glaciers with respect to the smaller ones. However, the smaller the glacier, the more limited the advance (if any) during the 1970s and early 1980s. The behaviour of glaciers shorter than 1 km appears to have changed in the last decade, and between 1993 and 2002 they retreated at a very high rate. The analysis of the subset of data led to a quanti\u2010fication of surface reduction of c. 10% from 1992 to 1999 for glaciers in Lombardy. Small glaciers proved to contribute strongly to total area loss: in 1999, 232 glaciers (c. 90% of the total) were smaller than 1 km2, covering 27.2 km2 (less than 30% of the total area), but accounted for 58% of the total loss in area (they had lost 7.4 km2).&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. The study is aimed at contributing to understanding the potential of remote sensing technologies in measuring complex deformation phenomena in historic buildings, such as those caused by soil-structural interaction and earthquakes, considering the monumental Consoli Palace and the Town Walls as case studies. The research activities have been carried out within the European HERACLES project, funded in the framework of Horizon (2020) and aimed at proposing novel diagnostic monitoring solutions for enhancing heritage resilience against various types of hazards. The mission of these networks was to prepare for and act in the event of a Soviet invasion or influence. Although initially intended for defense against foreign invasions, there have been controversies and debates regarding Gladio&#x27;s activities, including alleged involvement in political manipulation and terrorism within Italy.\n\nHere are key findings from scholarly research on Project Gladio in Italy:\n\n1. **Origins and Development**: The Italian &#x27;Stay-Behind&#x27; network, known as Operation &#x27;Gladio&#x27;, was officially denominated and established in the post-World War II period. While documents released to Italian Parliamentary Committees have not definitively connected Gladio to illegal activities or domestic terrorism, they have contributed to understanding Italy&#x27;s foreign and security policies in the aftermath of World War II [(Nuti, 2007)](https://consensus.app/papers/staybehind-network-origins-operation-gladio-nuti/4bbf93e1c2f5591e81159d13b26d6ecd/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n2. **US Covert Intervention**: The Italian stay-behind network has been studied in the context of American covert intervention, exploring broader policymaking and strategic issues. These networks, including Gladio, were part of a larger framework of U.S. efforts to counteract Soviet influence in Italy and other Western countries during the Cold War [(Cacciatore, 2021)](https://consensus.app/papers/staybehind-networks-interim-strategy-gladio-case-cacciatore/d5b426f021d451e68705fdc3983b06f1/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n3. **Conspiracy and Terrorism**: There have been numerous allegations linking Gladio to acts of terrorism during the Cold War, especially during Italy&#x27;s &quot;Years of Lead.&quot; Although there is significant debate among researchers, concrete evidence tying Gladio directly to terrorist activities remains inconclusive. However, the existence of the network and its potential for misuse have led to serious concerns and inquiries [(Ganser, 2006)](https://consensus.app/papers/ghost-machiavelli-approach-operation-gladio-terrorism-ganser/c1921f069901502d9eebfbe4b30d7111/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nThese studies provide an understanding of Project Gladio&#x27;s role within the broader context of the Cold War and Italian history. While Gladio was part of a larger NATO strategy, its legacy is intertwined with Italy&#x27;s political and social turbulence during the latter half of the 20th century."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

"text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;R &amp; D Cooperation in AI: Report on the U.S. and Japanese panel, IJCAI 1985&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The consensus of government, academic, and industry leaders widely supports the strategic positioning of U.S. and Japanese research and development in mutually beneficial, two-way flows of innovation. This report is derived from the IJCAI panel titled U.S and Japanese Cooperation in AI and R&amp;D Opportunities, held August 23, 1986 at the University of California at Los Angeles. This panel discussed the sensitive topic of alternatives to nationalistic competitive strategies that have contributed to an extreme trade deficit surpassing $40 billion in 1986. The ideas offered by the panelists shed light on ways our countries&#x27; respective scientific communities can blend talents to achieve the best results in reducing trade frictions. Each country has designated AI research as a key to unlock years of generations of technology and has directed billions of dollars to fund this development. The most recognized projects are the U.S. Microelectronics Technology Computer Consortium (MCC) and Japan&#x27;s Fifth Generation Computer Project (ICOT). Although noting the obstacles, the panelists encouraged specific, shared efforts to ensure the development of a closer working relationship to explore AI&#x27;s benefits.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;H. Jacobson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1986,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Ai Magazine&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/cooperation-report-japanese-panel-ijcai-1985-jacobson/e12dd01ae55056ce9c8672907b189f86/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1609/AIMAG.V7I2.539&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;7&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;65-69&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:1},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Overseas Research: A Practical Guide&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Scholars and students engaged in overseas research projects often spend much of their time worrying about mundane details never reported in published research. In fact, the quality of scholarship often depends on the researcher&#x27;s ability to navigate a bewildering array of social, financial, bureaucratic, and logistical obstacles encountered in preparing for, working in, and recovering from \\&quot;the field.\\&quot; &#x27;Overseas Research: A Practical Guide&#x27; is the first book designed explicitly to prepare scholars and professionals for the real-life challenges of living and working abroad. Opening with a discussion of site selection and project funding, the authors advise researchers on preparing for departure, setting up residence in the field, conducting research in an unfamiliar environment, employing field assistants, and organizing for and adjusting to the return home. The text is supplemented with the insights, anecdotes, and tips from more than sixty scholars in a wide variety of disciplines who conducted research in more than forty countries.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;C. Using an adaptation of the Value\u2013Belief\u2013Norm theory of proenvironmental behavior (Stern, 2000), we hypothesized that study abroad nurtures global citizenship related to ecologically conscious behaviors by strengthening core relations among environmental values, beliefs, and norms. The sample consisted of students (n = 623) from 10 U.S. universities participating in a 4-week study abroad program to either Australia or New Zealand in 2008 and 2009. A pre-, posttest design was adopted in which students voluntarily completed a survey instrument on the first and last days of the program in the destination country. Results of the study suggested that the modified Value\u2013Belief\u2013Norm approach provides a robust theoretical framework, used in conjunction with theories of learning, for explaining how proenvironmental behavior is nurtured. The pace of change for this new AI technological age is staggering, with new breakthroughs in algorithmic machine learning and autonomous decision-making, engendering new opportunities for continued innovation. The impact of AI could be significant, with industries ranging from: finance, healthcare, manufacturing, retail, supply chain, logistics and utilities, all potentially disrupted by the onset of AI technologies. The data for this analysis is based on 127,000 research clusters (RCs) that are derived from 1.4 billion citation links between 104.8 million documents from four databases (Dimensions, Microsoft Academic Graph, Web of Science, and the Chinese National Knowledge Infrastructure). Of these RCs, 600 large clusters are associated with AI/ML topics, and 161 of these AI/ML RCs are expected to experience extreme growth between May 2020 and May 2023. Funding acknowledgments (in the corpus of the 104.9 million documents) are used to characterize the overall AI/ML research portfolios of each organization. NNSFC is the largest funder of AI/ML research and disproportionately funds computer vision. The EC, RC, and JSPS focus more efforts on natural language processing and robotics. The NSF and ERC are more focused on fundamental advancement of AI/ML rather than on applications. They are more likely to participate in the RCs that are expected to have extreme growth. NIH funds the largest relative share of general AI/ML research papers (meaning in areas other than computer vision, natural language processing, and robotics). Stay Rates of Foreign Doctorate Recipients from US Universities: 2005 (Oak Ridge Institute for Science and Education, 2007). Chinese students who receive their doctoral degrees in the United States are more likely than students from any other country to stay there. China is implementing a new scheme to try to lure the most promising ones back home. STAYING IN THE UNITED STATES China has announced a nationwide plan that promises top salaries and attractive funding to elite researchers who are working overseas and willing to return to the country. The plan, known as the one-thousand-talents scheme, aims to boost China\u2019s innovation capability. But critics say that its success will depend on whether domestic talent gets similar support, and whether the country\u2019s science infrastructure can be reformed. \u201cThe scheme sends a strong signal that the Chinese government values talented people from overseas and welcomes their contribution in key areas of research development,\u201d says Zhanqing Li, an atmospheric scientist at the University of Maryland in College Park. The plan, announced this month by the country\u2019s top personnel administration, targets people with full professorships or the equivalent in developed countries. It offers a relocation package of 1 million renminbi (US$146,000) per person, with salaries and research funding left to universities and institutes to sort out. Previous approaches \u2014 such as the Chinese Academy of Sciences\u2019 onehundred-talents scheme and the education ministry\u2019s Yangtze River Scholar Scheme \u2014 have lured more than 4,000 researchers, mostly at postdoctoral or assistant-professor levels, back to the country in the past fifteen years.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. We integrated highly structured research experiences into short-term study abroad programs across multiple countries, then tested for longer term student perceived impacts. Based on qualitative and quantitative analysis of postgraduation data provided by 118 former participants, we identified positive self-reported impacts across a range of domains relevant to longer term academic and career success (e.g., professional connections, specific skills, worldview, and personal growth). Themes and subthemes were consistently similar by minority status, gender, and program locations. Inclusion of highly structured research experiences in short-term study abroad can provide additional value to students. Therefore, it is imperative that colleges and universities understand how the characteristics and backgrounds of their students influence intent to study abroad. This study examined factors that may affect U.S. student participation in study abroad, including parental income and education, gender, race, intended major, attitudes about other cultures, and distance of college from home. Data were collected from a large, public northeastern university in the United States that participated in the 2007 Cooperative Institutional Research Program (CIRP) survey, which provides information about incoming students\u2019 backgrounds, academic and career expectations, personal goals, and opinions on a wide range of political and social issues. In this study, through the application of natural language processing, machine learning, and statistical algorithms, we examine extant literature in terms of its dominant topics, diversity, evolution over time, and dynamics to map the existing knowledge base. Ten salient research themes emerge: (1) understanding consumer sentiments, (2) industrial opportunities of AI, (3) analyzing customer satisfaction, (4) electronic word-of-mouth\u2013based insights, (5) improving market performance, (6) using AI for brand management, (7) measuring and enhancing customer loyalty and trust, (8) AI and novel services, (9) using AI to improve customer relationships, and (10) AI and strategic marketing. The scientometric analyses reveal key concepts, keyword co-occurrences, authorship networks, top research themes, landmark publications, and the evolution of the research field over time. With the insights as a foundation, this article closes with a proposed agenda for further research.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Mustak&quot;,&quot;Joni O. Salminen&quot;,&quot;L. Pl\u00e9&quot;,&quot;Jochen Wirtz&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2020,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Business Research&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/intelligence-marketing-topic-modeling-analysis-research-mustak/65f582c0eda35c218d79c51392582014/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.jbusres.2020.10.044&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:18},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Training and Working Abroad&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Publisher Summary This chapter explores the benefits of international mobility for research and development. Spending a period abroad to pursue training and/or work opportunities can be very beneficial, not only to the scientists themselves but to their employers, their home countries, and society itself. Scientists have globally marketable skills. This can be demonstrated by mapping individual moves. A second way to demonstrate the transferability of scientific research skills across national borders is to identify the countries of origin of the students, postdoctoral fellows, and scientists working in a single institute at a single point of time. Migration patterns between countries or between regions of the world are not necessarily balanced. For example, if one looks at exchanges between candidate countries and the EU that were funded by the European Commission Research Directorate&#x27;s \u201cFifth Framework Program\u201d (1998\u20132000), 18% of EU fellows came from candidate countries to work in EU member states, while only 1.5% of EU fellows from EU member states chose to work in candidate countries. There are several stages in a scientific career when thought can be given to the possibility of studying or doing research abroad. These are at the undergraduate level, the earning of a Ph.D., the postdoctoral phase, the first or subsequent job, and a sabbatical.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Osborn&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2006,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/training-working-abroad-osborn/c64535be8e3a5a0e99ea5fe56f0f5902/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/B978-012088411-7/50044-0&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;37-58&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:19},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Keeping Top AI Talent in the United States&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Talent is core to U.S. competitiveness in artificial intelligence, and international graduate students are a large source of AI talent for the United States.
