A human aict ~s specified by (and s? is co.rrect:ly describe~ in terms of) its end. A human act IS specified by (and so Is correctly described in terms of) its object. An a:ct which is bad by reason of its object cannot be justified by its end (its: good intention) . A human a:ct is specified by (and so is correctly described in iterms of) its intention .... Such a sequence of statements of St. Thomas ought to leave an impression of confusion. That impression would be heightened by the traditional representation of his analysis of acting in a schema of 12 terms signifying a sequence of psychological acts involved in willing and doing something. For in this analysis, intention seems to precede \u00b7deliberating, judging, and choosing, and so, as deliberating, judging, and choosing often present themselves to consciousness distinctly, intention is presented in this analysis as if it were a distinct content of consciousness. When intention is so conceived, iit becomes possible to imagine that one can, so to speak, choose to direct (an) intention to or withhold it from the various aspects of one&#x27;s chosen behavior, e.g. it.hose consequences which one foresees and welcomes or those one chooses to bring about onJ.y with regret. The concept of power is intricately linked to the state of mind and intentions of an individual, emphasizing the complexity of human behavior beyond just rational actions [(White, 1971)](https://consensus.app/papers/power-intention-white/dfa5cc60676f5719bc9cea4a8ace168a/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n2. Conscious Intention and Motor Cognition [(Haggard, 2005)](https://consensus.app/papers/intention-motor-cognition-haggard/17b609fc3d54561e8cd455f937a543c6/?utm_source=chatgpt)\nIn this study, the author explores the subjective experience of conscious intention, which is a key component of our mental life. Philosophical discussions have questioned whether conscious intentions can cause actions. Modern neuroscience, however, shifts this debate by suggesting that the experience of intending to act originates from action preparation processes in frontal and parietal brain areas. This study highlights that both the sense of intention and the sense of agency\u2014our feeling of controlling events in the external world\u2014are results of the brain&#x27;s mechanisms for predictive motor control rather than merely retrospective inferences. This insight reshapes our understanding of conscious free will by grounding it in specific brain processes rather than abstract philosophical concepts.\n\n### 5. The Intention/Volition Debate [(Adams &amp; Mele, 1992)](https://consensus.app/papers/intentionvolition-debate1-adams/5bd4a67f0a4a56afb45781648f62a7f9/?utm_source=chatgpt)\nThis paper delves into the ongoing debate regarding the nature and existence of volition and how it relates to intention and the process of trying. The authors argue that the major roles traditionally ascribed to the concept of volition can be effectively fulfilled by a combination of intention, the act of trying, and feedback mechanisms. This suggests a more integrated approach to understanding human action, where intention and the effort of trying, combined with the response to feedback, play crucial roles. The study challenges the need for a distinct concept of volition beyond these elements, proposing a simplified framework for analyzing human behavior.\n\n### 6. Intentionality, the Heart of Human Will [(May, 1965)](https://consensus.app/papers/intentionality-heart-human-will-may/359696f4be6e5b72a375f17be118d00e/?utm_source=chatgpt)\nRollo May&#x27;s work revives the medieval concept of intentionality, which was sidelined by the Cartesian mind-body dichotomy. Intentionality is described as the bridge between mind and body, making their bifurcation impossible. May argues that intentionality is central to understanding human consciousness and the dynamics of wish and will. Unlike mere conscious intentions or desires, intentionality encompasses a broader state of being, reflecting the individual&#x27;s total orientation to the world at any given time. This can include unconscious drives and motivations, revealing a more complex interplay between an individual&#x27;s conscious goals and their underlying intentionality. May emphasizes that understanding this concept is crucial for psychotherapy and offers a richer understanding of human experience, beyond the limitations of traditional academic psychology.\n\nEach of these studies offers a unique perspective on the nature of human intention and will, from the neurological underpinnings to philosophical debates and psychological interpretations, contributing to a comprehensive understanding of these complex phenomena."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

It challenges the classical notion of conscious intentions causing actions, suggesting instead that the feeling of intention results from brain activity preparing for action. The study indicates that both intention and the sense of agency (feeling in control of actions) stem from the brain&#x27;s predictive mechanisms for motor control, rather than from a post-action rationalization process. This perspective shifts the understanding of free will and conscious decision-making by proposing a model where conscious intention arises as a byproduct of the brain&#x27;s motor preparation processes.\n\n5. **The Intention/Volition Debate1** [(Adams &amp; Mele, 1992)](https://consensus.app/papers/intentionvolition-debate1-adams/5bd4a67f0a4a56afb45781648f62a7f9/?utm_source=chatgpt): Adams and Mele explore the distinctions between intention, volition, and trying in human action. They scrutinize the philosophical and psychological aspects of human action, questioning whether there is a need to distinguish between willing to do things and merely intending or trying to do them. The authors propose that the functions usually attributed to volition can be explained by a combination of intention, trying, and feedback from actions, arguing that these elements sufficiently account for human action without needing to invoke an additional concept of volition. This paper contributes to the philosophical debate on the nature of human action and the mechanisms underlying intentional behavior.\n\n6. **Intentionality, the Heart of Human Will** [(May, 1965)](https://consensus.app/papers/intentionality-heart-human-will-may/359696f4be6e5b72a375f17be118d00e/?utm_source=chatgpt): Rollo May&#x27;s work delves into the concept of intentionality as fundamental to human consciousness and action, arguing against the Cartesian dualism of mind and body. May emphasizes that intentionality is a bridging concept that renders such a dualism untenable. He discusses how intentionality is crucial in psychotherapy and human experience, impacting areas of wish, will, and consciousness. By examining the discrepancy between a person&#x27;s conscious intentions and their deeper, often unconscious, intentionality, May illustrates how understanding this concept can lead to a richer understanding of human behavior and psychotherapeutic processes.\n\n7. **Willpower and perceived behavioral control: Influences on the intention-behavior relationship and postbehavior attributions** [(Fitch &amp; Ravlin, 2005)](https://consensus.app/papers/willpower-perceived-control-influences-fitch/99d5941af38155b98d9f6fab0f9a2c52/?utm_source=chatgpt): This study examines how individual differences in willpower (related to conscientiousness) and perceived behavioral control (the belief about how much control one has over their actions) affect the relationship between intentions and behaviors. The authors investigate how these factors influence whether a person&#x27;s intentions lead to actual behaviors and how people attribute causes to their behaviors post-action. Their findings suggest that willpower and perceived behavioral control can moderate the strength of the intention-behavior link and influence how individuals attribute success or failure, which has significant implications for understanding motivation and self-regulation.\n\nThese studies collectively provide insights into the cognitive and neurological underpinnings of human intention and willpower, offering a multifaceted understanding of how intentions guide behavior and how our brain constructs the sense of agency and decision-making."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

You make it to the platform just in time to see your train go by, leaving the station without you. Now you must wait on the platform, crowded with many others, feeling hot, sweaty, perhaps a bit miserable, thinking of going to a job that you don&#x27;t care for, with people you don&#x27;t like, for pay you consider a pittance just to pay your bills. Amid the chaos, discomfort, and dissatisfaction with your job, you&#x27;re overwhelmed with negative emotions. In this all-too-familiar setting, it&#x27;s hard to believe that happiness could be a matter of personal choice. Yet, emerging scientific research and philosophical debates suggest that our intentions and willpower significantly shape our emotional experiences and realities.\n\nThe concept of conscious intention and its role in our actions has been scrutinized by researchers like Haggard (2005), who explored how our brain prepares for action and how this relates to our subjective experience of intention. Contrary to the traditional belief in free will, Haggard&#x27;s findings suggest that the feeling of intending to act arises from the brain&#x27;s preparation for action, highlighting the predictive nature of motor control mechanisms. This scientific perspective challenges the notion of direct mind-body causation but supports the idea that by focusing our intention, we may harness the brain&#x27;s predictive capacities to influence our emotional states [(Haggard, 2005)](https://consensus.app/papers/intention-motor-cognition-haggard/17b609fc3d54561e8cd455f937a543c6/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nPhilosophically, the debate around intention and volition delves deeper into human agency. Adams and Mele (1992) discuss how intentions, combined with efforts and feedback, fulfill the roles ascribed to volition, suggesting that our actions are more a result of a complex interplay between intention and trying rather than sheer willpower alone. This aligns with the notion that deciding to adopt a positive outlook could indeed reshape one&#x27;s emotional landscape [(Adams &amp; Mele, 1992)](https://consensus.app/papers/intentionvolition-debate1-adams/5bd4a67f0a4a56afb45781648f62a7f9/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nRollo May (1965) further illuminates the power of intentionality, arguing that it is at the heart of consciousness and human will. Intentionality, as a state of being, encompasses our total orientation towards the world at any given time, which could be contrary to our conscious intentions. This suggests that by realigning our deeper intentionality, we could transform our experience of reality, transcending the immediate negativity of a moment like missing a train [(May, 1965)](https://consensus.app/papers/intentionality-heart-human-will-may/359696f4be6e5b72a375f17be118d00e/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nFurthermore, Fitch and Ravlin (2005) explore how willpower and perceived behavioral control influence our actions and emotional responses. Their research indicates that higher willpower correlates with behavior more consistent with one&#x27;s intentions. This supports the idea that strengthening our willpower and controlling our focus could enable us to maintain a sense of inner peace amidst chaos [(Fitch &amp; Ravlin, 2005)](https://consensus.app/papers/willpower-perceived-control-influences-fitch/99d5941af38155b98d9f6fab0f9a2c52/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nWhat these studies collectively suggest is that while our immediate circumstances might prompt automatic negative reactions, the broader capacity of our intentions\u2014shaped by complex neurological processes, philosophical understandings, and psychological efforts\u2014can significantly influence our emotional state. The scenario on the train platform, rather than being a moment of despair, can become an opportunity for practicing this power of intention. By deciding to view the situation differently, by intentionally shifting focus from the external to an inner sense of peace, we can control our emotions and, consequently, our happiness.\n\nIn conclusion, while external situations inevitably impact our emotions, the scientific and philosophical underpinnings of intention and willpower offer empowering perspectives. They suggest that by cultivating strong intentions and focusing our will, we can transform our emotional experiences and shape our reality. In the crowded train platform of life, it turns out, happiness could indeed be a choice \u2013 a choice rooted in the power of our intentions.\n\nFor those intrigued by the interplay between intention, willpower, and emotion, further exploration into the realms of cognitive neuroscience, philosophy of mind, and psychology may provide additional insights and practical strategies for harnessing this transformative power."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

"create_time": 1709598049.341001, "update_time": 1709598037.1307719, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Conscious intention and motor cognition&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The subjective experience of conscious intention is a key component of our mental life. Philosophers studying &#x27;conscious free will&#x27; have discussed whether conscious intentions could cause actions, but modern neuroscience rejects this idea of mind-body causation. Instead, recent findings suggest that the conscious experience of intending to act arises from preparation for action in frontal and parietal brain areas. Intentional actions also involve a strong sense of agency, a sense of controlling events in the external world. Both intention and agency result from the brain processes for predictive motor control, not merely from retrospective inference.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;P. Haggard&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2005,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Trends in Cognitive Sciences&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/intention-motor-cognition-haggard/17b609fc3d54561e8cd455f937a543c6/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.tics.2005.04.012&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;9&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;290-295&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:1},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Conscious intention and brain activity.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The problem of free will lies at the heart of modern scientific studies of consciousness. An influential series of experiments by Libet has suggested that conscious intentions arise as a result of brain activity. This contrasts with traditional concepts of free will, in which the mind controls the body. A more recent study by Haggard and Eimer has further examined the relation between intention and brain processes, concluding that conscious awareness of intention is linked to the choice or selection of a specific action, and not to the earliest initiation of action processes. The exchange of views in this paper further explores the relation between conscious intention and brain activity.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;P. Haggard&quot;,&quot;B. Libet&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2001,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Consciousness Studies&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/intention-brain-activity-haggard/1c74027863395287878ef3d7a5057ef7/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:2},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Functional imaging of \u2018theory of mind\u2019&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Our ability to explain and predict other people&#x27;s behaviour by attributing to them independent mental states, such as beliefs and desires, is known as having a &#x27;theory of mind&#x27;. Interest in this very human ability has engendered a growing body of evidence concerning its evolution and development and the biological basis of the mechanisms underpinning it. Functional imaging has played a key role in seeking to isolate brain regions specific to this ability. Three areas are consistently activated in association with theory of mind. These are the anterior paracingulate cortex, the superior temporal sulci and the temporal poles bilaterally. This review discusses the functional significance of each of these areas within a social cognitive network.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;H. Gallagher&quot;,&quot;C. Frith&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2003,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Trends in Cognitive Sciences&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/imaging-theory-mind-gallagher/4474a7c036e9560a975365d35c8ea6c0/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/S1364-6613(02)00025-6&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;7&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;77-83&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:3},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Intentional Minds: A Philosophical Analysis of Intention Tested through fMRI Experiments Involving People with Schizophrenia, People with Autism, and Healthy Individuals&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;In this paper we show how we empirically tested one of the most relevant topics in philosophy of mind through a series of fMRI experiments: the classification of different types of intention. To this aim, firstly we trace a theoretical distinction among private, prospective, and communicative intentions. Second, we propose a set of predictions concerning the recognition of these three types of intention in healthy individuals, and we report the experimental results corroborating our theoretical model of intention. Third, we derive from our model predictions relevant for the domain of psychopathological functioning. In particular, we treat the cases of both hyper-intentionality (as in paranoid schizophrenia) and hypo-intentionality (as in autistic spectrum disorders). Our conclusion is that the theoretical model of intention we propose contributes to enlarge our knowledge on the neurobiological bases of intention processing, in both healthy people and in people with impairments to the neurocognitive system that underlies intention recognition.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Bara&quot;,&quot;A. Ciaramidaro&quot;,&quot;H. Walter&quot;,&quot;M. Adenzato&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2011,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Frontiers in Human Neuroscience&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/minds-philosophical-analysis-intention-tested-fmri-bara/b729cec08e4156ebb5a693e7a7617c6b/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.3389/fnhum.2011.00007&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;5&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:4},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Frontal Lobe Contributions to Theory of Mind&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Theory of mind, the ability to make inferences about others&#x27; mental states, seems to be a modular cognitive capacity that underlies humans&#x27; ability to engage in complex social interaction. It develops in several distinct stages, which can be measured with social reasoning tests of increasing difficulty. Individuals with Asperger&#x27;s syndrome, a mild form of autism, perform well on simpler theory of mind tests but show deficits on more developmentally advanced theory of mind tests. We tested patients with bilateral damage to orbito-frontal cortex (n = 5) and unilateral damage in left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (n = 5) on a series of theory of mind tasks varying in difficulty. Bilateral orbito-frontal lesion patients performed similarly to individuals with Asperger&#x27;s syndrome, performing well on simpler tests and showing deficits on tasks requiring more subtle social reasoning, such as the ability to recognize a faux pas. In contrast, no specific theory of mind deficits were evident in the unilateral dorsolateral frontal lesion patients. The dorsolateral lesion patients had difficulty only on versions of the tasks that placed demands on working memory.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Valerie E. Stone&quot;,&quot;Simon Baron-Cohen&quot;,&quot;Robert T. Knight&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1998,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/frontal-lobe-contributions-theory-mind-stone/01d8d03396025aa4b2a1e61e6a47e4ac/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1162/089892998562942&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;10&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;640-656&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:5},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Lay theories of willpower&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Some people believe that willpower relies on a limited resource and that performing cognitive work (such as using self-control) results in mental fatigue. Others believe that willpower is nonlimited and that performing cognitive work instead prepares and energizes them for more. These differing lay theories of willpower determine whether or not one\u2019s self-control performance actually does decrease or increase after use, with only limited-willpower theorists showing a decrease (the ego depletion effect). Due to the self-control requirements of everyday life, willpower theories also predict outcomes across domains of academics, health, goal-progress, interpersonal relationships, and well-being. Generally, limited-willpower theorists\u2019 belief in their limited capacity results in poorer outcomes, particularly during times of high demand. By understanding how willpower theories form and function, interventions that encourage nonlimited willpower theories may be created to improve people\u2019s performance and well-being.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Z. Francis&quot;,&quot;V. Job&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2018,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Social and Personality Psychology Compass&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/theories-willpower-francis/073b6a02c5725b1c905dde069dee2f79/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1111/SPC3.12381&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;12&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:6},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Philosophy of Mind&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Philosophy of mind concerns questions about mental phenomena that empirical research alone can&#x27;t settle, such as the nature of mental states and which sorts of things can have them-only living things, or also machines? Settling them requires reflection on such phenomena as consciousness, rationality, and intentionality; the &#x27;explanatory gaps&#x27; that seem to exist between these; and underlying physical phenomena and the different strategies-dualist, eliminativist, physicalist, and functionalist-that have been proposed for dealing with them. Copyright \u00a9 2010 John Wiley &amp; Sons, Ltd. For further resources related to this article, please visit the WIREs website.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Berit Brogaard&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2006,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/philosophy-mind-brogaard/21d8edb78e84531a98892d73fad0c099/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1163/1877-5888_rpp_sim_124381&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:7},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The intentional network: How the brain reads varieties of intentions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Social neuroscience provides insights into the neural correlates of the human capacity to explain and predict other people&#x27;s intentions, a capacity that lies at the core of the Theory of Mind (ToM) mechanism. Results from neuroimaging research describe a widely distributed neural system underlying ToM, including the right and left temporo-parietal junctions (TPJ), the precuneus, and the medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC). Nevertheless, there is disagreement in the literature concerning the key region for the ToM network. Some authors point to the MPFC, others to the right TPJ. In the effort to make a contribution to the debate, we propose a model of a dynamic ToM network consisting of four regions. We also introduce a novel theoretical distinction among varieties of intention, which differ by the nature of an individual&#x27;s pursued goal (private or social) and by the social interaction&#x27;s temporal dimension (present or future). Our results confirm the crucial role of both the MPFC and the right TPJ, but show that these areas are differentially engaged depending on the nature of the intention involved. Whereas the right TPJ and the precuneus are necessary for processing all types of prior intentions, the left TPJ and the anterior paracingulate cortex are specifically involved in the understanding of social intention. More specifically, the left TPJ is activated only when a subset of social intentions are involved (communicative intentions). Taken together, these results demonstrate the progressive recruitment of the ToM network along the theoretical dimensions introduced in the present paper.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;A. Ciaramidaro&quot;,&quot;A. Ciaramidaro&quot;,&quot;M. Adenzato&quot;,&quot;Ivan Enrici&quot;,&quot;S. Erk&quot;,&quot;Lorenzo Pia&quot;,&quot;Lorenzo Pia&quot;,&quot;B. Bara&quot;,&quot;Henrik Walter&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2007,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Neuropsychologia&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/network-brain-reads-varieties-intentions-ciaramidaro/ec017cc8e2675f9886c96108b6fb4b54/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.neuropsychologia.2007.05.011&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;45&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;3105-3113&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:8},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;A hot/cool-system analysis of delay of gratification: dynamics of willpower.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;A 2-system framework is proposed for understanding the processes that enable--and undermine--self-control or \\&quot;willpower\\&quot; as exemplified in the delay of gratification paradigm. A cool, cognitive \\&quot;know\\&quot; system and a hot, emotional \\&quot;go\\&quot; system are postulated. The cool system is cognitive, emotionally neutral, contemplative, flexible, integrated, coherent, spatiotemporal, slow, episodic, and strategic. It is the seat of self-regulation and self-control. The hot system is the basis of emotionality, fears as well as passions--impulsive and reflexive--initially controlled by innate releasing stimuli (and, thus, literally under \\&quot;stimulus control\\&quot;): it is fundamental for emotional (classical) conditioning and undermines efforts at self-control. The balance between the hot and cool systems is determined by stress, developmental level, and the individual&#x27;s self-regulatory dynamics. The interactions between these systems allow explanation of findings on willpower from 3 decades of research.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. Metcalfe&quot;,&quot;W. Mischel&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1999,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Psychological review&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/hotcoolsystem-analysis-delay-gratification-dynamics-metcalfe/12d45c32dea15aa1b6a39c82cf8e0112/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0033-295X.106.1.3&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;106 1&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          3-19\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:9},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Willpower and perceived behavioral control: Influences on the intention-behavior relationship and postbehavior attributions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Individual differences in willpower (a subdimension of conscientiousness) and perceived behavioral control (PBC: cognition regarding extent of control over an action; Ajzen, 1985) in the intention-behavior relationship were explored to better understand when intention will be completed to action. The impact of these constructs in postbehavior attributions also was explored. Participants were traditional and nontraditional students (N = 325) preparing for examinations at two time periods. Rather than confirming main effects proposed by prior research (e.g., Ajzen), moderation effects characterized these data. At Time 1, individuals higher in willpower behaved more consistently with their intentions. At Time 2, individuals higher in PBC showed a similar effect. Lower willpower also led subjects to make less attribution to effort when expectations were exceeded.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Judy L. Fitch&quot;,&quot;Elizabeth C. Ravlin&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2005,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Social Behavior and Personality&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/willpower-perceived-control-influences-fitch/99d5941af38155b98d9f6fab0f9a2c52/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.2224/SBP.2005.33.2.105&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;33&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;105-124&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:10},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;A novel task assessing intention and emotion attribution: Italian standardization and normative data of the Story-based Empathy Task&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Theory of Mind (ToM), the process by which an individual imputes mental states to himself and others, is presently considered as a multidimensional cognitive domain, with two main facets (i.e., cognitive and affective ToM) accounting, respectively, for the ability to understand others\u2019 intention (intention attribution-IA) and emotions (emotion attribution-EA). Despite the large amount of literature investigating the behavioural and neural bases of mentalizing abilities in neurological conditions, there is still a lack of validated neuropsychological tools specifically designed to assess such skills. Here, we report the normative data of the Story-Based Empathy Task (SET), a non-verbal test developed for the assessment of intention and emotion attribution in the neurodegenerative conditions characterized by the impairment of social\u2013emotional abilities. It is an easy-to-administer task including 18 stimuli, sub-grouped into two experimental conditions assessing, respectively, the ability to infer others\u2019 intentions (SET-IA) and emotions (SET-EA), compared to a control condition of causal inference (SET-CI). Normative data were collected in 136 Italian subjects pooled across subgroups homogenous for age (range 20\u201379\u00a0years), sex, and education (at least 5\u00a0years). The results show a detrimental effect of age and a beneficial effect of education on both the global score and each subscale, for which we provide correction grids. This new task could be a useful tool to investigate both affective and cognitive aspects of ToM in the course of disorders of socio-emotional behaviour, such as the fronto-temporal dementia spectrum.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;A. Dodich&quot;,&quot;C. Cerami&quot;,&quot;N. Canessa&quot;,&quot;C. Crespi&quot;,&quot;S. Iannaccone&quot;,&quot;A. Marcone&quot;,&quot;S. Realmuto&quot;,&quot;G. Lettieri&quot;,&quot;D. Perani&quot;,&quot;S. Cappa&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2015,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Neurological Sciences&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/task-assessing-intention-emotion-attribution-dodich/857d4ac6161858fcb81a2793964f046f/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1007/s10072-015-2281-3&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;36&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1907-1912&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:11},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Healthcare professionals&#x27; intentions and behaviours: A systematic review of studies based on social cognitive theories&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;BackgroundThere is an important gap between the implications of clinical research evidence and the routine clinical practice of healthcare professionals. Because individual decisions are often central to adoption of a clinical-related behaviour, more information about the cognitive mechanisms underlying behaviours is needed to improve behaviour change interventions targeting healthcare professionals. The aim of this study was to systematically review the published scientific literature about factors influencing health professionals&#x27; behaviours based on social cognitive theories. These theories refer to theories where individual cognitions/thoughts are viewed as processes intervening between observable stimuli and responses in real world situations.MethodsWe searched psycINFO, MEDLINE, EMBASE, CIHNAL, Index to theses, PROQUEST dissertations and theses and Current Contents for articles published in English only. We included studies that aimed to predict healthcare professionals&#x27; intentions and behaviours with a clear specification of relying on a social cognitive theory. Information on percent of explained variance (R2) was used to compute the overall frequency-weighted mean R2 to evaluate the efficacy of prediction in several contexts and according to different methodological aspects. The cognitive factors most consistently associated with prediction of healthcare professionals&#x27; intention and behaviours were documented.ResultsSeventy eight studies met the inclusion criteria. Among these studies, 72 provided information on the determinants of intention and 16 prospective studies provided information on the determinants of behaviour. The theory most often used as reference was the Theory of Reasoned Action (TRA) or its extension the Theory of Planned Behaviour (TPB). An overall frequency-weighted mean R2 of 0.31 was observed for the prediction of behaviour; 0.59 for the prediction of intention. A number of moderators influenced the efficacy of prediction; frequency-weighted mean R2 varied from 0.001 to 0.58 for behaviour and 0.19 to 0.81 for intention.ConclusionOur results suggest that the TPB appears to be an appropriate theory to predict behaviour whereas other theories better capture the dynamic underlying intention. In addition, given the variations in efficacy of prediction, special care should be given to methodological issues, especially to better define the context of behaviour performance.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;G. Godin&quot;,&quot;A. Belanger-Gravel&quot;,&quot;M. Eccles&quot;,&quot;J. Grimshaw&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2008,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Implementation Science : IS&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/healthcare-professionals-intentions-behaviours-review-godin/8ff403f65fdd5b91be6f1912951bdf5b/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1186/1748-5908-3-36&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;3&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;36 - 36&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:12},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The getting of wisdom: theory of mind in old age.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Theory of mind, the ability to attribute mental states, has been little explored beyond the early school years. Yet, later development, including possible patterns of breakdown, has important implications for current debate concerning the modularity/domain-specificity of the cognitive and neurological systems underlying theory of mind. This article reports a first study of theory of mind in normal aging. The results suggest that although performance on tasks with nonmental content may decrease with age, performance on theory of mind tasks remains intact and may even improve over the later adult years. The implications of these findings for the cognitive processes underlying theory of mind are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Francesca Happ\u00e9&quot;,&quot;Ellen Winner&quot;,&quot;H. Brownell&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1998,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Developmental psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/getting-wisdom-theory-mind-happ\u00e9/09942a44d1ed519ea6fc68505327adc8/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0012-1649.34.2.358&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;34 2&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          358-62\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:13},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;For the law, neuroscience changes nothing and everything.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The rapidly growing field of cognitive neuroscience holds the promise of explaining the operations of the mind in terms of the physical operations of the brain. Some suggest that our emerging understanding of the physical causes of human (mis)behaviour will have a transformative effect on the law. Others argue that new neuroscience will provide only new details and that existing legal doctrine can accommodate whatever new information neuroscience will provide. We argue that neuroscience will probably have a transformative effect on the law, despite the fact that existing legal doctrine can, in principle, accommodate whatever neuroscience will tell us. New neuroscience will change the law, not by undermining its current assumptions, but by transforming people&#x27;s moral intuitions about free will and responsibility. This change in moral outlook will result not from the discovery of crucial new facts or clever new arguments, but from a new appreciation of old arguments, bolstered by vivid new illustrations provided by cognitive neuroscience. We foresee, and recommend, a shift away from punishment aimed at retribution in favour of a more progressive, consequentialist approach to the criminal law.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Joshua D. Greene&quot;,&quot;J. Cohen&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2004,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Philosophical transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological sciences&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/neuroscience-changes-nothing-everything-greene/c9239ad4a6695c57b1c4a9c51672e1be/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1098/RSTB.2004.1546&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;359 1451&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          1775-85\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:14},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Intention Concepts and Brain-Machine Interfacing&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Intentions, including their temporal properties and semantic content, are receiving increased attention, and neuroscientific studies in humans vary with respect to the topography of intention-related neural responses. This may reflect the fact that the kind of intentions investigated in one study may not be exactly the same kind investigated in the other. Fine-grained intention taxonomies developed in the philosophy of mind may be useful to identify the neural correlates of well-defined types of intentions, as well as to disentangle them from other related mental states, such as mere urges to perform an action. Intention-related neural signals may be exploited by brain-machine interfaces (BMIs) that are currently being developed to restore speech and motor control in paralyzed patients. Such BMI devices record the brain activity of the agent, interpret (\u201cdecode\u201d) the agent\u2019s intended action, and send the corresponding execution command to an artificial effector system, e.g., a computer cursor or a robotic arm. In the present paper, we evaluate the potential of intention concepts from philosophy of mind to improve the performance and safety of BMIs based on higher-order, intention-related control signals. To this end, we address the distinction between future-, present-directed, and motor intentions, as well as the organization of intentions in time, specifically to what extent it is sequential or hierarchical. This has consequences as to whether these different types of intentions can be expected to occur simultaneously or not. We further illustrate how it may be useful or even necessary to distinguish types of intentions exposited in philosophy, including yes- vs. no-intentions and oblique vs. direct intentions, to accurately decode the agent\u2019s intentions from neural signals in practical BMI applications.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;F. Thinnes-Elker&quot;,&quot;O. Iljina&quot;,&quot;John K. Apostolides&quot;,&quot;Felicitas Kraemer&quot;,&quot;A. Schulze-Bonhage&quot;,&quot;A. Aertsen&quot;,&quot;T. Ball&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2012,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Frontiers in Psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/intention-concepts-brainmachine-interfacing-thinneselker/74ce4771696b562dbe52b81d533390b7/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.3389/fpsyg.2012.00455&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;3&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:15},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Intention, cognitive commitment, and planning&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This paper defends a cognitive-motivational account of intending against recent criticism by J. Garcia, connects intending with a number of other concepts important in the theory of action \u2014 including decison, volition, and planning \u2014 and explores some principles of intention transfer construed as counterparts of epistemic principles governing closure for belief and justification. Several routes to intention formation are described; the role of intentions in planning is examined; and a holistic conception of intention formation and change is stressed. The proposed conception of intending as embodying at once a cognitive and a motivational commitment to action is thus shown to help in understanding both the explanation of action and the rationality of agents.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;R. Audi&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1991,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Synthese&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/intention-commitment-planning-audi/2fdcb5cb49c35370b3d99ad0148b1174/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1007/BF00485266&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;86&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;361-378&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:16},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Exploring theory of mind after severe traumatic brain injury&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Previous studies have reported a dissociation between social behavioral impairments after severe traumatic brain injury (TBI) and relatively preserved performances in traditional tasks that investigate cognitive abilities. Theory of mind (ToM) refers to the ability to make inferences about other&#x27;s mental states and use them to understand and predict others&#x27; behavior. We tested a group of 15 patients with severe TBI and 15 matched controls on a series of four verbal and non-verbal ToM tasks: the faux pas test, the first-order and second-order false belief task, the character intention task and the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test. Participants with severe TBI were also compared to controls on non-ToM inference tasks of indirect speech act from the Montreal Evaluation of Communication (M.E.C.) Protocol and empathy (Davis Interpersonal Reactivity Index - I.R.I.) and tests for executive functions. Subjects with TBI performed worse than control subjects on all ToM tasks, except the first-order false belief task. The findings converge with previous evidence for ToM deficit in TBI and dissociation between ToM and executive functions. We show that ToM deficit is probably distinct from other aspects of social cognition like empathy and pragmatic communication skills.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;F. Muller&quot;,&quot;A. Simion&quot;,&quot;Elsa Reviriego&quot;,&quot;C. Gal\u00e9ra&quot;,&quot;J. Mazaux&quot;,&quot;M. Barat&quot;,&quot;P. Joseph&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2010,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Cortex&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/exploring-theory-mind-brain-injury-muller/f0e24ed2399b5bb38a871d8d91d5deb0/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.cortex.2009.08.014&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;46&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1088-1099&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:17},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Understanding Intention for Machine Theory of Mind: a Position Paper&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Theory of Mind is often characterized as the ability to recognize desires, beliefs, and intentions of others. In this position paper, I look at the literature on modeling Theory of Mind in machines and find that, to date, intention is not usually a focus. I define what I mean by intention\u2014 choice with commitment\u2014following prior work. Intention has a long history of research in some communities, and I offer one theoretical framework for modeling intention as a starting point. I take inspiration from how children learn intention through joint attention with others and how that leads to Theory of Mind. I argue that though models of machine Theory of Mind need not follow the same learning progression as children, intention is an aspect of Theory of Mind that should be more explicit.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;C. Kennington&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2022,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;2022 31st IEEE International Conference on Robot and Human Interactive Communication (RO-MAN)&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/understanding-intention-machine-theory-mind-position-kennington/5429f6ec3e73543eb103d9af4d5bd466/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1109/RO-MAN53752.2022.9900783&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;450-453&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:18},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Attention to Intention&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Intention is central to the concept of voluntary action. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, we compared conditions in which participants made self-paced actions and attended either to their intention to move or to the actual movement. When they attended to their intention rather than their movement, there was an enhancement of activity in the pre-supplementary motor area (pre-SMA). We also found activations in the right dorsal prefrontal cortexand left intraparietal cortex. Prefrontal activity, but not parietal activity, was more strongly coupled with activity in the pre-SMA. We conclude that activity in the pre-SMA reflects the representation of intention.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;H. Lau&quot;,&quot;R. Rogers&quot;,&quot;P. Haggard&quot;,&quot;R. Passingham&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2004,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Science&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/attention-intention-lau/5d01fd9ed587529e932c2b9d05eeab52/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1126/SCIENCE.1090973&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;303&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1208 - 1210&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:19},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;A componential view of theory of mind: evidence from Williams syndrome&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;In this paper we argue that there are two distinct components of a theory of mind: a social-cognitive and a social-perceptual component. Evidence for this proposal is presented from various sources, including studies of children with Williams syndrome, a rare genetic neurodevelopmental disorder. Earlier work has demonstrated that people with Williams syndrome appear to be spared in the social-perceptual component of a theory of mind. In this paper we present evidence that they are not spared in the social-cognitive component of theory of mind. Three experiments with young children with Williams syndrome were conducted. In each experiment the children with Williams syndrome were compared to age-, IQ-, and language-matched children with Prader-Willi syndrome, and children with non-specific mental retardation. The experiments used different measures of theory of mind ability, including false belief (Experiment 1), explanation of action (Experiment 2), and recognition of emotional expressions (Experiment 3). In none of these experiments did the children with Williams syndrome evidence superior performance compared to the control groups. The results from this and other studies on Williams syndrome support the view that the social-cognitive and social-perceptual components of a theory of mind are dissociable. In Williams syndrome only the latter components, which are linked to distinct neurobiological substrates, are spared.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;H. Tager-Flusberg&quot;,&quot;K. into the realms of cognitive neuroscience, philosophy of mind, and psychology, a significant article to consider is &quot;Conscious intention and motor cognition&quot; by P. Haggard, published in Trends in Cognitive Sciences. This article examines the neuroscientific perspective on conscious intentions and their role in motor actions, discussing the implications for our understanding of free will and self-control. Haggard&#x27;s work challenges traditional views of conscious intentions leading actions and instead proposes that these experiences arise from brain preparations for action, providing a modern context for the philosophical debates on intentionality and the psychological aspects of self-regulation [(Haggard, 2005)](https://consensus.app/papers/intention-motor-cognition-haggard/17b609fc3d54561e8cd455f937a543c6/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nThis study, along with related research, promises additional insights and practical strategies for unlocking our full potential by understanding the complex interplay between our intentions, our brain&#x27;s predictive mechanisms, and our subsequent behaviors. Here are the primary philosophical paradigms presented in the novel:\n\n1. **Critique of Optimism:** The most prominent target of Voltaire&#x27;s satire is the philosophical optimism advocated by Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, which is epitomized in the character of Pangloss. This philosophy asserts that, since God is benevolent, the world he created must be the best of all possible worlds. Through the relentless misfortunes that befall Candide and his companions, Voltaire ridicules the naivety of this unwavering optimism.\n\n2. **Questioning of Religion and Clerical Power:** Voltaire, through various characters and scenarios in &quot;Candide,&quot; critiques the corruption, hypocrisy, and ineptitude of religious figures and institutions. This reflects his broader criticism of the church&#x27;s role in society and its interference in politics and personal freedoms.\n\n3. **Criticism of War and Violence:** The novel depicts several brutal scenes of war and violence, criticizing the senselessness and cruelty of these human endeavors. Voltaire condemns the destruction and suffering caused by war, challenging the glorification of military conquest prevalent in his time.\n\n4. **Examination of Human Suffering and Evil:** Throughout &quot;Candide,&quot; the characters encounter natural disasters, human cruelty, and random misfortune, leading to a profound examination of the nature of suffering and evil in the world. This challenges readers to consider the reasons behind human suffering and the existence of evil.\n\n5. **Exploration of Personal Freedom and Autonomy:** The journey of Candide is also one of personal growth and discovery. The novel explores themes of freedom, choice, and individual autonomy, questioning societal norms and the pursuit of happiness.\n\n6. **Satire of Aristocracy and Social Class:** Voltaire uses his characters and their misadventures to mock the pretensions and inequities of the European aristocracy and class system, highlighting the absurdity and injustice of inherited status and wealth.\n\n7. **Advocacy of Practical Philosophy and Work:** In the conclusion of the novel, Candide and his friends find some measure of peace in gardening and work, which Voltaire suggests as a remedy to idle speculation and philosophical abstraction. This can be seen as advocating a more pragmatic, down-to-earth approach to life&#x27;s challenges.\n\nOverall, &quot;Candide&quot; presents a multifaceted critique of the philosophical, religious, and social attitudes of Voltaire&#x27;s time, promoting skepticism, practical engagement with the world, and the questioning of dogma and authority."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

"update_time": 1709222065.0908365, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The science of self-help: Translating positive psychology research into increased individual happiness&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive psychology aims to understand the positive side of human functioning, expanding research on positive behaviors, cognitions, emotions, and character traits. The findings of this research have highlighted strategies (e.g., savoring, gratitude, kindness, social relationships, and hope and meaning) that, when practiced, lead to increases in individual happiness. Researchers and practitioners have translated these strategies into effective interventions that can be disseminated directly to individuals, allowing them to actively pursue greater levels of happiness. We present a summary of the current state of positive psychological interventions as they pertain to self-help. A major focus in the application of positive psychological interventions for self-help is dissemination - ensuring that those interested have access to evidence-based strategies to increase their happiness. The future of self- help involves spreading these practices through classes, workshops, books, and increasingly prevalent technologies such as Internet sites and mobile applications. We outline unique concerns related to providing self-help in the absence of professional support including motivation and engagement, variety and flexibility, and person-activity fit. As positive psychology has developed a host of evidence-based practices, the next stage of research requires implementing these strategies in ways to support their use in real-world contexts.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. Schueller&quot;,&quot;A. Parks&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2014,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;European Psychologist&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/science-selfhelp-translating-psychology-research-schueller/fa23fd811e385439849e0a2dccb5736d/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1027/1016-9040/A000181&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;19&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;145-155&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:1},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Benefits of Frequent Positive Affect: Does Happiness Lead to Success?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Numerous studies show that happy individuals are successful across multiple life domains, including marriage, friendship, income, work performance, and health. The authors suggest a conceptual model to account for these findings, arguing that the happiness-success link exists not only because success makes people happy, but also because positive affect engenders success. Three classes of evidence--crosssectional, longitudinal, and experimental--are documented to test their model. Relevant studies are described and their effect sizes combined meta-analytically. The results reveal that happiness is associated with and precedes numerous successful outcomes, as well as behaviors paralleling success. Furthermore, the evidence suggests that positive affect--the hallmark of well-being--may be the cause of many of the desirable characteristics, resources, and successes correlated with happiness. Limitations, empirical issues, and important future research questions are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. Lyubomirsky&quot;,&quot;L. King&quot;,&quot;E. Diener&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2005,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/benefits-frequent-positive-affect-does-happiness-lead-lyubomirsky/f7a25f49b01f5633a4499b4a3700c47a/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0033-2909.131.6.803&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:2},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Happiness as a treatment goal.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Happiness is a concept reflecting general satisfaction with one&#x27;s life and with oneself, not necessarily congruent with objective indicators. A most important ingredient is a positive self-image, depending, in turn, on positive perception of self as compared to one&#x27;s peers and to the expectations of important figures in one&#x27;s life. This requires understanding of personal strengths and constructive acceptance of limitations. Helping individuals develop subjective self-satisfaction should be the goal in any treatment program, achieved through direct therapeutic interventions as well as environmental supports (e.g., provision of opportunities for success). It is essential that service providers differentiate between their own values, goals, and administrative requirements and the individual&#x27;s personal preferences and wishes.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;L. Szymanski&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2000,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;American journal of mental retardation : AJMR&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/happiness-treatment-goal-szymanski/ce9be9a11d00577c8e428af203d077e3/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1352/0895-8017(2000)105&lt;0352:HAATG&gt;2.0.CO;2&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;105 5&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          352-62\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:3},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Happiness and Virtue in Positive Psychology&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive psychologists aspire to study the moral virtues, as well as positive emotions, while retaining scientific objectivity. Within this framework, Martin Seligman, a founder of positive psychology, offers an empirically-based argument for an ancient and venerable theme: happiness can be increased by exercising the virtues. Seligman&#x27;s project is promising, but it needs to pay greater attention to several methodological matters: (1) greater care in defining happiness, so as to avoid smuggling in value assumptions of the sort suggested by the title of his book, Authentic Happiness; (2) more attention to the gap between happiness as overall satisfaction and specific gratifications (enjoyments); (3) the danger of sliding to subjectivism by equating self-assessments of virtue with objectively-justified values of the sort Aristotle had in mind; (4) awareness of how \u201cpositive\u201d emotions and attitudes presuppose value assumptions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Mike W. Martin&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2007,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal for The Theory of Social Behaviour&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/happiness-virtue-positive-psychology-martin/67751a3969b45e15ba57ac248c6703ac/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1111/J.1468-5914.2007.00322.X&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;37&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;89-103&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:4},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Two conceptions of happiness: Contrasts of personal expressiveness (eudaimonia) and hedonic enjoyment.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Aristotle&#x27;s concept of eudaimonia and hedonic enjoyment constitute 2 philosophical conceptions of happiness. Two studies involving combined samples of undergraduate and graduate students (Study 1, N = 209; Study 2, N = 249) were undertaken to identify the convergent and divergent aspects of these constructs. As expected, there was a strong positive correlation between personal expressiveness (eudaimonia) and hedonic enjoyment. Analyses revealed significant differences between the 2 conceptions of happiness experienced in conjunction with activities for the variables of (a) opportunities for satisfaction, (b) strength of cognitive-affective components, (c) level of challenges, (d) level of skills, and (e) importance. It thus appears that the 2 conceptions of happiness are related but distinguishable and that personal expressiveness, but not hedonic enjoyment, is a signifier of success in the process of self-realization. The qualities deemed to represent optimal, healthy, or effective psychological functioning have been a perennial concern within personality psychology. However, work on optimal functioning has generally been carried out within diverse theoretical systems with few efforts made to interrelate or integrate concepts proposed as optimal within the different theories. Four such constructs are (a) a sense of personal identity (Erikson, 1963, 1968\u2014ego analytic theory), (b) self-actualization (Maslow, 1968,1970\u2014humanistic theory), (c) an internal locus of control (Rotter, 1966\u2014social learning theory), and (d) principled moral reasoning (Gilligan, 1982, Kohlberg, 1969\u2014cognitive developmental theory). In an analysis of the philosophical underpinnings of these constructs, I (Waterman, 1981, 1984) have demonstrated that they share individualistic philosophical assumptions regarding the role of self-realization as a component of optimal psychological functioning. The philosophical theory that corresponds to the perspectives advanced with regard to each of the four constructs, and that is foundational to claims made for each, is eudaimonism.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;A. It highlights the components of self-management which provides the sense of positivity in achieving individuals working and life goal. It has taken some quotations from the holy book Bhagvat Gita to justify the content of self-management.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Khagendra Bahadur Niroula&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2020,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Management&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/tool-positive-psychology-niroula/bdc1b340ebb15a85a749c5378daa8f31/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.3126/jom.v3i1.30913&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:6},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Becoming happier takes both a will and a proper way: an experimental longitudinal intervention to boost well-being.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;An 8-month-long experimental study examined the immediate and longer term effects of regularly practicing two assigned positive activities (expressing optimism and gratitude) on well-being. More important, this intervention allowed us to explore the impact of two metafactors that are likely to influence the success of any positive activity: whether one self-selects into the study knowing that it is about increasing happiness and whether one invests effort into the activity over time. Our results indicate that initial self-selection makes a difference, but only in the two positive activity conditions, not the control, and that continued effort also makes a difference, but, again, only in the treatment conditions. We conclude that happiness interventions are more than just placebos, but that they are most successful when participants know about, endorse, and commit to the intervention.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. Lyubomirsky&quot;,&quot;R. Dickerhoof&quot;,&quot;Julia K. Boehm&quot;,&quot;Kennon M. Sheldon&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2011,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Emotion&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/becoming-takes-intervention-boost-wellbeing-lyubomirsky/8711efa52a915f608e77ceb474be0c81/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/a0022575&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;11 2&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          391-402\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:7},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Personality, culture, and subjective well-being: emotional and cognitive evaluations of life.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Subjective well-being (SWB), people&#x27;s emotional and cognitive evaluations of their lives, includes what lay people call happiness, peace, fulfillment, and life satisfaction. Personality dispositions such as extraversion, neuroticism, and self-esteem can markedly influence levels of SWB. Although personality can explain a significant amount of the variability in SWB, life circumstances also influence long-term levels. Cultural variables explain differences in mean levels of SWB and appear to be due to objective factors such as wealth, to norms dictating appropriate feelings and how important SWB is considered to be, and to the relative approach versus avoidance tendencies of societies. Culture can also moderate which variables most influence SWB. Although it is challenging to assess SWB across societies, the measures have some degree of cross-cultural validity. Although nations can be evaluated by their levels of SWB, there are still many open questions in this area.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;E. Diener&quot;,&quot;S. Oishi&quot;,&quot;Richard E. Lucas&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2003,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Annual review of psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/personality-culture-wellbeing-cognitive-evaluations-diener/6a517fd204f95b7099228ec7dfa7d632/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1146/ANNUREV.PSYCH.54.101601.145056&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;54&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          403-25\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:8},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Happiness, the Self and Human Flourishing&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The psychological condition of happiness is normally considered a paradigm subjective good, and is closely associated with subjectivist accounts of well-being. This article argues that the value of happiness is best accounted for by a non-subjectivist approach to welfare: a eudaimonistic account that grounds well-being in the fulfillment of our natures, specifically in self-fulfillment. And self-fulfillment consists partly in authentic happiness. A major reason for this is that happiness, conceived in terms of emotional state, bears a special relationship to the self. These arguments also point to a more sentimentalist approach to well-being than one finds in most contemporary accounts, particularly among Aristotelian forms of eudaimonism.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Daniel M. Haybron&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2008,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Utilitas&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/happiness-self-human-flourishing-haybron/9351e73fd4c55823b1918f605e3d2623/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1017/S0953820807002889&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;20&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;21 - 49&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:9},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Construct and Measurement of Peace of Mind&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Previous studies have shown that Asian American or Chinese individuals value low-arousal positive affect and a harmonious state of happiness more than European Americans do. However, the affective component of subjective well-being has mostly been defined as the presence of positive affect and the absence of negative affect. This definition emphasizes the importance of hedonic pleasure but fails to include the affect valued in Chinese culture. The present study developed the construct of peace of mind to describe the affective well-being valued in Chinese culture. Peace of mind was defined as an internal state of peacefulness and harmony. To develop a measure to assess peace of mind, three studies were conducted. Study 1 developed the Peace of Mind Scale (PoM), Study 2 established its validity as an affective well-being measure, and Study 3 found that individuals from Chinese cultures score higher on this scale than those from Western cultures. The results indicate that the PoM has good reliability and validity for measuring affective well-being. The cross-cultural validation also found that Taiwanese individuals scored higher on the PoM than European Americans, which provides further evidence of good construct validity of the PoM.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Yi-Chen Lee&quot;,&quot;Y. Lin&quot;,&quot;Chin-Lan Huang&quot;,&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2013,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Happiness Studies&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/construct-measurement-peace-mind-lee/3b777a641c01528fa3c559774ddf4c43/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1007/S10902-012-9343-5&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;14&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;571-590&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:10},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Prioritizing positivity: an effective approach to pursuing happiness?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;A decade of research reveals the benefits of positive emotions for mental and physical health; however, recent empirical work suggests the explicit pursuit of happiness may backfire. The present study hypothesized that the pursuit of happiness is not inherently self-defeating; in particular, individuals who seek positivity, as exemplified by how they make decisions about how to organize their day-to-day lives, may be happier. This individual difference is labeled prioritizing positivity. In a community sample of young to older adults (N = 233), prioritizing positivity predicted a host of well-being outcomes (positive emotions, depressive symptomology). In addition, people high in prioritizing positivity have greater resources, and these links are explained by more frequent experiences of positive emotions. In sum, the present study suggests that seeking happiness, although a delicate art, may be a worthwhile pursuit.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Lahnna I Catalino&quot;,&quot;S. Algoe&quot;,&quot;B. Participants (N\u00a0=\u00a0621), retired employees ages 51\u201395, completed standardized measures of affect, personality, psychosocial characteristics, physical health, and demographics. The relations between each of the two target variables (happiness and self-esteem) and the full set of remaining variables were assessed through a series of successive statistical analyses: (1) simple Pearson\u2019s correlations, (2) partial correlations, and (3) hierarchical regression analyses. The results revealed that happiness and self-esteem, while highly correlated (r\u00a0=\u00a00.58), presented unique patterns of relations with the other measured variables. The best predictors of happiness were the following: mood and temperamental traits (i.e., extraversion and neuroticism), social relationships (lack of loneliness and satisfaction with friendships), purpose in life, and global life satisfaction. By contrast, self-esteem was best predicted by dispositions related to agency and motivation (i.e., optimism and lack of hopelessness). Implications for the understanding of happiness and self-esteem are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. Lyubomirsky&quot;,&quot;Chris Tkach&quot;,&quot;M. This chapter encourages the reader to consider what personal happiness is to them. The definition of happiness is individual for each person but can be thought of as consisting of five main factors: positive emotions, engagement, relationships, meaning, and accomplishments. Happiness has genetic and environmental determinants. A survey of the history of concepts of happiness is offered, including the work of the Greek philosophers, Aristotle and Epicurus. Martin Seligman\u2019s PERMATM model, common measures of happiness, recent studies of the biological bases of happiness, the concept of the hedonic treadmill, and the value of expectation management are introduced. We examined the contrary prediction that positive self-statements can be ineffective or even harmful. A survey study confirmed that people often use positive self-statements and believe them to be effective. Two experiments showed that among participants with low self-esteem, those who repeated a positive self-statement (\u201cI&#x27;m a lovable person\u201d) or who focused on how that statement was true felt worse than those who did not repeat the statement or who focused on how it was both true and not true. Among participants with high self-esteem, those who repeated the statement or focused on how it was true felt better than those who did not, but to a limited degree. Repeating positive self-statements may benefit certain people, but backfire for the very people who \u201cneed\u201d them the most.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. V. Wood&quot;,&quot;W.Q. Positive thinking corresponds to the latent dimension underlying life satisfaction, self-esteem, and optimism. Happiness, instead, corresponds to the difference between positive and negative affect, as they are experienced in a variety of daily life situations. The findings of the study corroborated the paths of relations linking the examined variables.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;G. Caprara&quot;,&quot;P. Steca&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2005,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;European Psychologist&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/social-self-regulatory-efficacy-beliefs-determinants-caprara/d8f049402d0f593b94eb7e5a39af8a48/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1027/1016-9040.10.4.275&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;10&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;275-286&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:15},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The analysis and measurement of happiness as a sense of well-being&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;General happiness is philosophically construed as a sense of well-being which in turn has been defined either as a complete and lasting satisfaction with life-as-a-whole or as a preponderance of positive over negative feelings. A factor analysis of thirteen well-being scales shows that these two definitions coalesce into a single general well-being factor which is distinguishable only from an independent stress/worries factor. Further evidence shows that familiar scales of neuroticism, depression and trait anxiety measure the same well-being dimension if only in the negative half-range. So does a list of somatic complaints. Various two-factor models of well-being that treat positive and negative affect as independent processes, or that distinguish between affective and cognitive components, are challenged on the grounds that they depend on the properties of Bradburn\u2019s affect scales which are found to be highly dependent on methodological parameters. Attention is drawn here to the role of test method effects and curvilinearities as factors influencing inter-scale correlations and structural models. It is concluded that well-being is a robust, primary dimension of human experience and that happiness research is alive and well in psychology.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;R. The role of cognitive and motivational processes in well-being.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Addressing the question of why some people are happier than others is important for both theoretical and practical reasons and should be a central goal of a comprehensive positive psychology. Following a construal theory of happiness, the author proposes that multiple cognitive and motivational processes moderate the impact of the objective environment on well-being. Thus, to understand why some people are happier than others, one must understand the cognitive and motivational processes that serve to maintain, and even enhance, enduring happiness and transient mood. The author&#x27;s approach has been to explore hedonically relevant psychological processes, such as social comparison, dissonance reduction, self-reflection, self-evaluation, and person perception, in chronically happy and unhappy individuals. In support of a construal framework, self-rated happy and unhappy people have been shown to differ systematically in the particular cognitive and motivational strategies they use. Promising research directions for positive psychology in pursuit of the sources of happiness, as well as the implications of the construal approach for prescriptions for enhancing well-being, are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. The broaden-and-build theory suggests that this is because positive emotions help people build lasting resources. To test this hypothesis, the authors measured emotions daily for 1 month in a sample of students (N = 86) and assessed life satisfaction and trait resilience at the beginning and end of the month. Positive emotions predicted increases in both resilience and life satisfaction. Negative emotions had weak or null effects and did not interfere with the benefits of positive emotions. Positive emotions also mediated the relation between baseline and final resilience, but life satisfaction did not. This suggests that it is in-the-moment positive emotions, and not more general positive evaluations of one&#x27;s life, that form the link between happiness and desirable life outcomes. Change in resilience mediated the relation between positive emotions and increased life satisfaction, suggesting that happy people become more satisfied not simply because they feel better but because they develop resources for living well.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M.
